{{for|the Hungarian orienteer|András Hegedűs (orienteer)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox President | name= András Hegedüs | image=Hegedűs András 1955.jpg | caption =András Hegedüs in 1955 | nationality=[[Hungary|Hungarian]] | order=45th [[Prime Minister of Hungary]]
4th [[List of Prime Ministers of Hungary|Chairman]] of the [[Council of Ministers of the People's Republic of Hungary]] | term_start=18 April 1955 | term_end=24 October 1956 | predecessor=[[Imre Nagy]] | successor=[[Imre Nagy]] | birth_date={{Birth date|1922|10|31|df=yes}} | birth_place=[[Szilsárkány]], Hungary | death_date={{Death date and age|1999|10|23|1922|10|31|df=yes}} | death_place=[[Budapest]], Hungary | spouse= | party=[[Hungarian Communist Party]],
[[Hungarian Working People's Party]],
[[Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party]] | profession= }} {{eastern name order|Hegedüs András}} '''András Hegedüs''' ({{IPA-hu|ˈɒndraːʃ ˈhɛɡɛdyʃ}}; 31 October 1922 – 23 October 1999) was a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] Communist politician who served as [[Prime Minister of Hungary|Chairman of the Council of Ministers]] from 1955 to 1956. He fled to the Soviet Union on 28 October, the fifth day of the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956]], but returned in 1958 and taught sociology. ==Early years== Coming from a poor family, he finished high school in [[Sopron]] at the Evangelical Academy. Hegedüs first became involved in the underground communist movement during his university years when he studied railway engineering at [[Budapest]] Technical University in 1942. He was not able to finish his studies and was put under house arrest in the August 1944 for two years but managed to escape at the end of November. He became part of the interim government on 24 June 1945. ==1945–1990== In 1947 he married Zsuzsanna Hölzel; they had six children. From 1948 onwards Hegedüs became involved with the [[Hungarian Working People's Party]] eventually taking on leading roles. From the early 1950s he took on numerous ministerial portfolios and served as Prime Minister from 18 April 1955 to 24 October 1956. Hegedüs was 32 years old at the time of his appointment, making him the youngest Prime Minister in Hungarian history. [[File:HegedusAndras.jpg|thumb|left|András Hegedüs in the [[Hungarian Parliament Building|Parliament]] in summer 1956.]] After signing the document asking Soviet troops for assistance during the revolution on 24 October, the government and people overwhelmingly supported him handing power to [[Imre Nagy]]. He became the most hated man in [[Hungary]] and was advised to flee by Soviet ambassador [[Yuri Andropov]] to the [[Soviet Union]] along with other Hungarian hardliners such as [[Ernő Gerő]]. In Moscow, he worked as part of the philosophy department at the Soviet Academy of Sciences between 1957 and 1958. In the November 1956 the interim committee of the Communist party shut him out of the party but by September 1958 he was able to return home. From the late 1950s he held numerous academic posts and worked in various research institutes: 1958–61: Hungarian Academy of Sciences (HAS) Economic Institute 1961–63: Central Statistics Institute 1963–68: Founded and led the HAS Sociology Research Institute 1966: [[Karl Marx]] Economics University 1968–73: Industry Studies In 1968 he objected to the [[Warsaw Pact]] invasion of [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|Czechoslovakia]] during the [[Prague Spring]]. He was dismissed from his position at the Sociology Research Institute and later in 1973 was shut out of the Communist Party for his differing political and ideological views. He became a pensioner from 1975 to 1982 when he was allowed to teach at the Economics University. ==Post-communism== Following the collapse of Communism in 1990, Hegedüs founded the Worker's Academy. He was often interviewed about the events of 1956 by local and foreign news teams, as he was one of the few survivors from the government of that time. He died on the anniversary of the start of the Hungarian revolution. ==Selected publications== ===Books=== * ''Socialism and Bureaucracy'' (Motive series), London: Allison & Busby, 1976. * ''The Structure of Socialist Society'' (Sociology and Social Welfare series), London: Constable, 1977. * Hegedüs András. ''Élet egy eszme árnyékában'' ("Life in the shadow of an ideology"). Bethlen Gábor Publishing House. 1989. Budapest {{ISBN|963-02-7200-8}} (A slightly modified version of this book was published in 1985 in English.) ===Essays=== * with Maria Markus. [http://journal.telospress.com/ "Modernization and the Alternatives of Social Progress"]. [[TELOS (journal)|''TELOS'']] 17 (Fall 1973). New York: [http://www.telospress.com Telos Press] ==Further reading== {{Commons category|András Hegedüs}} {{portal|Cold War}} *{{cite book | last = Sebestyen | first = Victor | title = Twelve Days: The Story of the 1956 Hungarian Revolution | publisher = Pantheon | year = 2006 | location = New York | isbn = 0-375-42458-X | page = xix}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=[[Minister of Agriculture of Hungary|Minister of Agriculture]]|before=[[Ferenc Erdei]]|after=[[Ferenc Erdei]]|years=1953–1954}} {{succession box|title=[[Prime Minister of Hungary]]|before=[[Imre Nagy]]|after=[[Imre Nagy]]|years=1955–1956}} {{s-end}} {{HungarianPrimeMinisters}} {{HungarianAgricultureMinisters}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hegedus, Andras}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:People from Győr-Moson-Sopron County]] [[Category:Members of the Hungarian Working People's Party]] [[Category:Members of the Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party]] [[Category:Prime Ministers of Hungary]] [[Category:Agriculture ministers of Hungary]] [[Category:People of the Hungarian Revolution of 1956]] [[Category:Burials at Farkasréti Cemetery]]

{{Infobox person | name = Ben Thompson | image =Ben-Thompson.gif | imagesize = 210px | caption = Ben Thompson as a City Marshal of Austin Texas. | birth_name=Ben Thompson | birth_date = {{birth date|1843|11|2}} | birth_place = [[Knottingley]], [[West Yorkshire]], [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|England]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1884|3|11|1843|11|2}} | death_place = [[San Antonio, Texas]], U.S. | occupation = [[Gunfighter]], [[gambler]], and [[Law enforcement officer|lawman]] | years_active = 1868 – 1884 | known_for = Lawman and gunfighter of the old west | opponents = | spouse = Catherine L. Moore | signature= | children = 3 }} '''Ben Thompson''' (November 2, 1843 – March 11, 1884) was a [[gunfighter|gunman]], [[gambler]], and sometimes [[Law enforcement officer|lawman]] of the [[Old West]]. He was a contemporary of [[Buffalo Bill|"Buffalo" Bill Cody]], [[Bat Masterson]], [[John Wesley Hardin]], and [[James Butler Hickok|"Wild Bill" Hickock]], some of whom considered him a friend, others an enemy. Thompson fought for the [[Confederate States Army|Confederacy]] during the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], and later for [[Maximilian I of Mexico|Emperor Maximilian]] in Mexico. When hired in 1881 as [[Marshal#State and local marshals|marshal]] in [[Austin, Texas]], the crime rate reportedly dropped sharply. Thompson was murdered at the age of 40 in [[San Antonio, Texas]], in the "[[Vaudeville Theater Ambush]]."
==Early life== Thompson was born in [[Knottingley]], [[West Yorkshire]], [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|England]] to William and Mary Ann [nee Baker] Thompson, in November 1843.<ref>The 1851 Knottingley census records; Records notes that both Ben and Billy were enrolled in school.</ref> The family settled in Austin in late 1852. Ben was 8 years old, William 6, and Mary Jane 4 years old at the time.
Thompson worked for the ''Austin Rambler'' as a news printer's assistant while in his teens. Once he discovered gambling, however, Thompson began traveling and earning a living as a professional gambler.
==Military service== On June 12, 1861, Thompson enlisted in the Confederate States Army at San Antonio, and became a private in the 2nd Regiment,Texas Mounted Rifles, Company H.<ref>Note: The company was organized on April 17, 1861, and was known as Captain Hamner's Company. In April 1862, the company became the 2nd Texas Cavalry, Company F, under the command of Captain Tobin. Subsequently, the regiment became Company I, Morgan's Regiment, Texas Cavalry.</ref> His brother, [[Billy Thompson (gunman)|Billy Thompson]], joined the same regiment.
On January 1–2, 1863, Thompson participated in the [[Battle of Galveston]], where the [[USRC Harriet Lane (1857)|U.S.S. Harriet Lane]] was captured. Thompson was wounded during the battle, and was treated for six weeks in a military hospital at Niblett's Bluff (located west of [[Vinton, Louisiana]]).<ref>Note: Its corresponding address today is 3409 Nibletts Bluff Road.</ref>
Later that same year, Thompson took part in the [[Battle of LaFourche Crossing]] (June 20, 1863), near [[Thibodaux, Louisiana]]. The two Thompson brothers "found themselves at night separated from the living and standing among the dead."{{Citation needed|date=August 2014}} After this battle, Thompson returned home to Austin. He re-enlisted in Company F in September 1863, and served out the remainder of the war stationed along the banks of the [[Rio Grande]].
==Post war life==
===Mexico=== After the conclusion of the Civil War, Thompson fought in the armed forces of Emperor Maximilian against the Mexican revolutionaries.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}}
===Imprisonment=== In 1868 Thompson received word that his wife was being physically abused by her brother, Jim Moore. Soon after his return to Texas, he confronted Moore, and severely injured him. Charged with attempted murder, the 25-year-old Thompson was convicted and sentenced to two years in prison. He served time at [[Huntsville Unit|Huntsville Prison]], but eventually received a full pardon.{{Citation needed|date=August 2014}}
===Abilene, Wild Bill, and John Wesley Hardin=== {{main|Wild Bill Hickok|John Wesley Hardin}} In 1870, Thompson left Texas for [[Abilene, Kansas]], which had become a [[boomtown]] due to the expanding cattle trade. In 1871, Thompson opened the "[[Bulls Head Saloon]]" in Abilene, with friend and [[Business partner|partner]], [[Phil Coe]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Keys |first=Jim |title=Wild Bill Hickok |url=https://www.thehistoryherald.com/Articles/American-History/Civil-War-American-Indian-Wars-Pioneers-1801-1900/wild-bill-hickok/Page-2 |date=January 28, 2013 |access-date=December 27, 2017 |journal=The History Herald |page=2}}</ref> Their [[Western saloon|saloon]] prospered due to the many [[cattle drives]] that gave Abilene a steady stream of [[cowboy]]s' passing through who were anxious to drink and gamble.
It was at the Bulls Head Saloon that Thompson and Coe made the acquaintance of John Wesley Hardin, and actively recruited him in an attempt to rid the town of its marshal, "Wild" Bill Hickok. The two entrepreneurs had painted a picture of a bull with a large erect penis on the side of their establishment as a form of advertisement. Citizens of the town had complained to Hickok. When Thompson and Coe refused his request to remove the bull, Hickok had altered it himself. Infuriated, Thompson tried to incite Hardin by exclaiming to him: "He's a damn Yankee. Picks on [[Johnny Reb|rebels]], especially Texans, to kill." Hardin, then living under the assumed name of "Wesley Clemmons" (but better known to the townspeople by the alias, "Little Arkansas"), replied, "If Wild Bill needs killin', why don't you kill him yourself?"[sic]<ref name="Hardin Autobiography">{{cite book | first = John Wesley | last = Hardin | title = The Life of John Wesley Hardin: As Written By Himself | isbn = 978-0-8061-1051-6 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jLM-AAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=john+wesley+hardin#v=onepage&q&f=false | publisher = Smith & Moore |location=Seguin, Texas | year = 1896 | accessdate = 2014-08-27}}</ref> Later that night, Hardin was confronted by Hickok, who told him to hand over his guns, which he did. Hickok had no knowledge at the time of Hardin being a wanted man, and he advised "Clemmons" to avoid problems while remaining in Abilene.
Soon afterward, Thompson was injured in a fall from a horse. While he was recuperating, Coe was involved in a fatal ''[[shootout]]'' with Hickok. Thompson never confronted Hickok over the shooting of Coe, and both men left Abilene soon afterward.
===Altercation in Ellsworth === {{Main|Billy Thompson (gunman)}} Thompson moved to [[Ellsworth, Kansas]], which was also prospering as a cattle boomtown. On August 15, 1873, Thompson's younger brother, Billy, shot and killed Sheriff Chauncey Whitney. Whitney was standing near the two Thompson brothers, who were facing off against a local police officer, John "Happy Jack" Morco, and a gambler, John Sterling. The confrontation had developed over a gambling dispute. Whitney was a friend to both brothers, and numerous witnesses confirmed that Whitney stated before he died that the shooting was accidental.<ref>[http://www.imagesofyorkshire.co.uk/famous_people/ben_thompson/billy_thompson.htm "Billy Thompson"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517070115/http://www.imagesofyorkshire.co.uk/famous_people/ben_thompson/billy_thompson.htm |date=2008-05-17 }}, Images of Yorkshire online; accessed August 2015</ref>
[[Wyatt Earp]] claimed in an interview with his future biographer, [[Stuart N. Lake|Stuart Lake]], that he had arrested Thompson after the altercation although contemporary news accounts and Thompson's own biography describing the episode don't mention his presence at all.<ref name=earpnet>{{cite web | first=Steve |last=Gatto |url=http://www.wyattearp.net/ |title=Wyatt Earp History Page |publisher=WyattEarp.Net |accessdate=February 25, 2011}}</ref> But Lake's story ''[[Wyatt Earp: Frontier Marshal]]'', published two years after Earp's death, has been found by modern researchers to be a largely fictionalized biography,<ref name=goodman>{{cite book | title=Wyatt Earp |first=Michael |last=Goodman| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E4Bq2Uoi6MgC&pg | page=95 |date= July 30, 2005 |isbn=1583413391}}</ref> and the story he described of Earp's role in arresting Thompson was likely an "exaggerated account".<ref name=myers>{{cite web | last1=Myers| first1=Roger| title=Did Wyatt Earp Arrest Ben Thompson?| url=http://www.larned.net/rogmyers/ben_earp.htm| accessdate=27 August 2014| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208115547/http://www.larned.net/rogmyers/ben_earp.htm|archivedate=February 8, 2007| year=2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1=Roberts| first1=Gary| title=Did Wyatt Earp Arrest Ben Thompson In Ellsworth In 1873?| url=http://home.earthlink.net/~knuthco1/benthompson/garyroberts.htm| accessdate=27 August 2014}}</ref>
Morco filed charges of assault against Ben Thompson the following day, due to Thompson's having fired in his direction prior to Whitney being shot. Officer Ed Hogue arrested Ben Thompson. That same week, police officer Ed Crawford killed Thompson's friend, Cad Pierce, in an incident that Crawford reportedly provoked. Morco and Hogue soon ran another Thompson friend, Neil Cain, out of town. The town council dismissed Morco, Hogue, and Crawford, for inappropriate behavior. Soon after, newly appointed police officer, J.C. "Charlie" Brown, killed Morco when he pulled a gun during a disturbance. Friends of Cad Pierce soon killed Crawford. Ed Hogue left town. Billy Thompson fled [[Kansas]], too, but eventually was returned to be unsuccessfully tried for the death of Sheriff Whitney.
==Later life==
===Return to Texas=== In 1875, Ben Thompson returned to Texas, staying at [[Fort Elliott, Texas|Fort Elliott]], in the [[Texas Panhandle|Panhandle]]. There he met and befriended [[Bat Masterson]]. When Masterson shot and killed a [[US Cavalry|cavalry]] [[Corporal#United States|Corporal]] Melvin King in a dispute over a woman, Thompson stepped in to prevent other soldiers from attacking Masterson. After that incident, the [[Santa Fe Railroad]] hired both gunmen to intercede in a right-of-way dispute between that railroad and the [[Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad|Rio Grande Railroad]].
After the railway dispute ended, Thompson returned to Austin, where he opened the Iron Front Saloon. One of his competitors was the Capital Theater, owned and operated by Mark Wilson. On Christmas Eve 1876, Thompson and friends were at the Capital Theater drinking when a fight erupted involving other patrons. When Thompson tried to intervene, Wilson produced a shotgun and fired at Thompson but missed. Thompson then killed Wilson. A bartender, Charley Matthews, fired a Winchester rifle and grazed Thompson's hip. Thompson returned fire, hitting Matthews. Though seriously wounded, Matthews survived. Thompson was not arrested, as the shooting was ruled self defense.
In June 1880, Ben Thompson asked Masterson to go to [[Ogallala, Nebraska]] (then "the end of the Texas Trail"), to rescue his younger brother Billy, who was in trouble again as a result of being involved a shootout. Masterson, Ben, and Billy Thompson escaped from Ogallala, and headed to [[Dodge City, Kansas|Dodge City]].<ref>''Reminiscences of a Ranchman''; by [[Edgar Beecher Bronson]]</ref>
===In Austin, Texas=== In 1881, Thompson was hired by the city of Austin to serve as a city marshal. The following year, Thompson was involved in a dispute with Vaudeville Variety Theater owner, Jack Harris, in San Antonio. Thompson shot and killed Harris. Thompson was [[indicted]] for murder, and resigned his position as marshal. He was tried and acquitted, after which he returned to Austin. He was welcomed by the citizens, but he did not return to his law enforcement job.<ref>Note: One of the defense lawyers for Thompson was [[William M. Walton]], who later wrote a biography, ''The Life and Adventures of Ben Thompson''</ref>
== Murdered in San Antonio==
{{Main|Vaudeville Theater Ambush}} While on business in San Antonio, on March 11, 1884, Thompson ran into rancher, [[King Fisher]]. The two men, who had known one another for several years, decided to attend shows at the Turner Hall Opera House, and later at the Vaudeville Variety Theater. A local lawman, Jacob Coy, sat with them. Thompson wanted to see Joe Foster, a theater owner who had been a friend of Harris's. Thompson had already spoken to Billy Simms, another theater owner, and Foster's new partner.<ref name="Fisher">[http://ddfa.org/kingfisher.html ''John King Fisher – Gunfighter, Lawman''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060910085900/http://ddfa.org/kingfisher.html |date=September 10, 2006 }}; Texas;</ref>
Fisher and Thompson were directed upstairs to meet with Foster. Coy and Simms also joined them in the theater box. Foster refused to speak with Thompson. Fisher allegedly noticed that something was not right, when suddenly Simms and Coy stepped aside. As they did, a hail of bullets from an adjoining box hit Thompson and Fisher. Thompson fell, and either Coy or Foster ran up to him and shot him in the head with a pistol. Thompson died almost immediately. Fisher was shot thirteen times, but fired one round in retaliation, possibly wounding Coy, who was crippled for life.<ref name="Fisher"/><ref>Note: the fatal shot may have actually been friendly fire.</ref> While trying to draw his pistol, Foster had shot himself in the leg, which was later amputated. He died soon after the surgery.
==Burial== Thompson's body was returned to Austin. He is buried in [[Oakwood Cemetery (Austin, TX)|Oakwood Cemetery]] in Austin.
==Fate of Thompson's property== Thompson's will deeded all his property to his business partner. Among Thompson's gun collection was a custom made and engraved [[Stevens Arms#Target pistols|Stevens-Lord No. 36 target pistol]], given to him as a gift from Buffalo Bill.
On January 13, 2007, Ben Thompson's [[roulette]] table was sold at auction in Waco, Texas.<ref>"Western-themed items set for auction today"; C. Culp; January 17, 2007; ''Waco Tribune-Herald''; retrieved .</ref> It was reported that the table was used by Thompson in a gambling house he opened above the Iron Front Saloon, which had been located on Congress Avenue in Austin.<ref>"Rare auction items linked to San Antonio"; J. Zarazua; January 12, 2007; ''San Antonio Express-News''; retrieved .</ref>
==Television portrayal== Thompson's character is played by [[Denver Pyle]] in seven episodes of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[television series]], ''[[The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp]]'', with [[Hugh O'Brian]] in the title role. In one episode "The Time for All Good Men" (June 4, 1957), the actor [[Mike Ragan]] played [[Clay Allison]], who joins Thompson and [[John Wesley Hardin]] ([[Phillip Pine]]) in coming to Earp's aid in a shootout with the owner and foreman, respectively, of the Big T Ranch, Rance Purcell ([[Richard Devon]]) and Gus Andrews ([[Grant Withers]]). [[Walter Coy]] played Thompson in a single 1959 episode of the same series.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== * Adams, Paul. "The Unsolved Murder of Ben Thompson." ''Southwestern Historical Quarterly'' 48, January 1945. * DeMattos, Jack. "Gunfighters of the Real West: Ben Thompson." ''Real West'', October 1985. * Heath, Charles G. "The Thompsons of Knottingly." NOLA Quarterly, Vol. XIV, No. 1, Spring 1990. * Masterson, W.B. (Bat). "Famous Gun Fighters of the Western Frontier: Ben Thompson." ''Human Life Magazine'', Vol. 4, No. 4, January 1907. * Starr, Mary. ''History of Travis County and Austin, 1839-1899''. Texian Press, 1963. * Streeter, Floyd Benjamin. ''The Complete and Authentic Life of Ben Thompson: Man With a Gun'', New York: Frederick Fell, Inc., 1957. * Thorpe, John "Ben and Billy Thompson." ''English Westerners Brand Book'', Vol. XXIII, No. 1. Winter, 1984. * Walton, W.M. ''The Life and Adventures of Ben Thompson: The Famous Texan'', self-published by the author in 1884. A facsimile edition was published by The Steck Company of Austin, Texas in 1956.
==Fictional portrayals== *{{Cite book | last = Braun | first = Matt | title = Deathwalk | publisher = St. Martin's | date = September 2000 | isbn = 0-312-97516-3 | page = 336 }} * J. Silverman, "When the bad guys really wore the badges: SF Stages' new work by Kilmurry", ''Santa Fe New Mexican'', (New Mexico), July 4, 1997.
==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} {{Find a Grave|1028|accessdate=2009-03-24}} *[http://benthompsonfoundation.org/ Ben Thompson Foundation] *[http://www.odmp.org/officer/14118-sheriff-chauncey-belden-whitney "Sheriff Chauncey Belden Whitney"]
{{Authority control}}

'''Bentley Layton''' (born 12 August 1941), is Professor of Religious Studies (Ancient Christianity) and Professor of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations (Coptic) at [[Yale University]] (since 1983). He is a [[Harvard University|Harvard]]-educated scholar who has been central to the late 20th-century ''Rediscovery of [[Gnosticism]]'', which was the title of the international conference he hosted at Yale in 1980 and the volume that came of it. His interests lie in the [[History of Christianity]] from its origins until the rise of Islam, Gnostic studies and [[Coptic language|Coptic]].
With a ''summa cum laude'' thesis on the [[Nag Hammadi library|Nag Hammadi]] Gnostic Coptic [[Treatise on the Resurrection]], which he presented in a critical edition in 1978, he has moved on to present critical editions of other texts: ''[[The Hypostasis of the Archons]], Or, The Reality of the Rulers...'', serialized in ''[[Harvard Theological Review]]'' 67 (1974) 351—425 and 69 (1976) 1—71, and others. His most accessible book is ''The Gnostic Scriptures: A New Translation with Annotations'' (Garden City: Doubleday & Co., 1987), which presents some of the enigmatic literature of gnostic Christianity for nonspecialists. He sets his selection of gnostic scripture, the writings of [[Valentinius|Valentinus]] and his followers, and related writings that display gnostic tendencies within the broader context of [[Early Christianity]] and Hellenistic Judaism, with generous introductions and plentiful annotations.
For specialists, Layton's Coptic grammar is a standard text. He catalogued all the Coptic manuscripts in the [[British Library]]. He is a board member on the '' Harvard Theological Review'' and the ''Journal of Coptic Studies''.
==External links== *[http://www.yale.edu/religiousstudies/facultypages/cvbl.html Yale University:] Bentley Layton ''curriculum vitae''

{{redirect|Billy Hayes (writer)|the writer born in 1961|Bill Hayes (writer, born 1961)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Billy Hayes |birth_name = William Hayes |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1947|4|3}} |birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. |occupation = Writer, actor, film director |alma_mater = [[Marquette University]] (withdrew)<ref name="THEHARVARDCRIMSON1978">Contreras, Joe, [http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1978/11/4/busted-at-the-border-pbtbhe-submergence/ "Busted at the Border: I'm Billy Hayes...least I used to be."], ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]'', November 4, 1978</ref> |parents = William and Dorothy Hayes |spouse = Wendy West |residence = [[Los Angeles, California]] |home_town = [[North Babylon, New York]] <ref name="PEOPLE12091985">Shapiro, Harriet, [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20092409,00.html "Billy Hayes Stepped Off the Midnight Express and Embarked on a Trip of Self-Discovery"], ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine, December 09, 1985 Vol. 24 No. 24</ref> |criminal_charge = [[Drug smuggling]] }} '''William Hayes''' (born April 3, 1947) is an American writer, actor, and film director. He is best known for his autobiographical book ''[[Midnight Express (book)|Midnight Express]]'', about his experiences in and escape from a Turkish prison after being convicted of smuggling [[hashish]]. He was one of hundreds of U.S. citizens in foreign jails serving drug charge sentences following a drug smuggling crackdown by foreign governments.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,904284-1,00.html|title=Americans Abroad: The Jail Scene|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|date=April 13, 1970|accessdate=January 6, 2009}}</ref>
==Background== Hayes, an American student, was caught trying to smuggle four pounds of [[hashish]] out of [[Turkey]] on October 7, 1970. He was originally sentenced to four years and two months in a Turkish prison; with his release date weeks away, he learned that the authorities had chosen to penalize him with a [[life sentence]] for smuggling instead of possession.{{cn|date=October 2018}}
Hayes was imprisoned at [[Sultanahmet Jail|Sağmalcılar Prison]] in [[Istanbul]].<ref>[https://aad.archives.gov/aad/createpdf?rid=228251&dt=2474&dl=1345 INTERVIEW WITH WILLIAM HAYES/CODEL MURPHY / 030925Z MAY 74], U.S. State Department, Ankara, May 1974.</ref> Following an incident in prison, he was transferred in 1972 to [[Bakırköy Psychiatric Hospital]], described as a "lunatic asylum." The [[United States Department of State]] on several occasions pressured Turkey to transfer sentencing to the United States, however Turkish foreign minister [[Melih Esenbel]] stated that the United States was not in a position to dispute a sentence issued by a Turkish court.<ref name="hayescase">[https://aad.archives.gov/aad/createpdf?rid=249841&dt=2476&dl=1345 HAYES CASE / 190938Z MAR 75], U.S. State Department telegram, Ankara, March 1975.</ref> Esenbel stated privately to officials that a release might be possible on humanitarian grounds if Hayes' physical or mental health was deteriorating, but in a private consultation, Hayes stated to U.S. diplomats that his experience at Bakırköy Psychiatric Hospital in 1972 was highly traumatic and he did not have confidence that the hospital would certify him for early release;<ref name="hayescase" /> Hayes also stated that he felt attempts to win early release would jeopardize his prospects of being transferred to a more desirable half-open prison. On May 12, 1975, the [[Turkish Constitutional Court]] declared amnesty for all drug offenses, which shortened Hayes' sentence from life to 30 years. He was transferred to [[İmralı|İmralı Prison]] on July 11, 1975.
Declassified State Department telegrams indicated that in discussions between the U.S. embassy and Vahap Aşıroğlu, Turkish Director of Consular Affairs, Aşıroğlu believed Hayes would probably be released from prison on parole in October 1978, which in practice meant that a local prosecutor would declare him [[persona non grata]] and expel him from the country.<ref>[https://aad.archives.gov/aad/createpdf?rid=273843&dt=2476&dl=1345 BILATERAL AGREEMENT FOR REPATRIATION OF FOREIGN NATIONAL PRISONERS TO COMPLETE SENTENCING IN OWN COUNTRY / 091243Z MAY 75], U.S. State Department, Ankara, May 1975</ref>
He escaped from İmralı on October 2, 1975, via taking a [[rowboat]] at night to [[Bandirma]], blending in with locals and then heading westbound across the border to [[Greece]]. He was deported from [[Thessaloniki]] to [[Frankfurt]]{{why|date=February 2017}} on October 20, 1975 after several weeks' detention and interrogation about what [[military intelligence]] Hayes possessed about Turkey.
==Book== Hayes wrote a book on his experiences, ''[[Midnight Express (book)|Midnight Express]]'', which was later adapted into the 1978 [[Midnight Express (film)|film of the same name]] starring [[Brad Davis (actor)|Brad Davis]]. The film was directed by [[Alan Parker]], with a screenplay by [[Oliver Stone]]. The movie differs from Hayes' account in his book. Among the differences is a scene in which Hayes kills the prison guard Hamidou "the Bear" (portrayed by [[Paul L. Smith]]), the main antagonist of the story. In fact, the prison guard was killed in 1973 by a recently released prisoner, whose family Hamidou insulted while beating the prisoner, years before Hayes' actual escape.
For legal reasons,{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} the book and film adaptation were deliberately inaccurate. In one interview, Hayes admitted making several trips to Turkey to bring hash back to the United States. His lawyer informed him that he could be arrested again for such claims. {{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
In 2010, in an episode of [[National Geographic Channel]]'s ''[[Banged Up Abroad|Locked Up Abroad]]'', titled "The Real Midnight Express",<ref>[http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/channel/videos/the-real-midnight-express/ [[Banged Up Abroad|Locked Up Abroad]]: The Real Midnight Express] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103095240/http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/channel/videos/the-real-midnight-express/ |date=November 3, 2012 }}</ref> Hayes tells his version of the full story about being sent to the infamous Turkish Sağmalcilar prison, eventually escaping from the [[Marmara Sea]] prison on [[İmralı]] island. Hayes has now written the sequel books, ''Midnight Return (Escaping Midnight Express)'' and ''The Midnight Express Letters--from a Turkish Prison, 1970-1975'', a collection of the original letters written home to family and friends during his imprisonment.
==Acting and writing== Hayes is still {{When|date=April 2018}} active in the entertainment industry, specifically acting and writing. One of his successes was writing and directing 2003's ''Southside'' (later released as ''Cock and Bull Story'' in the US), which won numerous awards, including the 2002 L.A. Drama Critics' Circle award.<ref>{{cite web|title=Riding The Midnight Express With Billy Hayes|url=https://www.plays411.com/newsite/castcrew/play_castcrew.asp?show_id=2708|publisher=plays411.com|accessdate=6 July 2017}}</ref> On June 30, 2010, the National Geographic television channel aired ''[[Banged Up Abroad|Locked Up Abroad: The Real Midnight Express]]''. Billy Hayes has been traveling the world with his one-man show, ''Riding the Midnight Express with Billy Hayes,'' since it premiered at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe|Edinburgh Fringe Festival]] in August 2013.
==Interview on ''Midnight Express'' film== During the 1999 [[Cannes Film Festival]], [[Alinur Velidedeoğlu]], a Turkish advertiser, met Billy Hayes by chance and [[Midnight Express (film)#Billy Hayes interviewed|interviewed]] him on the film ''Midnight Express''. Hayes expressed his disappointment with parts of the film adaptation, especially its portrayal of all Turks as bad, and his regret that Turkey's image was negatively affected by the film. Hayes also displayed affection for Turkey and [[Istanbul]]. Although the [[Interpol]] warrant for him had by then been set aside, he explained that while he wanted to return, he hesitated to do so out of concern that many Turks might blame him for the negative publicity the movie had generated.
The video was made available on [[YouTube]].<ref>{{YouTube|WMsNPCVbNhw|Interview}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|_JTRs8e-FRk|Interview Part 2}}</ref> Hayes did finally return to Turkey on June 14, 2007, to attend the 2nd Istanbul Conference on Democracy and Global Security, organized by the [[Turkish National Police]] (TNP) and the [[Turkish Institute for Police Studies]] (TIPS), to amend the negative implications of his book. He held a press conference on June 15 and made an apology to the Turkish people.<ref name="TORONTOSTAR2007">Handelman, Stephen, [https://www.thestar.com/news/2007/06/24/revisiting_the_land_of_midnight_express.html "Revisiting the land of 'Midnight Express'"], ''[[Toronto Star]]'', June 24, 2007</ref>
==References== {{Portal|United States|Turkey|Biography|Criminal justice}} {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{IMDb name|370907|Billy Hayes}} * [http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=c55e4_4807 "Billy Hayes of 'Midnight Express' Interviewed"], ''liveleak.com'' * [http://www.ridingthemidnightexpresswithbillyhayes.com/ "Riding the Midnight Express with Billy Hayes" website]

{{Infobox scientist |name = Charles Hailey |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = |birth_place = |residence = |nationality = |death_date = |death_place = |field = [[Experimental physics]]
[[Astrophysics]] |work_institution = [[Columbia University]] |alma_mater = [[Cornell University]]
Columbia University |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[NuSTAR]]
[[General Antiparticle Spectrometer]] |prizes = Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Outstanding Achievement Award (three-time recipient) |footnotes = }} '''Charles James "Chuck" Hailey''' is an experimental astrophysicist and Pupin Professor of Physics at [[Columbia University]]. He earned his BA in Physics from [[Cornell University]] in 1977 and his PhD from Columbia in 1983, with a thesis entitled "The Development of an Imaging Gas Scintillation Proportional Counter for Use in X-ray Astronomy." He received tenure from Columbia University in 1995.{{cite web|url = http://physics.columbia.edu/people/profile/408|title = Charles Hailey Faculty Profile|work=Columbia University Department of Physics}} Hailey's research focuses on [[High energy astronomy|high energy astrophysics]] and experimental [[particle physics]]. He is Co-Director of the Columbia Astrophysics Laboratory, where he works on [[gamma-ray]] and X-ray research. Hailey led the team that built the NASA [[Nuclear Spectroscopic Telescope Array]] (NuSTAR) telescope.{{cite web|url = http://scienceline.org/2013/02/capturing-the-invisible/|title="Capturing the invisible"|work = "Scienceline"}} One of NuSTAR's main advantages, the use of [[slumping|slumping glass]] instead of polishing to achieve high resolution, was developed by Hailey himself.{{cite news|last1=Craig|first1=David|title=X-Ray Specs|url=http://magazine.columbia.edu/features/spring-2010/x-ray-specs?page=0,0|accessdate=26 January 2015|work=Columbia Magazine|date=Spring 2010}} He continues to be very involved in the project, investigating emissions from the [[supermassive black hole]] at the center of the Milky Way as well as the sources of other X-ray and gamma emissions. Hailey is the chair of the NuSTAR Galactic Plane Survey working group.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2012-333|title=NASA's NuSTAR Spots Flare from Milky Way's Black Hole|date=October 23, 2012|work=NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory}} Hailey is also Principal Investigator and leader of the [[General Antiparticle Spectrometer]] (GAPS) experiments, for which he works on developing new [[X-ray fluorescence#Si(Li) detectors|Si(Li) detectors]] for X-ray detection.{{cite web|url=http://gamma0.astro.ucla.edu/gaps/|title = General Antiparticle Spectrometer|work=UCLA Department of Astronomy}} One of the aims of the project is to attempt to detect [[dark matter]] and elucidate its composition by sending a balloon-suspended apparatus to search for anti-deuterons in the cosmic rays. The project had a successful prototype run in 2012 in Japan and is scheduled for a full run from Antarctica in 2019. Hailey previously served as V/L-Division program leader for Space Science and Technology at the [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]], where he worked from 1986 to 1995. In addition, he held the post of associate program leader for Intelligence and National Security Technology in the Nonproliferation, Arms Control and International Security Directorate until joining the faculty at Columbia. At Livermore, Hailey received the prestigious Outstanding Achievement Award three times.{{cite web|url=http://www.columbia.edu/cu/record/archives/vol21/vol21_iss6/record2106.13.html|title=Sciences Names Scholars to 14 Tenured Faculty Positions|work=Columbia University Archives}} Before that, he was employed as a research scientist in a now-defunct private firm building X-ray detectors. He has made a variety of contributions to physics outside GAPS and NuSTAR. He has built or helped to build telescopes such as the three-meter telescope at the [[Lick Observatory]] and the [[High-Energy Focusing Telescope]].{{cite news|last1=Thieme|first1=Trevor|title=High-Flying Telescope|work=Popular Science|date=February 2001|page=26}} He was a member of the [[UK Dark Matter Collaboration]] and collaborated with two other Columbia faculty members to build the liquid scintillator veto shield for the [[ZEPLIN-III]] dark matter detector.{{cite news|last1=Thieme|first1=Trevor|title=A Flash in the Dark|work=Popular Science|date=April 2001|page=73}} As part of a collaboration between researchers at Harvard and Columbia, Hailey worked on the EXIST All-Sky Sky Gamma-ray Survey mission study in 2000 at NASA's [[Goddard Space Flight Center]].{{cite web|url=https://aas.org/archives/BAAS/v33n1/054331basr.pdf|work = American Academy of Sciences|title=American Academy of Sciences Annual Report (Columbia University)}} Hailey holds several patents for his work on NuSTAR and GAPS, among other projects, and has authored over 200 publications. He teaches an undergraduate quantum mechanics course at Columbia. == Selected bibliography == * T. Aramaki et al., "Potential for Precision Measurement of Low-Energy Antiprotons with GAPS for Dark Matter and Primordial Black Hole Physics," ''Astroparticle Physics'' 59, 12, 2014. *P. von Doetinchem et al., "The Flight of the GAPS Prototype Experiment," ''Astroparticle Physics'', 54, 93, 2014. *B.W.Grefenstette et al., "Asymmetries in Core-Collapse Supernovae from Maps of Radioactive 44Ti in Cassiopeia A," ''Nature'', 506, 7488, 339, 2014. *M. Nynka et al., "NuSTAR Study of Hard X-ray Morphology and Spectroscopy of PWN G21.5-0.9," ''Astrophysical Journal'', 789, 72, 2014. *S. Zhang et al., "High-Energy X-ray Detection of G359.89-0.08 (Sgr A-E): Magnetic Flux Tube Emission Powered by Cosmic-rays?" ''Astrophysical Journal'', 784, 6, 2014 *C.J. Hailey, "An Indirect Search for Dark Matter Using Antideuterons: the GAPS Experiment," ''New Journal of Physics'', vol. 11, 105022, 2009. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hailey, Charles}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American astrophysicists]] [[Category:Columbia University faculty]] [[Category:Cornell University alumni]] [[Category:Particle physicists]] [[Category:Experimental physicists]] [[Category:NASA people]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Chrissie Glazebrook | image = | imagesize = | image_caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1945|3|19|df=y}}<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook">{{cite news |last1=O'Brien |first1=Sean |title=Chrissie Glazebrook |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2007/dec/11/guardianobituaries.booksobituaries |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=11 December 2007}}</ref><ref name="indep obit">{{cite news |last1=Fitzgerald |first1=Kitty |title=Chrissie Glazebrook: Writer with a slapstick, acid wit |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/chrissie-glazebrook-writer-with-a-slapstick-acid-wit-765060.html |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=Independent |date=14 December 2007}}</ref> | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|2007|12|7|1945|3|19|df=y}}<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/> | death_place = [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]], England, United Kingdom<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/> | occupation = Arts administrator, writer, secretary, journalist, broadcaster<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/> | nationality = British | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | awards = {{awd |[[The Waterstones Prize for Prose]]<ref name="Keenan2002">{{cite book|author=Joe Keenan|title=Blue Heaven|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qYuTxHUxjRoC&pg=PP2|year=2002|publisher=Arrow|isbn=978-0-09-943504-4|pages=2–}}</ref> |1998 }} {{awd |[[Time to Write Award]]<ref name="Leckey2015">{{cite book|author=Susan Leckey|title=The Europa Directory of Literary Awards and Prizes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WzFACwAAQBAJ&pg=PT310|date=22 December 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-35631-6|pages=310–}}</ref> |2002}} | influences = | influenced = | website = [http://shufflingoff.blogspot.com Shuffling Off] }}
'''Chrissie Glazebrook''', adopted as Christine Ann Wright (19 March 1945 – 7 December 2007) was a British writer, known for her novel ''The Madolescents'' (2001).
==Early life and marriage== Glazebrook was adopted at 8 weeks by Mary and Ernest Wright and brought up in the [[Black Country]].<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family">{{cite web |title=Chrissie Glazebrook |url=http://www.family-announcements.co.uk/localworld/view/3202698/chrissie-glazebrook |website=Family Announcements |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref> She was educated at [[Cannock Grammar School]] and then did a secretarial course.<ref name="indep obit"/> She married in the late 1960s and moved to Scarborough.<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/> She was divorced a few years later.<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/>
==Career== Before her writing career, Glazebrook had a number of jobs, including in a zoo and managing a vegetarian restaurant.<ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="Keenan2002"/> She also worked at the [[Stephen Joseph Theatre]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Administration |url=http://www.theatre-in-the-round.co.uk/page6/page65/page22.html |website=Scarborough In The Round |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref>
From 1982 to 1990 she worked as a freelance writer and broadcaster.<ref name="indep obit"/> She wrote for [[Jackie (magazine)]].<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/> She produced ''Flavour of the Month'', a cookery programme, for [[ITV Central|Tyne Tees Television]], and also worked as a television presenter for Tyne Tees.<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/>
In 1991 Glazebrook became an Arts Administrator at [[Arts Council of Great Britain|Northern Arts]].<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/> She was one of the founders of [[ProudWORDS]], a gay and lesbian literature festival.<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/>
In 1998 Glazebrook completed an MA in Creative Writing at [[Northumbria University]].<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="family"/><ref>{{cite web |title=Creative Writing Student Successes |url=https://www.northumbria.ac.uk/about-us/academic-departments/humanities/research/english-research/creative-writing/postgraduate-research-in-creative-writing/creative-writing-student-successes |website=Northumbria University |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref>
Her first novel, ''The Madolescents'', was published in 2001.<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/> Ray French said of the teenage narrator that "Rowena's cynical, fragile, vulgar voice is a delight".<ref>{{cite news |last1=French |first1=Ray |title=Ray French's top 10 black comedies |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2007/nov/13/top10s.black.comedies |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=13 November 2007}}</ref>
Glazebrook was part of a network of Northern writers, particularly women, including [[Julia Darling]].<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/>
==Illness and death== Glazebrook suffered from depression.<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/>
In 2006 she was diagnosed with [[liver cancer|liver]] and [[bowel cancer]].<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/> She died the following year in Scarborough, supported by her family.<ref name="Guardian Glazebrook"/><ref name="indep obit"/><ref name="family"/>
==Selected works== Glazebrook's publications include:<ref>{{cite web |title=Chrissie Glazebrook |url=http://northernwritersawards.com/winners/profile/chrissie-glazebrook |website=Northern Writers' Awards |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref>
* ''The Pocket Guide to Men'' (1986) * "The Full Monty", in ''Biting Back : new fiction from the North'', (ed) Kitty Fitzgerald (IRON, 2001) * ''The Madolescents'' (Heinemann/Arrow, 2002) * ''Blue Spark Sisters'' (Heinemann/Arrow, 2003)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://shufflingoff.blogspot.com Shuffling Off – author's blog] * [https://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/arts/openbook/openbook_20070614.shtml The Madolescents discussed on Radio 4's Open Book] {{authority control}}

{{distinguish|text=an attorney who works on contracts; see [[Commercial law]]}} {{refimprove|date=December 2007}} A '''contract attorney''' is a [[lawyer]] who works on legal cases on a [[contract]] basis. Such work is generally of a temporary nature, often with no guaranteed employment term.
A contract attorney is {{quote|An attorney temporarily hired by the law office for a specific job or period. When the job or period is finished, the relationship is over.|Brent D. Roper<ref>Brent D. Roper, ''Practical Law Office Management'', 3rd ed., pp. 5 (2007 Thomson Learning).</ref>}}
==Civil litigation== The work of contract attorneys often varies. They can be engaged activities such as [[document review]] in response to a document [[subpoena]]s or [[request for production]] of documents. In such projects, contract attorneys may review tens of thousands, if not millions, of pages of documents and mark them as responsive to a particular request, or protected as attorney [[Work-product doctrine|work product]] or under the [[attorney–client privilege]]. Large firms have learned that contract attorneys can perform this work much more cost effectively than high-priced associates.
Many contract, or freelance, attorneys perform [[legal research]], draft [[Brief (law)|legal briefs]], and provide a full range of other services to law firms of all sizes. These attorneys typically work for themselves, rather than for temporary agencies, and provide their services to other law firms on an as-needed basis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trialhelper.com/Site/Welcome.html |title= Full Service Freelance Litigation Support Information}}</ref>
Some people who hold [[juris doctor]] degrees, but who are awaiting [[Admission to the bar|bar admission]], work as temporary professionals in law firms doing the same type of work as contract attorneys. In other situations, a law firm may, due to a conflict of interest, be required to hire a contract attorney as ''[[Cumis counsel]]'' in certain cases.
Contract attorneys typically work on a project-by-project basis and are not full-time law firm employees. However, they also develop long-lasting relationships with firms that regularly or semi-regularly send work to the contract attorney. Many small firms find that the use of contract attorneys provides them the flexibility to grow their business without hiring salaried employees. <ref>{{cite web|last1=Velazquez|first1=Ashley|url=https://hireanesquire.com/magazine/small-firms-benefit-contract-attorneys/|website=Hire an Esquire|accessdate=7 March 2017 |title= Small Firms: The Benefit of Contract Attorneys}}</ref>
According to the [[American Bar Association]], law firms can add a surcharge to the fees of their contract attorneys so long as the final fee charged to the client is reasonable.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trialhelper.com/Site/ABA_Op._00-420.html |title= Summary of American Bar Association Formal Opinion 00-420: Surcharge to Client for Use of a Contract Lawyer}}</ref> Particularly in a slowing economy, the use of contract attorneys gives firms a competitive edge in the marketplace, helping them to control costs while increasing profitability.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trialhelper.com/Site/Freelance_Legal_Services_Preserve_Profit_Margins.html |title= The Myth of Associate Profitability: Why Freelance Legal Services Preserve Profit Margins in an Uncertain Economic Climate}}</ref>
==Criticisms== {{undue|section|date=December 2012}} In writing about the disparity between CEO and worker pay, ''New York Times'' best-selling author and social critic [[Barbara Ehrenreich]] said: {{quote|Similarly, the legal profession, which is topped by law firm partners billing hundreds of dollars an hour, now has a new proletariat of temp lawyers working for $19-25 an hour in sweatshop conditions. On sites like <nowiki>http://temporaryattorney.blogspot.com/</nowiki>, temp lawyers report working 12 hours a day, six days a week, in crowded basements with inadequate sanitary facilities. According to an article in ''American Lawyer'', a legal temp at a major New York firm reports being 'corralled in a windowless basement room littered with dead cockroaches,' where six out of seven exits were blocked.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/barbara-ehrenreich/going-to-extremes-ceos-v_b_49791.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Barbara | last=Ehrenreich | title=Going to Extremes: CEOs vs. Slaves | date=28 March 2008}}</ref>}}
==Assigned counsel work in criminal defense== In counties without a [[public defender]], or without an [[Conflict of interest|alternate defender]], a contract attorney may be hired to do [[Of counsel|assigned counsel]] work. A [[legal aid]] group may be hired to do such work as if a [[Temporary work|temporary work agency]], such as the [[Legal Aid Society]] of [[New York City]]. Other states or counties may have a panel of lawyers who act as contract attorneys. Some critics of this system have accused the method of leading to [[ineffective assistance of counsel]] in [[Criminal law|criminal cases]].
==Contract legal assistant== {{main|Paralegal}}
A law firm may, under certain circumstances, hire a [[freelance]] [[paralegal]], commonly known as a contract legal assistant, to perform many of the tasks that a contract attorney might perform.<ref>Brent D. Roper, ''Practical Law Office Management'', 3rd ed., pp. 8-9, 147 (2007 Thomson Learning).</ref>
==See also== * [[Attorney of record]] * [[Of counsel]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} [[File:Dhanush 62nd Britannia Filmfare South Awards (cropped).jpg|thumb|Dhanush at the [[62nd Filmfare Awards South]] in 2015|alt=A man holding a mic.]] [[Dhanush]] is an Indian film actor, producer, lyricist and singer known for his work in [[Tamil cinema]]. He made his acting debut in 2002 with the [[Coming-of-age story|coming of age]] drama, ''[[Thulluvadho Ilamai]]'', directed by his father [[Kasthuri Raja]].{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/society/in-love-with-village-vistas/article7872936.ece | title=In love with village vistas | work=[[The Hindu]] | date=13 November 2015 | accessdate=20 January 2017 | last=Saravanan | first=T. | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211110722/http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/society/in-love-with-village-vistas/article7872936.ece | archivedate=11 February 2017 | deadurl=no}} His role as a mentally-disturbed man in ''[[Kaadhal Kondein]]'' (2003){{mdash}}directed by his brother [[Selvaraghavan]]{{mdash}}won him critical acclaim. The following year, he starred in [[Subramaniam Siva]]'s ''[[Thiruda Thirudi]]'', a commercial success.{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1120429/jsp/graphiti/story_15429395.jsp#.WPCz2GmGNdg | title=The Kolaveri Kid | work=[[The Telegraph (Calcutta)]] | date=29 April 2012 | accessdate=14 April 2017 | last=Basu | first=Arundhati | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415013037/https://www.telegraphindia.com/1120429/jsp/graphiti/story_15429395.jsp | archivedate=15 April 2017 | deadurl=no}} This was followed by a series of commercial failures{{mdash}}''[[Pudhukottaiyilirundhu Saravanan]]'' (2004), ''[[Sullan]]'' (2004) and ''[[Dreams (2004 film)|Dreams]]'' (2004).{{cite web | url=http://movies.ndtv.com/photos/happy-birthday-dhanush-a-raanjhanaa-33-22476#photo-282426 | title=Happy Birthday Dhanush, a Raanjhanaa@33 | publisher=[[NDTV]] | date=28 July 2016 | accessdate=15 April 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415100532/http://movies.ndtv.com/photos/happy-birthday-dhanush-a-raanjhanaa-33-22476 | archivedate=15 April 2017 | deadurl=no}} He had two releases in 2005{{mdash}}''[[Devathayai Kanden]]'' and ''[[Adhu Oru Kana Kaalam]]''. In 2006, Dhanush starred in the [[gangster film]] ''[[Pudhupettai]]'', which was critically acclaimed and moderately successful at the box-office. He next collaborated with debutant director [[Vetrimaaran]] in ''[[Polladhavan (2007 film)|Polladhavan]]'' (2007). Based on the [[Italian neorealism|Italian neorealist]] film ''[[Bicycle Thieves]]'',{{cite web | url=http://www.sify.com/movies/polladhavan-review-tamil-pclwzeadadigf.html | title=Polladhavan | publisher=[[Sify]] | date=10 November 2007 | accessdate=20 January 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211110704/http://www.sify.com/movies/polladhavan-review-tamil-pclwzeadadigf.html | archivedate=11 February 2017 | deadurl=no}} it was critically acclaimed and commercially successful.{{cite news | url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/regional-movies/after-visaaranai-vetrimaaran-to-adapt-another-book-into-a-film/story-zI0quMinfx3uOKyONUc0mO.html | title=After Visaaranai, Vetrimaaran to adapt another book into a film | work=[[Hindustan Times]] | date=17 March 2016 | accessdate=14 April 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414114321/http://www.hindustantimes.com/regional-movies/after-visaaranai-vetrimaaran-to-adapt-another-book-into-a-film/story-zI0quMinfx3uOKyONUc0mO.html | archivedate=14 April 2017 | deadurl=no}}{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/Kutty-set-for-a-big-ride/article16837423.ece | title=Kutty set for a big ride? | work=The Hindu | date=13 January 2010 | accessdate=14 April 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170417170042/http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/Kutty-set-for-a-big-ride/article16837423.ece | archivedate=17 April 2017 | deadurl=no}} His subsequent releases{{mdash}}''[[Yaaradi Nee Mohini]]'' (2008) and ''[[Padikkadavan (2009 film)|Padikkadavan]]''{{mdash}}were box-office successes. He collaborated with Vetrimaaran for the second time in ''[[Aadukalam]]'' (2011). His role as a [[Cockfight|rooster fight]] jockey in the film won him [[58th National Film Awards|that year's National Film Award]] for [[National Film Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] and the [[Filmfare Award for Best Actor – Tamil|Best Tamil Actor Award]] at the [[60th Filmfare Awards South]].{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/south-interview-with-vetrimaran/20110531.htm | title=Aadukalam sees Dhanush in his best performance | publisher=[[Rediff.com]] | date=31 May 2011 | accessdate=20 January 2017 | last=Nadar | first=Ganesh | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170103010040/http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/south-interview-with-vetrimaran/20110531.htm | archivedate=3 January 2017 | deadurl=no}} In 2012, he received international attention with the song "[[Why This Kolaveri Di]]", which was recorded for [[Aishwarya R. Dhanush]]'s directorial debut ''[[3 (2012 Tamil film)|3]]''.{{cite news | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-record-breaker-kolaveri-di-becomes-1st-indian-video-to-cross-100-million-views-on-youtube-2151294 | title=Record-breaker: Kolaveri Di becomes 1st Indian video to cross 100 million views on YouTube | work=[[Daily News and Analysis]] | accessdate=20 January 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211110828/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-record-breaker-kolaveri-di-becomes-1st-indian-video-to-cross-100-million-views-on-youtube-2151294 | archivedate=11 February 2017 | deadurl=no}} His role as a man who is suffering from [[bipolar disorder]] in the film won him his second Filmfare Award.{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/Ram-is-very-close-to-my-heart-Dhanush/articleshow/25169878.cms |title=Ram is very close to my heart: Dhanush |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=4 November 2013 |accessdate=20 January 2017 |last=Karthik |first=Janani |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170606091910/http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/getFiles.asp?Style=OliveXLib:LowLevelEntityToPrintGifMSIE_PASTISSUES2&Type=text/html&Locale=english-skin-custom&Path=TOICH/2013/11/04&ChunkNum=0&ID=Ar02502 |archivedate=6 June 2017 |dead-url=no |df= }} Dhanush made his [[Bollywood]] debut with [[Anand L Rai]]'s ''[[Raanjhanaa]]'' (2013). His performance as an obsessive one-sided lover in the film won him the [[Filmfare Award for Best Male Debut|Best Male Debut Award]] and earned a [[Filmfare Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] nomination at the [[59th Filmfare Awards]].{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/lead/crazy-love-in-banaras/article4935904.ece | title=Crazy love in Banaras | work=The Hindu | date=21 July 2013 | accessdate=20 January 2017 | last=Bhaskar | first=Swara | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211110758/http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/lead/crazy-love-in-banaras/article4935904.ece | archivedate=11 February 2017 | deadurl=no}} The same year he was seen in the [[survival film]] ''[[Maryan (film)|Maryan]]'', which won him [[Filmfare Special Award – South|Best Actor Award (Critics)]] at the [[61st Filmfare Awards South]]. In 2014, he produced and starred in cinematographer [[Velraj]]'s directorial debut, ''[[Velaiilla Pattadhari]]'',{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/society/cinema-cinema/article6267935.ece | title=Cinema cinema! | work=[[The Hindu]] | date=31 July 2014 | accessdate=14 April 2017 | last=Saravanan | first=T. | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008052832/http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/society/cinema-cinema/article6267935.ece | archivedate=8 October 2014 | deadurl=no}} which was critically acclaimed as well as a box-office success.{{cite news | url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/140803/entertainment-kollywood/article/dhanush-climbing-%E2%80%98mass%E2%80%99-ladder | title=Dhanush climbing up the 'mass' ladder | work=[[Deccan Chronicle]] | date=3 August 2014 | accessdate=14 April 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414111956/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/140803/entertainment-kollywood/article/dhanush-climbing-%E2%80%98mass%E2%80%99-ladder | archivedate=14 April 2017 | deadurl=no}} His performance as an unemployed graduate won a third Filmfare Award in the Best Tamil Actor category.{{cite news | url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/vella-illa-pattathari-dhanush-s-royal-return-to-commercial-zone-ians-tamil-movie-review-114071800790_1.html | title='Vella Illa Pattathari': Dhanush's royal return to commercial zone | work=[[Business Standard]] | date=18 July 2014 | accessdate=14 April 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414170610/http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/vella-illa-pattathari-dhanush-s-royal-return-to-commercial-zone-ians-tamil-movie-review-114071800790_1.html | archivedate=14 April 2017 | deadurl=no}} He co-starred with [[Amitabh Bachchan]] in [[R. Balki]]'s ''[[Shamitabh]]'' (2015), where he played a mute [[superstar]].{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1150207/jsp/t2/story_1877.jsp#.WIJA-VV95dg | title=Shamitabh gives more face to the voice and less voice to the face | work=The Telegraph | date=7 February 2015 | accessdate=20 January 2017 | last=D. Gupta | first=Pratim | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170120165719/https://www.telegraphindia.com/1150207/jsp/t2/story_1877.jsp | archivedate=20 January 2017 | deadurl=no}} Dhanush played triple role in [[K. V. Anand]]'s [[romantic thriller]] ''[[Anegan]]'', a moderate success. He followed that with ''[[Maari (film)|Maari]]'' (2015) and ''[[Thanga Magan (2015 film)|Thanga Magan]]'' (2015), both moderately successful at the box office.{{cite news | url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/151230/entertainment-kollywood/article/year-twists-and-turns-kollywood | title=A year of twists and turns for Kollywood | work=[[Deccan Chronicle]] | date=15 April 2017 | accessdate=15 April 2017 | last=Subramanian | first=Anupama | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415095006/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/151230/entertainment-kollywood/article/year-twists-and-turns-kollywood | archivedate=15 April 2017 | deadurl=no}} Dhanush had two releases in 2016{{mdash}}[[Prabhu Solomon]]'s ''[[Thodari]]'', a critical and commercial failure;{{cite news | url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/regional/kollywood-box-office-thodari-fails-to-beat-vikrams-iru-mugan-aandavan-kattalai-grows-on-second-day/ | title=Kollywood box office: Thodari fails to beat Vikram's Iru Mugan, Aandavan Kattalai grows on second day | work=[[The Indian Express]] | date=24 September 2016 | accessdate=13 April 2017 | last=Manoj Kumar | first=R | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414082457/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/regional/kollywood-box-office-thodari-fails-to-beat-vikrams-iru-mugan-aandavan-kattalai-grows-on-second-day/ | archivedate=14 April 2017 | deadurl=no}} and the [[political thriller]] ''[[Kodi (film)|Kodi]]'', where he played dual roles. The latter earned him a Best Tamil Actor nomination at the [[64th Filmfare Awards South]].{{cite web | url=https://www.filmfare.com/awards/filmfare-awards-south-2017/tamil/nominations/best-actor-male/dhanush | title=Best Actor in a Leading Role (Male) Nominee: Dhanush | work=[[Filmfare]] | accessdate=14 August 2017 | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170814133606/https://www.filmfare.com/awards/filmfare-awards-south-2017/tamil/nominations/best-actor-male/dhanush | archivedate=14 August 2017 | deadurl=yes | df=dmy-all }} The following year, he made his directorial debut with ''[[Pa Paandi]]''. == Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+Key | style="background:#ffc;"| {{dagger|alt=Films that have not yet been released}} | Denotes films that have not yet been released |} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" id="filmography" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! {{pp-vandalism|expiry=23:55, 23 April 2019|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Edward Snowden | image = Edward Snowden-2.jpg{{!}}border | alt = | caption = Snowden in 2013 | birth_name = Edward Joseph Snowden | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|6|21|mf=yes}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Elizabeth City, North Carolina]], U.S.}} | residence = [[Moscow]], Russia ([[Right of asylum|asylum]]) | nationality = American | occupation = Computer security consultant | employer = [[Booz Allen Hamilton]]
[[Kunia Camp, Hawaii]], U.S.
(until June 10, 2013) | known_for = Revealing details of classified United States government surveillance programs | term = | successor = | awards = | website = {{ConditionalURL}} | signature = Edward Snowden signature 2013.svg }} {{Global surveillance}} {{NSA surveillance}} '''Edward Joseph Snowden''' (born June 21, 1983) is an American [[computer professional]], former [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA) employee, and former contractor for the [[Federal government of the United States|United States government]] who copied and [[news leak|leaked]] [[classified information]] from the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) in 2013. [[Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)|His disclosures]] revealed numerous [[global surveillance]] programs, many run by the NSA and the [[Five Eyes|Five Eyes Intelligence Alliance]] with the cooperation of [[Telephone company|telecommunication companies]] and European governments. In 2013, Snowden was hired by an NSA contractor, [[Booz Allen Hamilton]], after previous employment with [[Dell]] and the CIA.{{cite news |first1=Bryan |last1=Burrough |first2=Sarah |last2=Ellison |first3=Suzanna |last3=Andrews |title=The Snowden Saga: A Shadowland of Secrets and Light |date=April 23, 2014 |accessdate=April 29, 2016 |website=Vanity Fair |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/politics/2014/05/edward-snowden-politics-interview}} On May 20, 2013, Snowden flew to [[Hong Kong]] after leaving his job at an [[Hawaii Cryptologic Center|NSA facility in Hawaii]], and in early June he revealed thousands of classified NSA documents to journalists [[Glenn Greenwald]], [[Laura Poitras]], and [[Ewen MacAskill]]. Snowden came to international attention after stories based on the material appeared in ''[[The Guardian]]'' and ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Further disclosures were made by other publications including ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' and ''[[The New York Times]]''. On June 21, 2013, the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]] unsealed charges against Snowden of two counts of violating the [[Espionage Act of 1917]] and theft of government property, following which the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]] revoked his passport. Two days later, he flew into [[Moscow]]'s [[Sheremetyevo International Airport|Sheremetyevo Airport]], but Russian authorities noted that his [[United States passport|U.S. passport]] had been cancelled, and he was restricted to the airport terminal for over one month. Russia ultimately recognized his [[right of asylum]], with a visa for residence for one year. Repeated extensions have permitted him to stay at least until 2020. In early 2016, he became the president of the [[Freedom of the Press Foundation]], an organization that aims to protect journalists from hacking and government surveillance.{{cite journal|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/02/reporters-need-edward-snowden/|title=Edward Snowden's New Job: Protecting Reporters From Spies|journal=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=February 2017|first=Andy|last=Greenberg}} {{as of|2017}}, he was living in an undisclosed location in Moscow.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/18/russia-extends-edward-snowdens-asylum-2020/ |title=Russia Extends Edward Snowden Asylum until 2020 |work=The Telegraph |date=January 18, 2017 |first=Roland |last=Oliphant}} A subject of controversy, Snowden has been variously called a hero, a [[whistleblower]], a [[dissident]], a [[treason|traitor]], and a [[patriotism|patriot]]. His disclosures have fueled debates over [[mass surveillance]], [[Secrecy#Government secrecy|government secrecy]], and the balance between [[national security]] and [[information privacy]]. ==Background== ===Childhood, family, and education=== Edward Joseph Snowden was born on June 21, 1983,{{cite news |last=Ackerman |first=Spencer |authorlink=Spencer Ackerman|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/10/edward-snowden-army-special-forces |title=Edward Snowden was not successful in joining the US Army's elite special forces unit |work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London |date=June 10, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |quote=The army did confirm Snowden's date of birth: 21 June 1983.}} in [[Elizabeth City, North Carolina]].{{cite news |title=Report: Snowden has document to enter Russia |url=http://www.wvec.com/news/Report-Snowden-has-document-to-enter-Russia-216738651.html |publisher=[[WVEC]] |date=July 24, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822210644/http://www.wvec.com/news/Report-Snowden-has-document-to-enter-Russia-216738651.html |archivedate=August 22, 2013}} "Edward Snowden, who was born in Elizabeth City, NC, is wanted in the U.S. for espionage" by the FBI et al. His maternal grandfather, [[Edward J. Barrett]],{{cite news |title=NSA leaker Edward Snowden has ties to North Carolina |newspaper=[[The News & Observer]] |date=August 1, 2013 |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2013/08/01/3076001/edward-snowden-has-ties-to-north.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141019022334/http://www.newsobserver.com/2013/08/01/3076001/edward-snowden-has-ties-to-north.html |archivedate=October 19, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.uscg.mil/history/people/RetiredFlagOfficerIndex.asp#Br |title=Retired U.S. Coast Guard Flag Officers |publisher=United States Coast Guard |date=May 15, 2014}} a [[rear admiral]] in the [[United States Coast Guard|U.S. Coast Guard]], became a senior official with the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] and was at [[the Pentagon]] in 2001 during the [[September 11 attacks]].{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/edward-snowden-interview/edward-snowdens-motive-revealed-he-can-sleep-night-n116851 |title=Edward Snowden's Motive Revealed: He Can 'Sleep at Night' |first1=Matthew |last1=Cole |first2=Richard |last2=Esposito |first3=Bill |last3=Dedman |first4=Mark |last4=Schone |publisher=NBC News |date=May 28, 2014}} Snowden's father, Lonnie, was also an officer in the Coast Guard,{{cite news |url=http://www.mcall.com/news/breaking/mc-pa-ed-snowden-nsa-leak-20130610,0,7199785.story |title=Edward Snowden's father, stepmother plan to make public statement |last1=Itkowitz |first1=Colby |last2=Sheehan |first2=Daniel Patrick |work=[[The Morning Call]] |location=Allentown, PA |date=June 10, 2013}} and his mother, Elizabeth, is a clerk at the [[United States District Court for the District of Maryland|U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland]].{{cite web|url=https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/Decoder/2013/0611/Edward-Snowden-Who-is-he-and-what-kind-of-life-is-he-leaving-behind|title=Edward Snowden: Who is he, and what kind of life is he leaving behind?|publisher=The Christian Science Monitor|date=11 June 2013|author=Tulumello, Jennifer Skalka}}{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/06/10/snowden-neighbors-surveillance-security/2408573/ |title=Former neighbor remembers Snowden as 'nice kid' |first=Greg |last=Toppo |work=USA
