Jessica, was a lawyer at the [[Federal Judicial Center]] in Washington, D.C. Edward Snowden said that he had expected to work for the federal government, as had the rest of his family.{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/2014/08/edward-snowden/ |title=Edward Snowden: The untold story of the most wanted man in the world |last=Bamford |first=James |date=August 13, 2014 |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]}} His parents divorced in 2001,{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/edward-snowden-interview/edward-snowden-timeline-n114871 |title=Edward Snowden: A Timeline |first1=Matthew |last1=Cole |first2=Mike |last2=Brunker |publisher=NBC News |date=May 26, 2014}} and his father remarried.{{cite web |title=Edward Snowden's father, a Lehigh County resident, tells network he's concerned for son's well-being |url=http://www.lehighvalleylive.com/lehigh-county/index.ssf/2013/06/edward_snowdens_father_a_lehig.html |work=Leheigh Vally Express Times |accessdate=December 3, 2015}} Snowden scored above 145 on two separate [[Intelligence quotient|IQ]] tests. In the early 1990s, while still in grade school, Snowden moved with his family to the area of [[Fort Meade, Maryland]].{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/edward-snowden-interview/who-edward-snowden-man-who-spilled-nsas-secrets-n114861 |title=Who Is Edward Snowden, the Man Who Spilled the NSA's Secrets? |first1=Bill |last1=Dedman |first2=Mike |last2=Brunker |first3=Matthew |last3=Cole |publisher=NBC News |date=May 26, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} [[Infectious mononucleosis|Mononucleosis]] caused him to miss high school for almost nine months. Rather than returning to school, he passed the [[General Educational Development|GED]] test{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/09/edward-snowden-nsa-whistleblower-surveillance |title=Edward Snowden: the whistleblower behind the NSA surveillance revelations |last=Greenwald |first=Glenn |last2=MacAskill |first2=Ewen |last3=Poitras |first3=Laura |date=June 9, 2013 |work=The Guardian |location=London}} and took classes at [[Anne Arundel Community College]]. Although Snowden had no undergraduate college degree, he worked online toward a master's degree at the [[University of Liverpool]], England, in 2011.{{cite news |page=3 |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/us-fears-edward-snowden-defect-china-sources/story?id=19389672&page=3 |title=U.S. Fears Edward Snowden May Defect to China: Sources |publisher=ABC News |date=June 13, 2013}} He was interested in [[Japanese popular culture]], had studied the Japanese language,{{cite news |title=Snowden's Life Surrounded By Spycraft |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ap-impact-snowdens-life-surrounded-spycraft |work=Associated Press |date=June 15, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141219140551/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ap-impact-snowdens-life-surrounded-spycraft |archivedate=December 19, 2014 |deadurl=no}} and worked for an [[anime]] company that had a resident office in the U.S.{{cite news |title=Exclusive: Snowden as a teen online: anime and cheeky humor |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/12/us-usa-security-snowden-anime-idUSBRE95B14B20130612 |agency=Reuters |first1=Kristina |last1=Cooke |first2=Scott |last2=Shiffman |date=June 12, 2013}}{{cite news |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/06/15/national/02-profile-paints-snowden-as-manga-anime-gun-girlish-geek-with-list-of-likes/ |title=Snowden Web manga profile still online |work=Japan Times |location=Tokyo |first=Reiji |last=Yoshida |date=June 15, 2013}} He also said he had a basic understanding of [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin Chinese]] and was deeply interested in [[martial arts]]. At age 20, he listed [[Buddhism]] as his religion on a military recruitment form, noting that the choice of [[agnostic]] was "strangely absent."{{cite news |last1=Broder |first1=John M. |last2=Scott |first2=Shane |date=June 15, 2013 |title=For Snowden, a Life of Ambition, Despite the Drifting |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/16/us/for-snowden-a-life-of-ambition-despite-the-drifting.html |newspaper=The New York Times |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615232919/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/16/us/for-snowden-a-life-of-ambition-despite-the-drifting.html |archivedate=June 15, 2013 |deadurl=no}} ===Political views=== Snowden has said that, in the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 presidential election]], he voted for a [[Third party (United States)|third-party]] candidate, though he "believed in Obama's promises." Following the election, he believed President [[Barack Obama]] was continuing policies espoused by [[George W. Bush]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/09/nsa-whistleblower-edward-snowden-why |title=NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden: 'I do not expect to see home again' |last=MacAskill |first=Ewen |date=June 9, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |work=The Guardian |location=London}} In accounts published in June 2013, interviewers noted that Snowden's laptop displayed stickers supporting Internet freedom organizations including the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] (EFF) and the [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor Project]]. A week after publication of his leaks began, ''[[Ars Technica]]'' confirmed that Snowden had been an active participant at the site's [[Internet forum|online forum]] from 2001 through May 2012, discussing a variety of topics under the pseudonym "TheTrueHOOHA."{{cite news |last=Mullin |first=Joe |date=June 13, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/06/nsa-leaker-ed-snowdens-life-on-ars-technica/ |title=NSA leaker Ed Snowden's life on Ars Technica |work=[[Ars Technica]]}} In a January 2009 entry, TheTrueHOOHA exhibited strong support for the U.S. security state apparatus and said leakers of classified information "should be shot in the balls."{{cite news |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/06/exclusive-in-2009-ed-snowden-said-leakers-should-be-shot-then-he-became-one/3/ |title=In 2009, Ed Snowden said leakers "should be shot." Then he became one. |last=Mullin |first=Joe |date=June 26, 2013 |work=Ars Technica}} However, Snowden disliked Obama's CIA director appointment of Leon Panetta, saying "Obama just named a fucking politician to run the CIA." Snowden was also offended by a possible ban on assault weapons, writing "Me and all my lunatic, gun-toting NRA compatriots would be on the steps of Congress before the C-Span feed finished." Snowden disliked Obama's economic policies, was against Social Security, and favored [[Ron Paul]]'s call for a return to the gold standard.{{cite web |last1=Wilentz |first1=Sean |title=Would You Feel Differently About Snowden, Greenwald, and Assange If You Knew What They Really Thought? |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/116253/edward-snowden-glenn-greenwald-julian-assange-what-they-believe |publisher=New Republic}} In 2014, Snowden supported a [[basic income]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/snowden-exile-exclusive-interview/ |title=Edward Snowden: A 'Nation' Interview |work=The Nation}} ===Career=== Feeling a duty to fight in the [[Iraq War]] to help free oppressed people, Snowden enlisted in the [[United States Army Reserve]] on May 7, 2004, and became a [[United States special operations forces|Special Forces]] candidate through its [[Special Forces (United States Army)#Special Forces MOS descriptions|18X]] enlistment option.{{cite web |title=Army Enlisted Job Descriptions and Qualification Factors: 18X – Special Forces Enlistment Option |url=http://usmilitary.about.com/od/enlistedjobs/a/18x.htm |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} He did not complete the training. After breaking both legs in a training accident,{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/edward-snowden-army-discharge-92486.html |title=Records show Army discharged Edward Snowden after five months |newspaper=Politico |last=Gaskell |first=Stephanie |date=June 10, 2013}} he was discharged on September 28, 2004.{{cite web |last=Ackerman |first=Spencer |title=Edward Snowden did enlist for special forces, US army confirms |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/10/edward-snowden-army-special-forces |work=The Guardian}} Snowden was then employed for less than a year in 2005 as a security guard at the [[University of Maryland|University of Maryland's]] [[Center for Advanced Study of Language]], a research center sponsored by the National Security Agency (NSA).{{cite web |title=University-Affiliated Research Center Laboratories (UARCs) |url=http://www.defenseinnovationmarketplace.mil/FFRDC_UARC.html |publisher=U.S. Department of Defense |accessdate=May 20, 2016}} According to the University, this is not a classified facility,{{cite news |title=Investigators looking into how Snowden gained access at NSA |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/investigators-looking-at-how-snowden-gained-access-at-nsa/2013/06/10/83b4841a-d209-11e2-8cbe-1bcbee06f8f8_story_1.html |first1=Peter |last1=Finn |first2=Greg |last2=Miller |first3=Ellen |last3=Nakashima |work=The Washington Post |date=June 10, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |quote=University spokesman Brian Ullmann confirmed that in 2005, Snowden worked for less than a year as a 'security specialist' for the school's Center for Advanced Study of Language. The university-affiliated center, founded in 2003, is not a classified facility.}} though it is heavily guarded.{{cite web |title=Police detain reporters, stop them from photographing alleged NSA facility where Snowden worked |url=http://www2.campusreform.org/?ID=4792 |first1=Oliver |last1=Darcy |first2=Josiah |last2=Ryan |publisher=Campus Reform |accessdate=May 20, 2016}} In June 2014, Snowden told ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' that his job as a security guard required a high-level [[security clearance]], for which he passed a polygraph exam and underwent a stringent background check. ====Employment at CIA==== After attending a 2006 job-fair focused on intelligence agencies, Snowden accepted an offer for a position at the CIA.{{cite web |author1=Jacob Jijo |title=Edward Snowden Scandal: CIA Sent Him Home But NSA Hired Him Later |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/edward-snowden-scandal-cia-nsa-hired-warning-513190 |publisher=International Business Times |accessdate=January 30, 2014 |date=October 11, 2013}} The Agency assigned him to the global communications division at CIA headquarters in [[Langley, Virginia]]. In May 2006, Snowden wrote in ''Ars Technica'' that he had no trouble getting work because he was a "computer wizard". After distinguishing himself as a junior employee on the top computer-team, Snowden was sent to the CIA's secret school for technology specialists, where he lived in a hotel for six months while studying and training full-time. In March 2007, the CIA stationed Snowden with [[diplomatic cover]] in [[Geneva]], Switzerland, where he was responsible for maintaining computer-network security.{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2013/06/10/190293209/who-is-edward-snowden-the-nsa-leaker |title=Who Is Edward Snowden, The Self-Styled NSA Leaker? |first=Mark |last=Memmott |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=June 10, 2013}} Assigned to the [[Diplomatic mission|U.S. mission]] to the [[United Nations]], Snowden received a diplomatic passport and a four-bedroom apartment near [[Lake Geneva]]. According to Greenwald, while there Snowden was "considered the top technical and cybersecurity expert" in that country and "was hand-picked by the CIA to support the president at the 2008 NATO summit in Romania".{{cite book |title=No Place to Hide |first=Glenn |last=Greenwald |page=43 |publisher=[[Metropolitan Books]] |date=2014 |isbn=978-1627790734}} Snowden described his CIA experience in Geneva as formative, stating that the CIA deliberately got a Swiss banker drunk and encouraged him to drive home. Snowden said that when the latter was arrested, a CIA operative offered to help in exchange for the banker becoming an informant.{{cite news |title=Wie die CIA sich in Genf Bankdaten beschaffte |first=Christian |last=Bütikofer |url=http://www.handelszeitung.ch/politik/wie-die-cia-sich-genf-bankdaten-beschaffte |newspaper=[[Handelszeitung]] |location=Zürich |date=June 10, 2013 |language=German |trans-title= How the CIA acquired bank data in Geneva}} [[Ueli Maurer]], [[President of the Swiss Confederation]] for the year 2013, in June of that year publicly disputed Snowden's claims. "This would mean that the CIA successfully bribed the Geneva police and judiciary. With all due respect, I just can't imagine it," said Maurer.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/16/us-usa-security-switzerland-snowden-idUSBRE95F09120130616 |title=Swiss president would back criminal probe against NSA leaker |agency=Reuters |date=June 16, 2013 |first=Tom |last=Miles}} In February 2009, Snowden resigned from the CIA. {{cite news |title=How Edward Snowden went from loyal NSA contractor to whistleblower |first=Luke |last=Harding |date=January 31, 2014 |publisher=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/01/edward-snowden-intelligence-leak-nsa-contractor-extract}} ====NSA sub-contractee as an employee for Dell==== In 2009, Snowden began work as a contractee for [[Dell]],{{cite news |last=Hosenball |first=Mark |date=August 15, 2013 |title=Snowden downloaded NSA secrets while working for Dell, sources say |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/15/us-usa-security-snowden-dell-idUSBRE97E17P20130815 |publisher=Reuters}} which manages computer systems for multiple government agencies. Assigned to an NSA facility at [[Yokota Air Base]] near [[Tokyo]], Snowden instructed top officials and military officers on how to defend their networks from Chinese hackers. During his four years with Dell, he rose from supervising NSA computer system upgrades to working as what his résumé termed a "cyberstrategist" and an "expert in cyber counterintelligence" at several U.S. locations.{{cite web |title=Résumé Shows Snowden Honed Hacking Skills |first=Christopher |last=Drew |author2=Scott Shane |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/05/us/resume-shows-snowden-honed-hacking-skills.html |date=July 4, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} In 2011, he returned to Maryland, where he spent a year as lead technologist on Dell's CIA account. In that capacity, he was consulted by the chiefs of the CIA's technical branches, including the agency's [[chief information officer]] and its [[chief technology officer]]. U.S. officials and other sources familiar with the investigation said Snowden began downloading documents describing the government's electronic spying programs while working for Dell in April 2012. Investigators estimated that of the 50,000 to 200,000 documents Snowden gave to Greenwald and Poitras, most were copied by Snowden while working at Dell. In March 2012, Dell reassigned Snowden to Hawaii as lead technologist for the NSA's information-sharing office. At the time of his departure from the U.S. in May 2013, he had been employed for 15 months inside the NSA's [[Kunia Regional SIGINT Operations Center|Hawaii regional operations center]], which focuses on the electronic monitoring of China and North Korea,See also [[Edward Jay Epstein]] interview [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QkumH9OBNrY#t=73 at 1:25] the last three of which were with consulting firm [[Booz Allen Hamilton]].{{cite news |title=NSA Implementing 'Two-Person' Rule To Stop The Next Edward Snowden |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/06/18/nsa-director-says-agency-implementing-two-person-rule-to-stop-the-next-edward-snowden/ |last=Greenberg |first=Andy |date=June 18, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |work=[[Forbes]] |location=New York}} While intelligence officials have described his position there as a [[system administrator]], Snowden has said he was an infrastructure |last1=Shane |first1=Scott |last2=Sanger |first2=David E. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130704042802/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/01/us/job-title-key-to-inner-access-held-by-snowden.html |archivedate=July 4, 2013 |deadurl=no |df=}} On March 15, 2013—three days after what he later called his "breaking point" of "seeing the [[Director of National Intelligence]], [[James Clapper]], directly lie under oath to Congress"{{cite web |url=https://edwardsnowden.com/2014/01/27/video-ard-interview-with-edward-snowden/ |title=Transcript: ARD interview with Edward Snowden |publisher=The Kong Getaway |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/edward-jay-epstein-revisiting-snowdens-hong-kong-getaway-1404075875 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal}} Although he has said his career high annual salary was $200,000,{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/17/edward-snowden-nsa-files-whistleblower |title=Edward Snowden: NSA whistleblower answers reader questions |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=June 14, 2013}} Snowden said he took a pay cut to work at Booz Allen,{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/17/edward-snowden-nsa-files-whistleblower |title=Edward Snowden Q&A: Dick Cheney traitor charge is 'the highest honor' |date=June 17, 2013 |first=Glenn |last=Greenwald |publisher=The Guardian |location=London}} where he sought employment in order to gather data and then release details of the NSA's worldwide surveillance activity.Lam, Lana (June 24, 2013). one month after he had left the country.{{cite news |title=Contractor fires Snowden from $122,000 per-year job |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/06/11/booz-allen-snowden-fired/2411231/ |work=USA Today |first=John |last=Bacon |date=June 11, 2013}} A former NSA co-worker said that although the NSA was full of smart people, Snowden was a "genius among geniuses" who created a widely implemented backup system for the NSA and often pointed out security flaws to the agency. The former colleague said Snowden was given full administrator privileges with virtually unlimited access to NSA data. Snowden was offered a position on the NSA's elite team of [[hacker (computer security)|hackers]], [[Tailored Access Operations]], but turned it down to join Booz Allen.{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/12/16/an-nsa-coworker-remembers-the-real-edward-snowden-a-genius-among-geniuses/? |title=An NSA Coworker Remembers The Real Edward Snowden: 'A Genius Among Geniuses' |work=Forbes |date=December 16, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |first=Andy |last=Greenberg}} An anonymous source later said that Booz Allen's hiring screeners found possible discrepancies in Snowden's resume but still decided to hire him."[http://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/1266209/booz-allen-hired-snowden-despite-discrepancies-his-resume Booz Allen hired Snowden despite discrepancies in his résumé]." (print title: "Snowden hired despite discrepancies in résumé"). Reuters. ''[[South China Morning Post]]'' (Hong Kong). June 22, 2013. – [https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/21/us-usa-security-snowden-idUSBRE95K01J20130621 Alternate link] under title: "Exclusive: NSA contractor hired Snowden despite concerns about resume discrepancies" by Hosenball, Mark (Editing by David Lindsey and Stacey Joyce). Snowden's résumé stated that he attended computer-related classes at [[Johns Hopkins University]]. A spokeswoman for Johns Hopkins said that the university did not find records to show that Snowden attended the university, and suggested that he may instead have attended Advanced Career Technologies, a private for-profit organization that operated as the [[American Career Institute|Computer Career Institute]] at [[Johns Hopkins University]]. The University of Maryland University College acknowledged that Snowden had attended a summer session at a UM campus in Asia. Snowden's résumé stated that he estimated that he would receive a [[University of Liverpool]] computer security master's degree in 2013. The university said that Snowden registered for an online master's degree program in computer security in 2011 but was inactive as a student and had not completed the program. Snowden has said that he had told multiple employees and two supervisors about his concerns, but the NSA disputes his claim.{{cite news |last=Gellmann |first=Barton |title=Edward Snowden, after months of NSA revelations, says his mission's accomplished |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/edward-snowden-after-months-of-nsa-revelations-says-his-missions-accomplished/2013/12/23/49fc36de-6c1c-11e3-a523-fe73f0ff6b8d_story.html |accessdate=January 4, 2014 |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=December 24, 2013}} Snowden elaborated in January 2014, saying "[I] made tremendous efforts to report these programs to co-workers, supervisors, and anyone with the proper clearance who would listen. The reactions of those I told about the scale of the constitutional violations ranged from deeply concerned to appalled, but no one was willing to risk their jobs, families, and possibly even freedom to go through what [Thomas Andrews] [[Thomas Andrews Drake|Drake]] did."{{cite news |last=Cassidy |first=John |date=January 23, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |title=A Vindicated Snowden Says He'd Like to Come Home |url=http://www.newyorker.com/rational-irrationality/a-vindicated-snowden-says-hed-like-to-come-home |newspaper=The New Yorker}} In March 2014, during testimony to the European Parliament, Snowden wrote that before revealing classified information he had reported "clearly problematic programs" to ten officials, who he said did nothing in response.{{cite news |last=Peterson |first=Andrea |title=Snowden: I raised NSA concerns internally over 10 times before going rogue |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2014/03/07/snowden-i-raised-nsa-concerns-internally-over-10-times-before-going-rogue/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=March 10, 2014}} In a May 2014 interview, Snowden told [[NBC News]] that after bringing his concerns about the legality of the NSA spying programs to officials, he was told to stay silent on the matter. He asserted that the NSA had copies of emails he sent to their Office of [[General Counsel]], oversight and compliance personnel broaching "concerns about the NSA's interpretations of its legal authorities. I had raised these complaints not just officially in writing through email, but to my supervisors, to my colleagues, in more than one office." In May 2014, U.S. officials released a single email that Snowden had written in April 2013 inquiring about legal authorities but said that they had found no other evidence that Snowden had expressed his concerns to someone in an oversight position.Ellen Nakashima and Barton Gellman (May 29, 2014) [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/e-mail-snowden-sent-to-nsa-counsel-is-released/2014/05/29/4cc43410-e760-11e3-a86b-362fd5443d19_story.html U.S. officials, Snowden clash over e-mail records] ''[[Washington Post]]'' In June 2014, the NSA said it had not been able to find any records of Snowden raising internal complaints about the agency's operations.{{cite news |first=Julian |last=Hattem |date=June 25, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |url=http://thehill.com/policy/technology/210570-nsa-no-documents-of-snowden-complaints |title=NSA says it has no record of Snowden challenging spying |newspaper=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}} That same month, Snowden explained that he himself has not produced the communiqués in question because of the ongoing nature of the dispute, disclosing for the first time that "I am working with the NSA in regard to these records and we're going back and forth, so I don't want to reveal everything that will come out."{{cite web |title=Edward Snowden speaks to the Council of Europe on improving the protection of whistleblowers |url=http://www.edwardsnowden.com/2014/06/25/edward-snowden-speaks-to-the-council-of-europe-on-improving-the-protection-of-whistleblowers/ |work=The Courage Foundation |date=June 25, 2014}} In his May 2014 interview with NBC News, Snowden accused the U.S. government of trying to use one position here or there in his career to distract from the totality of his experience, downplaying him as a "low level analyst." In his words, he was "trained as a spy in the traditional sense of the word in that I lived and worked undercover overseas—pretending to work in a job that I'm not—and even being assigned a name that was not mine." He said he'd worked for the NSA undercover overseas, and for the [[Defense Intelligence Agency|DIA]] had developed sources and methods to keep information and people secure "in the most hostile and dangerous environments around the world. So when they say I'm a low-level systems administrator, that I don't know what I'm talking about, I'd say it's somewhat misleading." In a June interview with [[Globo TV]], Snowden reiterated that he "was actually functioning at a very senior level."[http://g1.globo.com/fantastico/noticia/2014/06/se-o-brasil-me-oferecer-asilo-aceito-diz-edward-snowden.html 'Se o Brasil me oferecer asilo, aceito', diz Edward Snowden] at 3:03 ''[[Rede Globo]]'' June 1, 2014 In a July interview with ''[[The Guardian]]'', Snowden explained that, during his NSA career, "I began to move from merely overseeing these systems to actively directing their use. Many people don’t understand that I was actually an analyst and I designated individuals and groups for targeting."{{cite news |last1=Rusbridger |first1=Alan |last2=MacAskill |first2=Ewen |title=Edward Snowden interview – the edited transcript |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/18/-sp-edward-snowden-nsa-whistleblower-interview-transcript |date=July 18, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian}} Snowden subsequently told ''Wired'' that while at Dell in 2011, "I would sit down with the [[Chief information officer|CIO]] of the CIA, the [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] of the CIA, the chiefs of all the technical branches. They would tell me their hardest technology problems, and it was my job to come up with a way to fix them." Of his time as an NSA analyst, directing the work of others, Snowden recalled a moment when he and his colleagues began to have severe ethical doubts. Snowden said 18 to 22-year-old analysts were suddenly "thrust into a position of extraordinary responsibility, where they now have access to all your private records. In the course of their daily work, they stumble across something that is completely unrelated in any sort of necessary sense—for example, an intimate nude photo of someone in a sexually compromising situation. But they're extremely attractive. So what do they do? They turn around in their chair and they show a co-worker ... and sooner or later this person's whole life has been seen by all of these other people." As Snowden observed it, this behavior happened routinely every two months but was never reported, being considered one of the "fringe benefits" of the work.{{cite news |last1=Rusbridger |first1=Alan |last2=MacAskill |first2=Ewen |title=I, spy: Edward Snowden in exile |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/18/-sp-edward-snowden-interview-rusbridger-macaskill |date=July 18, 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian}} ==Global surveillance disclosures== {{Main|Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)}} The exact size of Snowden's disclosure is unknown,Mazzetti, Mark and Schmidt, Michael S. (December 14, 2013) [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/15/us/officials-say-us-may-never-know-extent-of-snowdens-leaks.html Officials Say U.S. May Never Know Extent of Snowden's Leaks]. ''The New York Times'' but Australian officials have estimated 15,000 or more [[Australian Intelligence Community|Australian intelligence]] files{{cite news |last=Cameron Stewart and Paul Maley |title=Edward Snowden stole up to 20,000 Aussie files |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/policy/edward-snowden-stole-up-to-20000-aussie-files/story-fn59nm2j-1226775491490# |publisher=''[[The Australian]]'' |accessdate=February 1, 2014 |date=December 5, 2013}} and British officials estimate at least 58,000 [[List of intelligence agencies of the United Kingdom|British intelligence]] files.{{cite news |title=David Miranda row: Seized files 'endanger agents' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23898580 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=February 1, 2014 |date=August 30, 2013}} NSA Director [[Keith B. Alexander|Keith Alexander]] initially estimated that Snowden had copied anywhere from 50,000 to 200,000 NSA documents.Hosenball, M. (November 14, 2013). [https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/14/us-usa-security-nsa-idUSBRE9AD19B20131114 NSA chief says Snowden leaked up to 200,000 secret documents]. Reuters. Later estimates provided by U.S. officials were on the order of 1.7 million,{{cite news |last=Chris Strohm and Del Quentin Wilber |title=Pentagon Says Snowden Took Most U.S. Secrets Ever: Rogers |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-01-09/pentagon-finds-snowden-took-1-7-million-files-rogers-says.html |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |accessdate=February 1, 2014 |date=January 10, 2014}} a number that originally came from [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] talking points.{{cite news |last=Leopold |first=Jason |title=Exclusive: Inside Washington's Quest to Bring Down Edward Snowden |url=https://news.vice.com/article/exclusive-inside-washingtons-quest-to-bring-down-edward-snowden |work=[[Vice News]] |accessdate=June 4, 2015 |date=June 4, 2015}} In July 2014, ''The Washington Post'' reported on a cache previously provided by Snowden from domestic NSA operations consisting of "roughly 160,000 intercepted e-mail and instant-message conversations, some of them hundreds of pages long, and 7,900 documents taken from more than 11,000 online accounts."{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/in-nsa-intercepted-data-those-not-targeted-far-outnumber-the-foreigners-who-are/2014/07/05/8139adf8-045a-11e4-8572-4b1b969b6322_story.html |title=In NSA-intercepted data, those not targeted far outnumber the foreigners who are |last1=Gellman |first1=Barton |last2=Tate |first2=Julie |last3=Soltani |first3=Ashkan |date=July 5, 2014 |work=[[The Washington Post]]}} A U.S. [[Defense Intelligence Agency]] report declassified in June 2015 said that Snowden took 900,000 [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] files, more than he downloaded from the NSA. In March 2014, Army General [[Martin Dempsey]], [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]], told the [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|House Armed Services Committee]], "The vast majority of the documents that Snowden ... exfiltrated from our highest levels of security ... had nothing to do with exposing government oversight of domestic activities. The vast majority of those were related to our military capabilities, operations, tactics, techniques and procedures."{{cite news |last=Capra |first=Tony |title=Snowden Leaks Could Cost Military Billions: Pentagon |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/investigations/snowden-leaks-could-cost-military-billions-pentagon-n46426 |work=NBC News |date=March 6, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} When asked in a May 2014 interview to quantify the number of documents Snowden stole, retired NSA director [[Keith B. Alexander|Keith Alexander]] said there was no accurate way of counting what he took, but Snowden may have downloaded more than a million documents.{{cite web |title=Interview transcript: former head of the NSA and commander of the US cyber command, General Keith Alexander |url=http://www.afr.com/p/technology/interview_transcript_former_head_51yP0Cu1AQGUCs7WAC9ZVN |work=Australian Financial Review |accessdate=May 30, 2014}} According to Snowden, he did not indiscriminately turn over documents to journalists, stating that "I carefully evaluated every single document I disclosed to ensure that each was legitimately in the public interest. There are all sorts of documents that would have made a big impact that I didn't turn over"{{cite news |last1=Greenwald |first1=Glenn |last2=MacAskill |first2=Ewen |last3=Poitras |first3=Laura |date=June 10, 2013 |title=Edward Snowden: the whistleblower behind the NSA surveillance revelations |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/09/edward-snowden-nsa-whistleblower-surveillance |newspaper=The Guardian |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801014250/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/09/edward-snowden-nsa-whistleblower-surveillance |archivedate=August 1, 2013 |deadurl=no}} and that "I have to screen everything before releasing it to journalists ... If I have time to go through this information, I would like to make it available to journalists in each country." Despite these measures, the improper redaction of a document by ''The New York Times'' resulted in the exposure of intelligence activity against al-Qaeda.{{cite web |last1=Yuhas |first1=Alan |title=John Oliver presses Edward Snowden on whether he read all leaked NSA material |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/apr/06/edward-snowden-john-oliver-last-week-tonight-nsa-leaked-documents |website=theguardian.com |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |accessdate=September 30, 2015}} In June 2014, the NSA's recently installed director, [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] [[Admiral (United States)|Admiral]] [[Michael S. Rogers]], said that while some terrorist groups had altered their communications to avoid surveillance techniques revealed by Snowden, the damage done was not significant enough to conclude that "the sky is falling."Sanger, David E. (June 29, 2014) [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/30/us/sky-isnt-falling-after-snowden-nsa-chief-says.html New N.S.A. Chief Calls Damage From Snowden Leaks Manageable]. ''The New York Times'' Nevertheless, in February 2015, Rogers said that Snowden's disclosures had a material impact on the NSA's detection and evaluation of terrorist activities worldwide.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/02/23/politics/nsa-surveillance-north-korea/ |title=NSA: Snowden leaks hurt ability to track terrorists |publisher=CNN |date=February 23, 2015 |first=Aaron |last=Cooper}} On 14 June 2015, UK's ''Sunday Times'' reported that Russian and Chinese intelligence services had decrypted more than 1 million classified files in the Snowden cache, forcing the UK's [[MI6]] intelligence agency to move agents out of live operations in hostile countries. [[Sir David Omand]], a former director of the UK's [[GCHQ]] intelligence gathering agency, described it as a huge strategic setback that was harming Britain, America, and their NATO allies. ''The Sunday Times'' said it was not clear whether Russia and China stole Snowden's data or whether Snowden voluntarily handed it over to remain at liberty in Hong Kong and Moscow.{{cite web |last1=Haynes |first1=Deborah |title=Full damage of Snowden leaks revealed |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/uk/defence/article4385198.ece |website=thetimes.co.uk |publisher=The Times |accessdate=December 3, 2015}}{{subscription required}}{{cite web|title=British spies 'moved after Snowden files read'|website=bbc.com|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-33125068|publisher=[[BBC News]]}} In April 2015 the [[Henry Jackson Society]], a British [[neoconservative]] [[think tank]], published a report claiming that Snowden's intelligence leaks negatively impacted Britain's ability to fight terrorism and organized crime.{{cite web |last1=Simcox |first1=Robin |title=Surveillance after Snowden:Effective Espionage in an Age of Transparency |url=http://henryjacksonsociety.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Surveillance-after-Snowden.pdf |website=henryjacksonsociety.org |publisher=[[Henry Jackson Society]] |accessdate=December 3, 2015}} Gus Hosein, executive director of [[Privacy International]], criticized the report for, in his opinion, presuming that the public became concerned about privacy only after Snowden's disclosures.{{cite news |url=http://www.channel4.com/news/edward-snowden-mass-surveillance-gchq-nsa |title=Snowden leaks: undermining security or defending privacy? |publisher=[[Channel 4]] |date=May 26, 2015}} ===Release of NSA documents=== Snowden's decision to leak NSA documents developed gradually following his March 2007 posting as a technician to the Geneva CIA station.{{cite news |last=Risen |first=James |title=Snowden Says He Took No Secret Files to Russia |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/18/world/snowden-says-he-took-no-secret-files-to-russia.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=January 20, 2014 |date=October 17, 2013}} Snowden first made contact with [[Glenn Greenwald]], a journalist working at ''The Guardian'', on December 1, 2012.{{cite news |last=Maass |first=Peter |authorlink=Peter Maass |date=August 13, 2013 |title=How Laura Poitras Helped Snowden Spill His Secrets |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/18/magazine/laura-poitras-snowden.html |newspaper=The New York Times}}{{cite news |last=Reitman |first=Janet |authorlink=Janet Reitman |date=December 4, 2013 |title=Snowden and Greenwald: The Men Who Leaked the Secrets |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/snowden-and-greenwald-the-men-who-leaked-the-secrets-20131204 |newspaper=Rolling Stone}} He contacted Greenwald anonymously as "Cincinnatus"Kevin Poulsen (May 21, 2014) [https://www.wired.com/2014/05/snowden-cryptoparty/ Snowden's First Move Against the NSA Was a Party in Hawaii] ''Wired'' and said he had sensitive documents that he would like to share.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/19/edward-snowden-nsa-secrets-glenn-greenwald-laura-poitras How Edward Snowden led journalist and film-maker to reveal NSA secrets]. ''The Guardian''. Greenwald found the measures that the source asked him to take to secure their communications, such as encrypting email, too annoying to employ. Snowden then contacted documentary filmmaker [[Laura Poitras]] in January 2013.{{cite news |url=https://www.salon.com/2013/06/10/qa_with_laura_poitras_the_woman_behind_the_nsa_scoops/ |title=How we broke the NSA story |last=Carmon |first=Irin |date=June 10, 2013 |work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]}} According to Poitras, Snowden chose to contact her after seeing her ''New York Times'' article about NSA whistleblower [[William Binney (U.S. intelligence official)|William Binney]].{{cite journal |last=Packer |first=George |authorlink=George Packer |authormask= |date=October 20, 2014 |title=The Holder of Secrets |department=Profiles |journal=[[The New Yorker]] |volume=90 |issue=32 |pages=50–59 |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/10/20/holder-secrets}} What originally attracted Snowden to both Greenwald and Poitras was a ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'' article written by Greenwald detailing how Poitras' controversial films had made her a target of the government. Greenwald began working with Snowden in either February{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/edward-snowden-nsa-leaker-glenn-greenwald-barton-gellman-92505.html#ixzz2VrPnKjNf |title=Barton Gellman, Glenn Greenwald feud over NSA leaker |last=Weinger |first=Mackenzie |date=June 10, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |work=[[Politico]]}} or April 2013, after Poitras asked Greenwald to meet her in New York City, at which point Snowden began providing documents to them. [[Barton Gellman]], writing for ''The Washington Post'', says his first direct contact was on May 16, 2013. According to Gellman, Snowden approached Greenwald after the ''Post'' declined to guarantee publication within 72 hours of all 41 PowerPoint slides that Snowden had leaked exposing the [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] electronic data mining program, and to publish online an encrypted code allowing Snowden to later prove that he was the source. Snowden communicated using [[Email encryption|encrypted email]], and going by the codename "[[:wikt:verax|Verax]]". He asked not to be quoted at length for fear of identification by [[stylometry]].{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/code-name-verax-snowden-in-exchanges-with-post-reporter-made-clear-he-knew-risks/2013/06/09/c9a25b54-d14c-11e2-9f1a-1a7cdee20287_story.html |title=Code name 'Verax': Snowden, in exchanges with Post reporter, made clear he knew risks |last=Gellman |first=Barton |date=June 10, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |work=[[The Washington Post]]}} According to Gellman, prior to their first meeting in person, Snowden wrote, "I understand that I will be made to suffer for my actions, and that the return of this information to the public marks my end." Snowden also told Gellman that until the articles were published, the journalists working with him would also be at mortal risk from the [[United States Intelligence Community]] "if they think you are the single point of failure that could stop this disclosure and make them the sole owner of this information." In May 2013, Snowden was permitted temporary leave from his position at the NSA in Hawaii, on the pretext of receiving treatment for his [[epilepsy]]. In mid-May, Snowden gave an electronic interview to Poitras and [[Jacob Appelbaum]] which was published weeks later by ''[[Der Spiegel]]''.{{cite web |title=Interview with Whistleblower Edward Snowden on Global Spying |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/interview-with-whistleblower-edward-snowden-on-global-spying-a-910006.html |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |accessdate=December 18, 2013 |date=July 8, 2013 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qq1jHlUe?url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/interview-with-whistleblower-edward-snowden-on-global-spying-a-910006.html |archivedate=July 5, 2014 |df=mdy}} (, [http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/interview-with-whistleblower-edward-snowden-on-global-spying-a-910006-2.html Page 2], [https://www.webcitation.org/6Qq24BvDP?url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/interview-with-whistleblower-edward-snowden-on-global-spying-a-910006-2.html Page 2 Archive]) – Originally published in German in Issue 28/2013, July 8, 2013. Snowden interview originally conducted in English, with English version of the article using the original English interview After disclosing the copied documents, Snowden promised that nothing would stop subsequent disclosures. In June 2013, he said, "All I can say right now is the US government is not going to be able to cover this up by jailing or murdering me. Truth is coming, and it cannot be stopped."{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jun/17/world/la-fg-nsa-leak-20130618 |title=Edward Snowden vows more disclosures about U.S. surveillance |work=Los Angeles Times |date=June 17, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |first1=Shashank |last1=Bengali |first2=Ken |last2=Dilanian}} ===Publication=== On May 20, 2013, Snowden flew to [[Hong Kong]], where he was staying when the initial articles based on the leaked documents were published,{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/hong-kong-hotel-says-edward-snowden-was-there-but-checked-out-monday/2013/06/10/44baa0fa-d1af-11e2-a73e-826d299ff459_story.html |title=Edward Snowden faces strong extradition treaty if he remains in Hong Kong |last=Yang |first=Jia Lynn |date=June 10, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |work=The Washington Post}} beginning with ''The Guardian'' on June 5.{{cite web |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/multimedia/timeline-edward-snowden-revelations.html |title=Timeline of Edward Snowden's revelations | Al Jazeera America |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=December 3, 2015}} Greenwald later said Snowden disclosed 9,000 to 10,000 documents.[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/journalist-says-explosive-reports-coming-from-snowden-data-a-912034.html Greenwald: 'Explosive' NSA Spying Reports Are Imminent] ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' July 19, 2013 Within months, documents had been obtained and published by media outlets worldwide, most notably ''The Guardian'' (Britain), ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' (Germany), ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''[[The New York Times]]'' (U.S.), ''[[O Globo]]'' (Brazil), ''[[Le Monde]]'' (France), and similar outlets in Sweden, Canada, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Spain, and Australia.{{cite web |title=NSA Primary Sources |url=https://www.eff.org/nsa-spying/nsadocs |publisher=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] |accessdate=December 14, 2013}} In 2014, [[NBC]] broke its first story based on the leaked documents.{{cite news |first1=Richard |last1=Esposito |first2=Matthew |last2=Cole |first3=Mark |last3=Schone |first4=Glenn |last4=Greenwald |title=Snowden docs reveal British spies snooped on YouTube and Facebook |url=http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2014/01/27/22469304-snowden-docs-reveal-british-spies-snooped-on-youtube-and-facebook |publisher=[[NBC]] |accessdate=January 29, 2014}} In February 2014, for reporting based on Snowden's leaks, journalists Glenn Greenwald, Laura Poitras, Barton Gellman and ''The Guardian′''s [[Ewen MacAskill]] were honored as co-recipients of the 2013 [[George Polk Award]], which they dedicated to Snowden.{{cite web |title=Journalists who broke NSA story in Guardian dedicate award to Snowden |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/11/journalists-nsa-guardian-polk-award-snowden |work=The Guardian |accessdate=April 25, 2014}} The NSA reporting by these journalists also earned ''The Guardian'' and ''The Washington Post'' the 2014 [[Pulitzer Prize for Public Service]]{{cite web |title=Edward Snowden's prize |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/04/pulitzer-prize-edward-snowden-105682.html |work=Politico |accessdate=April 25, 2014}} for exposing the "widespread surveillance" and for helping to spark a "huge public debate about the extent of the government's spying". ''The Guardian''{{'}}s chief editor, [[Alan Rusbridger]], credited Snowden for having performed a public service.{{cite news |title=The Pulitzer Prizes Just Demolished The Idea That Edward Snowden Is A Traitor |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/14/pulitzers-edward-snowden-traitor_n_5148471.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=April 14, 2014 |accessdate=April 17, 2014 |first=Jack |last=Mirkinson}} ===Revelations=== {{Main|Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)}} {{See also|PRISM (surveillance program)#Responses to disclosures}} [[File:NSA Muscular Google |last2=Soltani |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html |title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say |work=The Washington Post |date=November 1, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} the sketch shows where the |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2013/11/04/how-we-know-the-nsa-had-access-to-internal-google-and-yahoo-cloud-data/|title=How we know the NSA had access to internal Google and Yahoo cloud data |work=The Washington Post |date=November 4, 2013}}]] [[File:US intelligence budget.png|thumb|Data visualization of U.S. intelligence [[black budget]] (2013)]] The ongoing publication of leaked documents has revealed previously unknown details of a [[global surveillance]] apparatus run by the [[National Security Agency|United States' NSA]]{{cite news |first1=Glenn |last1=Greenwald |first2=Ewen |last2=MacAskill |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/08/nsa-boundless-informant-global-datamining |title=Boundless Informant: the NSA's secret tool to track global surveillance data |work=The Guardian |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |location=London |date=June 8, 2013}} in close cooperation with three of its [[Five Eyes]] partners: Australia's [[Australian Signals Directorate|ASD]],{{cite web |last=Tim Leslie and Mark Corcoran |title=Explained: Australia's involvement with the NSA, the US spy agency at heart of global scandal |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-11-08/australian-nsa-involvement-explained/5079786 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=December 18, 2013}} the UK's [[Government |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/01/gchq-europe-spy-agencies-mass-surveillance-snowden |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=December 18, 2013}} and Canada's [[Communications Security Establishment Canada|CSEC]].{{cite news |first1=Greg |last1=Weston |first2=Glenn |last2=Greenwald |first3=Ryan |last3=Gallagher |title=Snowden document shows Canada set up spy posts for NSA |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/snowden-document-shows-canada-set-up-spy-posts-for-nsa-1.2456886 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=December 13, 2013 |date=December 10, 2013}} [[File:Prism-slide-8.jpg|thumb|PRISM: a [[clandestine operation|clandestine]] [[global surveillance|surveillance]] program under which the NSA collects user data from companies like [[Microsoft]], [[Google]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Yahoo]], [[Facebook]] and [[YouTube]].]] On June 5, 2013, media reports documenting the existence and functions of classified surveillance programs and their scope began and continued throughout the entire year. The first program to be revealed was [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], which allows for court-approved direct access to Americans' [[Google]] and [[Yahoo]] accounts, reported from both ''The Washington Post'' and ''The Guardian'' published one hour apart.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/special/politics/prism-collection-documents/ |title=NSA slides explain the PRISM data-collection program |work=The Washington Post |date=July 10, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} Barton Gellman of ''The Washington Post'' was the first journalist to report on Snowden's documents. He said the U.S. government urged him not to specify by name which companies were involved, but Gellman decided that to name them "would make it real to Americans."{{cite news |last=Levy |first=Steven |url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2014/01/how-the-us-almost-killed-the-internet/all/ |title=How the NSA Almost Killed the Internet | Threat Level |work=Wired |date=January 7, 2014}} Reports also What happens next?" ===Motivations=== [[File:PRISM - Snowden Interview - Laura Poitras HQ.webm|thumb|Snowden speaks about the NSA leaks, in Hong Kong, filmed by Laura Poitras.]] Snowden first contemplated leaking confidential documents around 2008 but held back, partly because he believed the newly elected Barack Obama might introduce reforms. After the disclosures, his identity was made public by ''The Guardian'' at his request on June 9, 2013. "I do not want to live in a world where everything I do and say is recorded," he said. "My sole motive is to inform the public as to that which is done in their name and that which is done against them."{{cite AV media |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2013/jun/09/nsa-whistleblower-edward-snowden-interview-video |title=NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden: 'I don't want to live in a society that does these sort of things' |format=video |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=June 9, 2013}} Snowden said he wanted to "embolden others to step forward" by demonstrating that "they can win."Gellman, Barton. (June 9, 2013) [https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-06-09/world/39856622_1_intelligence-powers-single-point "Code name 'Verax': Snowden, in exchanges with Post reporter, made clear he knew risks"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131201065806/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-06-09/world/39856622_1_intelligence-powers-single-point |date=December 1, 2013 }}. ''The Washington Post''. He also said that the system for reporting problems did not work. "You have to report wrongdoing to those most responsible for it." He cited a lack of whistleblower protection for government contractors, the use of the 1917 [[Espionage Act]] to prosecute leakers, and his belief that had he used internal mechanisms to "sound the alarm," his revelations "would have been buried forever."[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/18/edward-snowden-us-would-have-buried-nsa-warnings-forever Edward Snowden: US would have buried NSA warnings forever]. ''The Guardian''. (October 18, 2013). In December 2013, upon learning that a U.S. federal judge had ruled the collection of U.S. phone metadata conducted by the NSA as likely unconstitutional, Snowden said, "I acted on my belief that the NSA's mass surveillance programs would not withstand a constitutional challenge, and that the American public deserved a chance to see these issues determined by open courts ... today, a secret program authorized by a secret court was, when exposed to the light of day, found to violate Americans' rights."{{cite news |title=Federal Judge Rules Against N.S.A. Phone Data Program |date=December 16, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/17/us/politics/federal-judge-rules-against-nsa-phone-data-program.html |newspaper=The New York Times |first=Charlie |last=Savage}} In January 2014, Snowden said his "breaking point" was "seeing the Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, directly lie under oath to Congress." This referred to testimony on March 12, 2013—three months after Snowden first sought to share thousands of NSA documents with Greenwald, and nine months after the NSA says Snowden made his first illegal downloads during the summer of 2012—in which Clapper denied to the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|U.S. Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]] that the NSA wittingly collects data on millions of Americans.{{cite news |last=Greenberg |first=Andy |title=Watch Top U.S. Intelligence Officials Repeatedly Deny NSA Spying On Americans Over The Last Year (Videos) |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/06/06/watch-top-u-s-intelligence-officials-repeatedly-deny-nsa-spying-on-americans-over-the-last-year-videos/ |work=[[Forbes]] |date=June 6, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} Snowden said, "There's no saving an intelligence community that believes it can lie to the public and the legislators who need to be able to trust it and regulate its actions. The public had a right to know about these programs."{{cite web |title=Snowden-Interview: Transcript |url=http://www.ndr.de/ratgeber/netzwelt/snowden277_page-1.html |accessdate=January 28, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140128224400/http://www.ndr.de/ratgeber/netzwelt/snowden277_page-1.html |archivedate=January 28, 2014}} In March 2014, Snowden said he had reported policy or legal issues related to spying programs to more than ten officials, but as a contractor had no legal avenue to pursue further whistleblowing.Peterson, Andrea. I have been given no reason to doubt your system.'}} Snowden also told the ''Post'' that "the United States government has committed a tremendous number of crimes against Hong Kong [and] the [[China|PRC]] as well,"Lana Lam (June 12, 2014) [http://multimedia.scmp.com/snowden/ Edward Snowden in Hong Kong] ''[[South China Morning Post]]'' going on to identify Chinese Internet Protocol addresses that the NSA monitored and stating that the NSA collected text-message data for Hong Kong residents. Glenn Greenwald said Snowden was motivated by a need to "ingratiate himself to the people of Hong Kong and China."[[Eli Lake]] (June 25, 2013) [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/06/25/greenwald-snowden-s-files-are-out-there-if-anything-happens-to-him.html Greenwald: Snowden's Files Are Out There if 'Anything Happens' to Him] ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' After leaving the Mira Hotel, Snowden stayed in a cramped apartment with other refugees seeking asylum in Hong Kong, an arrangement set up by Tibbo to hide from the authorities.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/08/world/asia/hong-kong-edward-snowden-refugees.html |title=After Edward Snowden Fled U.S., Asylum Seekers in Hong Kong Took Him In |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 7, 2016 |first=Patrick |last=Boehler}} The Russian newspaper ''[[Kommersant]]'' nevertheless reported that Snowden was living at the Russian consulate shortly before his departure from Hong Kong to Moscow.{{cite news |first=Will |last=Englund |date=August 26, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/report-snowden-stayed-at-russian-consulate-while-in-hong-kong/2013/08/26/8237cf9a-0e39-11e3-a2b3-5e107edf9897_story.html |title=Report: Snowden stayed at Russian consulate while in Hong Kong |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}} [[Ben Wizner]], a lawyer with the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) and legal adviser to Snowden, said in January 2014, "Every news organization in the world has been trying to confirm that story. They haven't been able to, because it's false."{{cite web |last=Mayer |first=Jane |title=Snowden Calls Russian-Spy Story "Absurd" |url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2014/01/snowden-calls-russian-spy-story-absurd.html |work=The New Yorker |accessdate=January 22, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140807192630/http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/snowden-calls-russian-spy-story-absurd-in-exclusive-interview |archivedate=August 7, 2014 |deadurl=no}} Likewise rejecting the ''Kommersant'' story was [[Anatoly Kucherena]], who became Snowden's lawyer in July 2013 when Snowden asked him for help in seeking temporary asylum in Russia.{{cite web |last=Luhn |first=Alec |title=Edward Snowden passed time in airport reading and surfing internet |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/01/edward-snowden-airport-reading |work=The Guardian [http://rbth.asia/world/2013/09/06/snowden_asked_russian_diplomats_in_hong_kong_for_help_-_putin_48711.html Snowden "asked Russian diplomats in Hong Kong for help" – Putin] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130907160506/http://rbth.asia/world/2013/09/06/snowden_asked_russian_diplomats_in_hong_kong_for_help_-_putin_48711.html |date=September 7, 2013 }} ''[[Russia Beyond the Headlines]]''[http://www.itar-tass.com/en/c32/859415.html Snowden is in 'safe place' waiting for his father to discuss future] ''[[Information Telegraph Agency of Russia]]'' August 31, 2013 representatives.[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323623304579054890606102138 Putin Admits Early Snowden Contact] ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' September 4, 2013 On June 22 (18 days in Ecuador] [[Fox News Channel]] June 23, 2013 On June 23, Snowden boarded the commercial [[Aeroflot]] flight SU213 to Moscow, accompanied by [[Sarah Harrison (journalist)|Sarah Harrison]] of [[WikiLeaks]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/24/world/offering-snowden-aid-wikileaks-gets-back-in-the-game.html|title=Offering Snowden Aid, WikiLeaks Gets Back in the authorities said that Snowden had not been detained for the U.S. because the request had not fully complied with Hong Kong law,{{cite news |last1=Perlez |first1=Jane |last2=Bradsher |first2=Keith |date=June 24, 2013 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/24/world/asia/china-said-to-have-made-call-to-let-leaker-depart.html |title=China Said to Have Made Call to Let Leaker Depart |work=[[The New York Times]] |page=A9 (US edition)}}{{cite press release |url=http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201306/23/P201306230476.htm |title=HKSAR Government issues statement on Edward Snowden |publisher=Hong |url=http://www.news.gov.hk/en/categories/law_order/html/2013/06/20130624_163906.shtml |publisher=Hong Kong Information Services Department}}{{cite web |title=No delay in Snowden case: SJ |date=June 25, 2013 |url=http://www.news.gov.hk/en/categories/law_order/html/2013/06/20130625_175835.shtml |publisher=Hong Kong Information Services Department}}{{refn|Hong Kong's [[Secretary for Justice (Hong Kong)|Secretary for Justice]] [[Rimsky Yuen]] argued that government officials did not issue a provisional arrest warrant for Snowden due to "discrepancies and missing information" in the paperwork sent by U.S. authorities. Yuen explained that Snowden's full name was inconsistent, and his U.S. passport number was also missing.{{cite news |title=Hong Kong did not assist Snowden's departure |url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130625/hong-kong-did-not-assist-snowdens-departure |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=June 25, 2013 |work=Global Post |quote=Yuen also said there were discrepancies and missing information in documents used to identify Snowden. 'On the diplomatic documents, James was used as the middle name, on the record upon entering the border, Joseph was used as the middle name, on the American court documents sent to us by the American Justice department, it only said Edward J Snowden,' he said. Hong Kong authorities also noticed that documents produced by the U.S. did not show Snowden's American passport number. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712143252/http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130625/hong-kong-did-not-assist-snowdens-departure |archivedate=July 12, 2013 |df=}} Hong Kong also wanted more details of the charges and evidence against Snowden to make sure it was not a political case. Yuen said he spoke to U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder by phone to reinforce the request for details "absolutely necessary" for detention of Snowden. Yuen said "As the US government had failed to provide the information by the time Snowden left Hong Kong, it was impossible for the Department of Justice to apply to a court for a temporary warrant of arrest. In fact, even at this time, the US government has still not provided the details we asked for."{{cite news |last=Luk |first=Eddie |date=June 26, 2013 |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=134957&sid=39870263&con_type=1&d_str=20130626&isSearch=1&sear_year=2013 |title=Justice chief spells it out |work=The Standard |location=Hong Kong |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822210647/http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=134957&sid=39870263&con_type=1&d_str=20130626&isSearch=1&sear_year=2013 |archivedate=August 22, 2013 |df=mdy}}|group="Notes"}} On June 24, a U.S. State Department spokesman rejected the explanation of technical noncompliance, accusing the Hong Kong government of deliberately releasing a fugitive despite a valid arrest warrant and after having sufficient time to prohibit his travel.[https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/dpb/2013/06/211081.htm#SNOWDEN Daily Press Briefing] ''[[United States Department of State]]'' June 24, 2013 That same day, [[Julian Assange]] said that WikiLeaks had paid for Snowden's lodging in Hong Kong and his flight out.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/24/us-usa-security-reconstruction-idUSBRE95N1CA20130624/ |title=Behind Snowden's Hong Kong exit: fear and persuasion |agency=Reuters |first1=James |last1=Pomfret |first2=Greg |last2=Torode |date=June 24, 2013}} In October 2013, Snowden said that before flying to Moscow, he gave all the classified documents he had obtained to journalists he met in Hong Kong, and kept no copies for himself. In January 2014, he told a German TV interviewer that he gave all of his information to American journalists reporting on American issues. During his first American TV interview, in May 2014, Snowden said he had protected himself from Russian leverage by destroying the material he had been holding before landing in Moscow. ===Russia=== [[File:Edward Joseph Snowden - Arrival at Sheremetyevo International Airport 02.jpg|thumb|right|Ecuador embassy car at [[Sheremetyevo International Airport|Sheremetyevo Airport]] in Moscow on June 23, 2013]] On June 23, 2013, Snowden landed at Moscow's [[Sheremetyevo International Airport|Sheremetyevo Airport]].{{cite news |first=Sergei L. |last=Loiko |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jun/23/world/la-fg-wn-snowden-expected-in-moscow-20130623 |title=Snowden stopping in Moscow en route to Cuba, Russian says |work=Los Angeles Times |date=June 23, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} WikiLeaks said he was on a circuitous but safe route to asylum in [[Ecuador]].[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/edward-snowden-lands-in-moscow-likely-bound-for-ecuador/ Edward Snowden lands in Moscow, likely bound for Ecuador]. CBS News (June 23, 2013). Snowden had a seat reserved to continue to [[Cuba]][https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/28/us-usa-security-snowden-cuba-idUSBRE97R0JJ20130828 Fidel Castro labels libelous report Cuba blocked Snowden travel] Reuters August 28, 2013 but did not board that onward flight, saying in a January 2014 interview that he intended to transit through Russia but was stopped en route. He asserted "a planeload of reporters documented the seat I was supposed to be in" when he was ticketed for [[Havana]], but the U.S. cancelled his passport. He said the U.S. wanted him to stay in Moscow so "they could say, 'He's a Russian spy.'"[http://g1.globo.com/fantastico/noticia/2014/06/se-o-brasil-me-oferecer-asilo-aceito-diz-edward-snowden.html 'Se o Brasil me oferecer asilo, aceito', diz Edward Snowden] ''[[Rede Globo]]'' June 1, 2014 Greenwald's account differed on the point of Snowden being already ticketed. According to Greenwald, Snowden's passport was valid when he departed Hong Kong but was revoked during the hours he was in transit to Moscow, preventing him from obtaining a ticket to leave Russia. Greenwald said Snowden was thus forced to stay in Moscow and seek asylum.{{cite web |title=United States of Secrets |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/united-states-of-secrets/ |work=Frontline |publisher=PBS |accessdate=May 21, 2014}} According to one Russian report, Snowden planned to fly from Moscow through Havana to Latin America; however, Cuba told Moscow it would not allow the Aeroflot plane carrying Snowden to land.{{cite web |title=Snowden "asked Russian diplomats in Hong Kong for help" - Putin |url=http://rbth.asia/world/2013/09/06/snowden_asked_russian_diplomats_in_hong_kong_for_help_-_putin_48711.html |work=Asia Pacific |accessdate=May 29, 2014 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130907160506/http://rbth.asia/world/2013/09/06/snowden_asked_russian_diplomats_in_hong_kong_for_help_-_putin_48711.html |archivedate=September 7, 2013 |df=mdy}} Russian newspaper ''[[Kommersant]]'' reported that Cuba had a change of heart after receiving pressure from U.S. officials,{{cite web |title=Russian media report: How Snowden missed his flight to Cuba |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Global-News/2013/0826/Russian-media-report-How-Snowden-missed-his-flight-to-Cuba |work=Christian Science Monitor |date=August 26, 2013}} leaving him stuck in the transit zone because at the last minute Havana told officials in Moscow not to allow him on the flight.{{cite news |title=Snowden got stuck in Russia after Cuba blocked entry: newspaper |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/26/us-usa-security-snowden-idUSBRE97P05M20130826 |work=Reuters |accessdate=May 29, 2014 |date=August 26, 2013}} ''The Washington Post'' contrasted this version with what it called "widespread speculation" that Russia never intended to let Snowden proceed.[[Will Englund]] (August 26, 2013), [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/report-snowden-stayed-at-russian-consulate-while-in-hong-kong/2013/08/26/8237cf9a-0e39-11e3-a2b3-5e107edf9897_story.html Snowden stayed at Russian Consulate while in Hong Kong, report says] ''[[The Washington Post]]'' [[Fidel Castro]] called claims that Cuba would have blocked Snowden's entry a "lie" and a "libel." Describing Snowden's arrival in Moscow as a surprise and likening it to "an unwanted Christmas gift,"{{cite news |title=Путин признал: Сноуден – в Москве. И посоветовал США не "стричь поросенка" |url=http://newsru.com/world/25jun2013/kerry.html |agency=[[NEWSru]] |date=June 25, 2013}} Russian president Putin said that Snowden remained in the transit area of Sheremetyevo Airport, had committed no crime in Russia, was free to leave and should do so.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/25/us-usa-security-putin-idUSBRE95O0VE20130625 |title=Putin says Snowden at Russian airport, signals no extradition |date=June 25, 2013 |agency=Reuters}} Putin denied that Russia's intelligence agencies had worked or were working with Snowden. Following Snowden's arrival in Moscow, the White House expressed disappointment in Hong Kong's decision to allow him to leave.{{cite news |last1=Baker |first1=Peter |last2=Barry |first2=Ellen |date=June 23, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/24/world/asia/nsa-leaker-leaves-hong-kong-local-officials-say.html |title=N.S.A. 'Leaker Leaves Hong Kong, Local Officials Say' |work=[[The New York Times]]}}{{cite web |title=Daily Briefing by Press Secretary Jay Carney, 6/24/2013 |date=June 24, 2013 |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/06/24/daily-briefing-press-secretary-jay-carney-6242013 |publisher=[[The White House]]}} An anonymous U.S. official not authorized to discuss the matter told AP Snowden's passport had been revoked before he left Hong Kong, but that a senior official in a country or airline could order subordinates to overlook the withdrawn passport.{{cite news |title=AP Source: NSA leaker Snowden's passport revoked |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ap-source-nsa-leaker-snowdens-passport-revoked |work=Associated Press |accessdate=May 27, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626035443/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ap-source-nsa-leaker-snowdens-passport-revoked |archivedate=June 26, 2015 |deadurl=no}} U.S. [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[John Kerry]] said that Snowden's passport was cancelled "within two hours" of the charges against Snowden being made public[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/kerry-warns-russia-on-snowden-respect-the-relationship/ Kerry warns Russia on Snowden: "Respect the relationship"] ''[[CBS News]]'' 21 June 2013 which was Friday, June 21. In a July 1 statement, Snowden said, "Although I am convicted of nothing, [the U.S. government] has unilaterally revoked my passport, leaving me a stateless person. Without any judicial order, the administration now seeks to stop me exercising a basic right. A right that belongs to everybody. The right to seek asylum."[https://wikileaks.org/Statement-from-Edward-Snowden-in.html Statement from Edward Snowden in Moscow]. Wikileaks.org (July 1, 2013). Four countries offered Snowden permanent asylum: Ecuador, Nicaragua, Bolivia, and Venezuela.{{cite web |title=Did Edward Snowden just evade the US justice system? |url=http://www.msnbc.com/hardball/did-edward-snowden-just-evade-the-us-justice |work=MSNBC |accessdate=May 21, 2014}} No direct flights between Moscow and Venezuela, Bolivia or Nicaragua existed, however, and the U.S. pressured countries along his route to hand him over. Snowden said in July 2013 that he decided to bid for asylum in Russia because he felt there was no safe way to reach Latin America.{{cite web |last=Radia |first=Kirit |title=Edward Snowden Makes No-Leak Promise in Asylum Bid: Lawyer |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/edward-snowden-legal-apply-russian-asylum/story?id=19678502 |work=ABC |accessdate=May 29, 2014}} Snowden said he remained in Russia because "when we were talking about possibilities for asylum in Latin America, the United States forced down the Bolivian President's plane", citing the [[Evo Morales grounding incident|Morales plane incident]]. On the issue, he said "some governments in Western European and North American states have demonstrated a willingness to act outside the law, and this behavior persists today. This unlawful threat makes it impossible for me to travel to Latin America and enjoy the asylum granted there in accordance with our shared rights."{{cite news |last=Black |first=Phil |title=Snowden meets with rights groups, seeks temporary asylum in Russia |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/12/world/europe/russia-us-snowden/ |work=CNN |accessdate=May 29, 2014}} He said that he would travel from Russia if there was no interference from the U.S. government. Four months after Snowden received asylum in Russia, [[Julian Assange]] commented, "While Venezuela and Ecuador could protect him in the short term, over the long term there could be a change in government. In Russia, he's safe, he's well-regarded, and that is not likely to change. That was my advice to Snowden, that he would be physically safest in Russia." According to Snowden, "the CIA has a very powerful presence [in Latin America] and the governments and the security services there are relatively much less capable than, say, Russia.... they could have basically snatched me...."[http://www.newyorker.com/new-yorker-festival/live-stream-edward-snowden The Virtual Interview: Edward Snowden] at -50:23 ''[[The New Yorker]] October 11, 2014 In an October 2014 interview with ''[[The Nation]]'' magazine, Snowden reiterated that he had originally intended to travel to Latin America: "A lot of people are still unaware that I never intended to end up in Russia." According to Snowden, the U.S. government "waited until I departed Hong Kong to cancel my passport in order to trap me in Russia." Snowden added, "If they really wanted to capture me, they would've allowed me to travel to Latin America, because the CIA can operate with impunity down there. They did not want that; they chose to keep me in Russia."{{cite web |last1=Vanden Heuvel |first1=Katrina |last2=Cohen |first2=Stephen F. |title=Edward Snowden: A 'Nation' Interview |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/186129/snowden-exile-exclusive-interview |work=The Nation |date=October 28, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} ====Morales plane incident==== {{Main|Evo Morales grounding incident}} [[File:Grounding of Evo Morales presidential plane.svg|thumb|Spain, France, and Italy (red) denied Bolivian president [[Evo Morales]] permission to cross their airspace. Morales' plane landed in Austria (yellow).]] On July 1, 2013, president [[Evo Morales]] of [[Bolivia]], who had been attending a conference in Russia, suggested during an interview with [[Russia Today]] that he would consider a request by Snowden for asylum.{{cite news |url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/internacional/2013/07/01/606824/evo-morales-se-abre-a-ceder-asilo-a-edward-snowden-si-lo-solicita.html |title=Evo Morales se abre a ceder asilo a Edward Snowden si lo solicita |newspaper=[[El Mercurio]] |language=Spanish |date=July 1, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |agency=EFE |trans-title=Evo Morales prepared to give asylum to Edward Snowden if requested |location=Santiago |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6O7guwSjr?url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/internacional/2013/07/01/606824/evo-morales-se-abre-a-ceder-asilo-a-edward-snowden-si-lo-solicita.html |archivedate=March 16, 2014 |df=}} The following day, Morales' plane, en route to Bolivia, was rerouted to Austria and landed there, after France, Spain, and Italy denied access to their airspace. While the plane was parked in Vienna, the Spanish ambassador to Austria arrived with two embassy personnel and asked to search the plane but were denied permission by Morales himself.{{cite news |last=Fisher |first=Max |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/07/03/evo-morales-controversial-flight-over-europe-minute-by-heavily-disputed-minute/ |title=Evo Morales's controversial flight over Europe, minute by heavily disputed minute |work=The Washington Post |date=July 3, 2013}} U.S. officials had raised suspicions that Snowden may have been on board.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-23201767 |title=Spain 'told Edward Snowden was on Bolivia president's plane' |publisher=BBC News |date=July 5, 2013}} Morales blamed the U.S. for putting pressure on European countries, and said that the grounding of his plane was a violation of international law.[https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/07/05/south-american-leaders-back-morales/2490925/ Rerouted Morales plane has South American leaders irate]. ''USA Today''. (July 5, 2013). In April 2015, Bolivia's ambassador to Russia, [[María Luisa Ramos Urzagaste]], accused Julian Assange of putting Morales's life at risk by intentionally providing to the U.S. false rumors that Snowden was on Morales' plane. Assange responded that the plan "was not completely honest, but we did consider that the final result would have justified our actions. The result was caused by the United States' intervention. We can only regret what happened."{{cite news |url=http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Bolivia-Accuses-Assange-of-Putting-Evo-Morales-Life-at-Risk-20150413-0024.html |title=Bolivia Accuses Assange of Putting Evo Morales' Life at Risk |publisher=[[teleSUR]] |date=April 13, 2015}} ====Asylum applications==== Snowden applied for political asylum to 21 countries.{{cite web |title=Edward Snowden asylum: countries approached and their responses |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/02/edward-snowden-nsa-asylum-application-list-countries |work=The Guardian |accessdate=May 5, 2014}}{{cite news |url=https://www.siliconrepublic.com/enterprise/2015/06/05/edward-snowden-ive-applied-for-asylum-in-21-countries |title=Edward Snowden: I’ve applied for asylum in 21 countries |work=Silicon Republic |date=June 5, 2015 |first=Gordon |last=Hunt}} A statement attributed to him contended that the U.S. administration, and specifically Vice President [[Joe Biden]], had pressured the governments to refuse his asylum petitions. Biden had telephoned President [[Rafael Correa]] days prior to Snowden's remarks, asking the Ecuadorian leader not to grant Snowden asylum.{{cite news |last=Gladstone |first=Rick |date=July 1, 2013 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/02/world/europe/snowden-speaks-out-in-moscow-for-first-time.html |title=Snowden Is Said to Claim U.S. Is Blocking Asylum Bids |work=The New York Times}} Ecuador had initially offered Snowden a temporary travel document but later withdrew it,{{cite news |title=Ecuador cools on Edward Snowden asylum as Assange frustration grows |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/28/edward-snowden-ecuador-julian-assange |newspaper=The Guardian |date=June 28, 2013 |location=London |first1=Rory |last1=Carroll |first2=Amanda |last2=Holpuch}} and Correa later called the offer a mistake.{{cite news |title=Ecuador says it blundered over Snowden travel document |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/02/ecuador-rafael-correa-snowden-mistake |newspaper=The Guardian |date=July 3, 2013 |location=London |first=Rory |last=Carroll}} In a July 1 statement published by WikiLeaks, Snowden accused the U.S. government of "using citizenship as a weapon" and using what he described as "old, bad tools of political aggression." Citing Obama's promise to not allow "wheeling and dealing" over the case, Snowden commented, "This kind of deception from a world leader is not justice, and neither is the extralegal penalty of exile."[http://washington.cbslocal.com/2013/07/01/alleged-snowden-statement-obama-administration-using-citizenship-as-a-weapon/ Alleged Snowden Statement: Obama Administration 'Using Citizenship As A Weapon' « CBS DC]. Washington.cbslocal.com (July 1, 2013).
