'in talks' over Snowden |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-23468459 |publisher=BBC |date=July 26, 2013}} ==Criminal charges== On June 14, 2013, United States federal prosecutors filed a criminal complaint against Snowden, charging him with theft of government property and two counts of violating the [[Espionage Act of 1917]] through unauthorized communication of national defense information and willful communication of classified communications intelligence information to an unauthorized person.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-charges-snowden-with-espionage/2013/06/21/507497d8-dab1-11e2-a016-92547bf094cc_story.html |title=U.S. charges Snowden with espionage |date=June 21, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |first1=Peter |last1=Finn |first2=Sari |last2=Horwitz |work=The Washington Post}} Each of the three charges carries a maximum possible prison term of ten years. The charge was initially secret and was unsealed a week later. Snowden was asked in a January 2014 interview about returning to the U.S. to face the charges in court, as Obama had suggested a few days prior. Snowden explained why he rejected the request: "What he doesn't say are that the crimes that he's charged me with are crimes that don't allow me to make my case. They don't allow me to defend myself in an open court to the public and convince a jury that what I did was to their benefit. ... So it's, I would say, illustrative that the President would choose to say someone should face the music when he knows the music is a show trial."Transcript corrected from "to my benefit" to "to their benefit" per [http://vimeo.com/85736856 video at 29:20] Snowden's legal representative, [[Jesselyn Radack]], wrote that "the Espionage Act effectively hinders a person from defending himself before a jury in an open court." She said that the "arcane World War I law" was never meant to prosecute whistleblowers, but rather spies who sold secrets to enemies for profit.{{cite news |last=Radack |first=Jesselyn |title=Jesselyn Radack: Why Edward Snowden Wouldn't Get a Fair Trial |url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303595404579318884005698684 |work=WSJ |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=February 19, 2014 |date=January 22, 2014}} ==Asylum in Russia== {{Main|Edward Snowden asylum in Russia}} On June 23, 2013, Snowden landed at Moscow's [[Sheremetyevo International Airport|Sheremetyevo Airport]] aboard a commercial [[Aeroflot]] flight from [[Hong Kong]].{{cite news|first=Sergei L.|last=Loiko|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jun/23/world/la-fg-wn-snowden-expected-in-moscow-20130623|title=Snowden stopping in Moscow en route to Cuba, Russian says|work=Los Angeles Times|date=June 23, 2013|accessdate=April 11, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Makinen|first=Julie|date=June 23, 2013|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-hong-kong-snowden-20130623,0,2899790.story|title=Snowden leaves Hong Kong; final destination unclear|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}} On August 1, after 39 days in the transit section, he left the airport and was granted temporary [[Right of asylum|asylum]] in Russia for one year.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/08/01/us/nsa-snowden/index.html|title=Snowden out of airport, still in Moscow|publisher=CNN|date=August 2, 2013|accessdate=April 11, 2015}} A year later, his temporary asylum having expired, Snowden received a three-year residency permit allowing him to travel freely within Russia and to go abroad for up to three months. He was not granted permanent political asylum.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/nsa-snooping/edward-snowden-can-stay-russia-three-years-lawyer-says-n174776|title=Edward Snowden Can Stay in Russia for Three Years, Lawyer Says|publisher=NBC News|date=August 7, 2014|accessdate=August 7, 2014}} In January 2017, a spokesperson for the [[Russian foreign ministry]] wrote on [[Facebook]] that Snowden's asylum, which was due to expire in 2017, was extended by "a couple more years."{{Cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/russia-extends-snowden-asylum-couple-082503508.html|title=Russia Extends Snowden's Asylum By 'A Couple More Years'|access-date=2018-03-18|language=en-US}}{{Cite Because we did need to know how far this has gone."{{cite web |last=MacAskill |first=Ewen |title=Edward Snowden's NSA leaks 'an important service', says Al Gore |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/10/edward-snowden-nsa-leaks-important-service-al-gore |work=The Guardian |accessdate=June 11, 2014}} :*In December, President Obama nominated former [[United States Deputy Secretary of Defense|deputy defense secretary]] [[Ashton Carter]] to succeed outgoing [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] [[Chuck Hagel]]. Seven months before, Carter had said, "We had a cyber Pearl Harbor. His name was Edward Snowden." Carter charged that U.S. security officials "screwed up spectacularly in the case of Snowden. And this knucklehead had access to destructive power that was much more than any individual person should have access to."{{cite news |last=Whitlock |first=Craig |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/ash-carter-passed-over-before-gets-picked-by-obama-to-lead-pentagon/2014/12/05/33a2429a-7c95-11e4-9a27-6fdbc612bff8_story.html |title=Ashton Carter, passed over before, gets picked by Obama to be defense secretary |work=The Washington Post |date=December 5, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} ====Debate==== In the U.S., Snowden's actions precipitated an intense debate on privacy and warrantless domestic surveillance.[https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/columnist/rieder/2013/06/12/rem-rieder-surveillance/2415753/ Rieder: Snowden's NSA bombshell sparks debate]. ''USA Today''. (June 12, 2013).[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/spy-chief-lauds-snowden-sparked-debate/story-e6frg6so-1226718193276 Spy chief lauds Snowden-sparked debate .]. The Australian (August 29, 2013). President Obama was initially dismissive of Snowden, saying "I'm not going to be scrambling jets to get a 29-year-old hacker."{{cite news |last=Pecquet |first=Julian |title=US won't 'scramble jets' to capture 'hacker' Snowden, Obama says |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/global-affairs/africa/308117-obama-wont-scramble-jets-to-capture-hacker-snowden |newspaper=The Hill |date=June 27, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-23084166 |title=Obama refuses to barter for Edward Snowden |publisher=BBC News |date=June 27, 2013 |accessdate=January 20, 2014}}{{cite news |title=Obama downplays Snowden case, says US not 'scrambling jets' to get 'hacker' |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/06/27/obama-downplays-snowden-case-says-us-not-scrambling-jets-to-get-hacker/ |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=June 27, 2013}} In August 2013, Obama rejected the suggestion that Snowden was a patriot,{{cite news |last=Wolf |first=Z. Byron |title=Fact-checking Obama's claims about Snowden |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/08/12/politics/obama-snowden-whistleblower |publisher=CNN |date=August 13, 2013}} and in November said that "the benefit of the debate he generated was not worth the damage done, because there was another way of doing it."David Remnick (January 27, 2014) [http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2014/01/27/140127fa_fact_remnick Going the Distance: On and off the road with Barack Obama] ''[[The New Yorker]]'' In June 2013, U.S. Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] of Vermont wrote on his blog, "Love him or hate him, we all owe Snowden our thanks for forcing upon the nation an important debate. But the debate shouldn't be about him. It should be about the gnawing questions his actions raised from the shadows."{{cite web |url=http://www.sanders.senate.gov/newsroom/must-read/why-i-dont-care-about-edward-snowden |title=Why I Don't Care About Edward Snowden |date=June 12, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |work=Sen. Bernie Sanders}} Snowden said in December 2013 that he was "inspired by the global debate" ignited by the leaks and that NSA's "culture of indiscriminate global espionage ... is collapsing."{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/report-snowden-would-help-brazil-if-given-asylum/2013/12/17/6ca6b7f8-66f0-11e3-997b-9213b17dac97_story.html |title=Snowden bides for political asylum in Brazil - The Washington Post |date=December 17, 2013 |publisher= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217122329/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/report-snowden-would-help-brazil-if-given-asylum/2013/12/17/6ca6b7f8-66f0-11e3-997b-9213b17dac97_story.html |archivedate=December 17, 2013 |df=mdy-all}} At the end of 2013, however, ''The Washington Post'' noted that the public debate and its offshoots had produced no meaningful change in policy, with the status quo continuing. In 2016, on ''The Axe Files'' [[Political podcast|podcast]], former U.S. Attorney General [[Eric Holder]] said that Snowden "performed a public service by raising the debate that we engaged in and by the changes that we made." Holder nevertheless said that Snowden's actions were inappropriate and illegal.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/30/politics/axe-files-axelrod-eric-holder/index.html |title=Eric Holder says Edward Snowden performed a 'public service' |last=Jaffe |first=Matthew |date=May 30, 2016 |website=cnn.com |publisher=[[Cable News Network (CNN)]]| access-date = May 31, 2016}} In September 2016, the bipartisan [[U.S. House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence]] completed a review of the Snowden disclosures and said that the federal government would have to spend millions of dollars responding to the fallout from Snowden's disclosures.{{cite web |url=http://intelligence.house.gov/uploadedfiles/hpsci_snowden_review_-_unclass_summary_-_final.pdf |title=Executive Summary of Review of the Unauthorized Disclosures of Former National Security Agency Contractor Edward Snowden |publisher=[[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence]] |date=September 15, 2016}} The report also said that "the public narrative popularized by Snowden and his allies is rife with falsehoods, exaggerations, and crucial omissions."{{cite news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Passcode/2016/0916/Hollywood-and-Washington-battle-to-define-Snowden-s-image |title=Hollywood and Washington battle to define Snowden's image |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=September 16, 2016}} The report was denounced by ''Washington Post'' reporter [[Barton Gellman]], who called it "aggressively dishonest" and "contemptuous of fact."[[Barton Gellman]] (September 16, 2016), [https://tcf.org/content/commentary/house-intelligence-committees-terrible-horrible-bad-snowden-report/ The House Intelligence Committee’s Terrible, Horrible, Very Bad Snowden Report] ''[[The Century Foundation]]'' ====Presidential panel==== In August 2013, President Obama said that he had called for a review of U.S. surveillance activities before Snowden had begun revealing details of the NSA's operations, and announced that he was directing DNI James Clapper "to establish a review group on intelligence and communications technologies."{{cite news |last=MacAskill |first=Ewen |title=White House insists James Clapper will not lead NSA surveillance review |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/13/white-house-james-clapper-nsa-surveillance-review |newspaper=The Guardian |date=August 13, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}}{{cite news |last=Farivar |first=Cyrus |title=Obama's 'outside experts' surveillance review panel has deep ties to gov't |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/08/obamas-reported-outside-experts-surveillance-review-panel-has-deep-ties-to-govt/ |newspaper=Ars Technica |date=August 23, 2013}} In December, the task force issued 46 recommendations that, if adopted, would subject the NSA to additional scrutiny by the courts, Congress, and the president, and would strip the NSA of the authority to infiltrate American computer systems using [[backdoor (computing)|backdoors]] in hardware or software.{{cite news |last=Sanger |first=David E. |title=Obama panel recommends new limits on N.S.A. spying |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/19/us/politics/report-on-nsa-surveillance-tactics.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=December 18, 2013 |author2=Savage, Charlie}} Panel member [[Geoffrey R. Stone]] said there was no evidence that the bulk collection of phone data had stopped any [[terror attacks]].{{cite web |url=http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/12/19/21975158-nsa-program-stopped-no-terror-attacks-says-white-house-panel-member |title=NSA program stopped no terror attacks, says White House panel member – Investigations |publisher=NBC News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131221133023/http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/12/19/21975158-nsa-program-stopped-no-terror-attacks-says-white-house-panel-member |archivedate=December 21, 2013}} ====Court rulings==== On June 6, 2013, in the wake of Snowden's leaks, conservative public interest lawyer and [[Judicial Watch]] founder [[Larry Klayman]] filed a lawsuit claiming that the federal government had unlawfully collected metadata for his telephone calls and was harassing him. In ''[[Klayman v. Obama]]'', Judge [[Richard J. Leon]] referred to the NSA's "almost-Orwellian technology" and ruled the bulk telephony metadata program to be probably unconstitutional.{{cite news |last=Nakashima |first=Ellen |title=Judge: NSA's collecting of phone records is probably unconstitutional |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/judge-nsas-collecting-of-phone-records-is-likely-unconstitutional/2013/12/16/6e098eda-6688-11e3-a0b9-249bbb34602c_story.html |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=March 13, 2014 |date=December 17, 2013}} Snowden later described Judge Leon's decision as vindication.{{cite web |last=Byers |first=Dylan |title=Edward Snowden looms over Pulitzer Prizes |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/03/edward-snowden-pulitzer-prize-washington-post-guardian-nsa-104608.html |work=Politico |accessdate=March 13, 2014}} On June 11, the ACLU filed a lawsuit against James Clapper, Director of National Intelligence, alleging that the NSA's phone records program was unconstitutional. In December 2013, ten days after Judge Leon's ruling, Judge [[William H. Pauley III]] came to the opposite conclusion. In ''[[ACLU v. Clapper]]'', although acknowledging that privacy concerns are not trivial, Pauley found that the potential benefits of surveillance outweigh these considerations and ruled that the NSA's collection of phone data is legal.{{cite news |last=Liptak |first=Adam |title=Judge Upholds NSA's Bulk Collection of Data on Calls |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/28/us/nsa-phone-surveillance-is-lawful-federal-judge-rules.html |work=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=March 13, 2014 |date=December 27, 2013}} Gary Schmitt, former staff director of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, wrote that "The two decisions have generated public confusion over the constitutionality of the NSA's data collection program—a kind of judicial 'he-said, she-said' standoff."{{cite web |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/articles/tale-two-judges_773264.html |title=A Tale of Two Judges |work=The Weekly Standard |date=January 13, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} On May 7, 2015, in the case of ''ACLU v. Clapper'', the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] said that [[Section 215]] of the [[Patriot Act]] did not authorize the NSA to collect Americans' calling records in bulk, as exposed by Snowden in 2013. The decision voided U.S. District Judge William Pauley's December 2013 finding that the NSA program was lawful, and remanded the case to him for further review. The appeals court did not rule on the constitutionality of the bulk surveillance, and declined to enjoin the program, noting the pending expiration of relevant parts of the Patriot Act. Circuit Judge [[Gerard E. Lynch]] wrote that, given the national security interests at stake, it was prudent to give Congress an opportunity to debate and decide the matter.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/07/usa-security-nsa-idUSL1N0XY1OK20150507 |title=U.S. NSA's phone spying program ruled illegal by appeals court |agency=Reuters |date=May 7, 2015 |accessdate=May 7, 2015}} ====USA Freedom Act==== On June 2, 2015, the U.S. Senate passed, and President Obama signed, the [[USA Freedom Act]] which restored in modified form several provisions of the [[Patriot Act]] that had expired the day before, while for the first time imposing some limits on the bulk collection of telecommunication data on U.S. citizens by American intelligence agencies. The new restrictions were widely seen as stemming from Snowden's revelations.{{cite news |last1=Diamond |first1=Jeremy |title=NSA surveillance bill passes after weeks-long showdown |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/02/politics/senate-usa-freedom-act-vote-patriot-act-nsa/ |website=CNN |accessdate=June 12, 2015 |quote="The bill's passage is the culmination of efforts to reform the NSA that blossomed out of NSA leaker Edward Snowden's 2013 revelations."}}{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/06/02/411534447/senateis-poised-to-vote-on-house-approved-usa-freedom-act |title=Senate Approves USA Freedom Act, After Amendments Fail : The Two-Way : NPR |date=June 2, 2015 |work=NPR.org}} ===Europe=== [[Hans-Georg Maaßen]], head of the [[Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution]], Germany's domestic security agency, said that Snowden could have been working for the Russian government.{{cite web |url=http://diepresse.com/home/politik/aussenpolitik/5012057/Deutscher-Verfassungsschutz_Snowden-womoglich-russischer-Spion |title=German Constitutional Protection: Snowden could be Russian spy (German) |date=June 10, 2016 |accessdate=July 19, 2016}} Snowden has rejected this insinuation.{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/edward-snowden-interview-there-is-still-hope-a-1166752.html |title=Interview with Edward Snowden: 'There Is Still Hope - Even for Me' |date=September 12, 2017 |first1=Martin |last1=Knobbe |first2=Jörg |last2=Schindler |newspaper=[[Spiegel Online]] |page=2}} ===International community=== [[File:DigiGes PRISM Yes we scan - Demo am Checkpoint Charlie June 2013.jpg|thumb|right|230px|Demonstration at [[Checkpoint Charlie]] in Berlin during Barack Obama's visit, June 18, 2013]] Crediting the Snowden leaks, the [[United Nations General Assembly]] unanimously adopted Resolution 68/167 in December 2013. The non-binding resolution denounced unwarranted digital surveillance and included a symbolic declaration of the right of all individuals to online privacy.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Carol J. |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-un-surveillance-privacy-rights-edward-snowden-20131219,0,1981619.story#axzz2nzV4bWSn |title=U.N. votes to protect online privacy; Edward Snowden leaks credited |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=December 19, 2013 |accessdate=April 26, 2017}}[http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2013/11/26/un-general-assembly-advances-digital-privacy-resolution-after-reports-us/ UN advances digital privacy resolution after reports of US eavesdropping]. Fox News (November 26, 2013).{{cite web |title=United Nations Resolution 68/167M |url=https://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/RES/68/167 |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=April 26, 2017}} Support for Snowden came from Latin American leaders including the Argentinian President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]], Brazilian President [[Dilma Rousseff]], Ecuadorian President [[Rafael Correa]], Bolivian President [[Evo Morales]], Venezuelan President [[Nicolás Maduro]], and Nicaraguan President [[Daniel Ortega]]."[http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/190809/latin-american-leaders-have-expressed-support-for-whistleblower Latin American leaders have expressed support for whistleblower]". ''[[Buenos Aires Herald]]''. June 4, 2015."[http://edition.cnn.com/2013/06/28/world/americas/ecuador-snowden/ Ecuador's president to U.S.: Don't threaten us on Snowden case]". CNN. June 28, 2013 In an official report published in October 2015, the [[United Nations special rapporteur]] for the promotion and protection of the right to freedom of speech, Professor [[David Kaye (law professor)|David Kaye]], criticized the U.S. government's harsh treatment of, and bringing criminal charges against, whistleblowers, including Edward Snowden. The report found that Snowden's revelations were important for people everywhere and made "a deep and lasting impact on law, policy and politics."{{cite web |last1=Froomkin |first1=Dan |title=U.N. Report Calls on Governments to Protect Whistleblowers Like Snowden, Not Prosecute Them |url=https://theintercept.com/2015/10/23/u-n-report-calls-on-governments-to-protect-whistleblowers-like-snowden-not-prosecute-them/ |website=[[The Intercept]] |date=October 23, 2015}}{{cite web |title=Report of the Special Rapporteur to the General Assembly on the Protection of Sources and Whistleblowers |url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/Issues/FreedomOpinion/Pages/ProtectionOfSources.aspx |publisher=[[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]]}} The [[European Parliament]] invited Snowden to make a pre-recorded video appearance to aid their NSA investigation.{{cite news |agency=Associated Press (Brussels) |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/09/edward-snowden-invited-testify-video-european-parliament-nsa-surveillance? |title=European parliament invites Edward Snowden to testify via video |work=The Guardian |date=January 9, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}}{{cite web |last=Peter |first=Gregor |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/edward-snowden-to-make-video-appearance-to-european-parliament-a-938725.html |title=Edward Snowden to Make Video Appearance to European Parliament |work=Der Spiegel |date=December 12, 2013}} Snowden gave written testimony in which he said that he was seeking asylum in the EU, but that he was told by European Parliamentarians that the U.S. would not allow EU partners to make such an offer.{{cite web |last=Peralta |first=Eyder |title=Edward Snowden Tells EU Parliament He Wants Asylum In Europe |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2014/03/07/287459845/edward-snowden-tells-eu-parliament-he-wants-asylum-in-europe |publisher=NPR |date=March 7, 2014}} He told the Parliament that the NSA was working with the security agencies of EU states to "get access to as much data of EU citizens as possible."{{cite web |last=Essers |first=Loek |title=NSA created 'European bazaar' to spy on EU citizens, Snowden tells European Parliament |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/2105840/nsa-created-european-bazaar-to-spy-on-eu-citizens-snowden-tells-european-parliament.html |work=PSWorld |accessdate=March 10, 2014}} The NSA's Foreign Affairs Division, he claimed, lobbies the EU and other countries to change their laws, allowing for "everyone in the country" to be spied on legally.{{cite web |last=Doctorow |first=Cory |title=Edward Snowden's magnificent testimony to the EU |url=http://boingboing.net/2014/03/07/edward-snowdens-magnificent.html |work=BoingBoing |accessdate=March 10, 2014}} In July 2014, [[Navi Pillay]], [[United Nations|UN]] [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]], told a news conference in Geneva that the U.S. should abandon its efforts to prosecute Snowden, since his leaks were in the public interest.{{cite news |title=U.N.'s Pillay suggests Snowden should not face trial |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/07/16/us-usa-security-un-idUSKBN0FL1PB20140716 |agency=Reuters |first1=Stephanie |last1=Nebehay |first2=Tom |last2=Miles |date=July 16, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}} ===Public opinion polls=== {{Main|Commentary on Edward Snowden's disclosure}} Surveys conducted by news outlets and professional polling organizations found that American public opinion was divided on Snowden's disclosures, and that those polled in Canada and Europe were more supportive of Snowden than respondents in the U.S. ===Recognition=== {{Main|Awards received by Edward Snowden}} For his global surveillance disclosures, Snowden has been honored by publications and organizations based in Europe and the United States. He was voted as ''[[The Guardian]]''{{'}}s person of the year 2013, garnering four times the number of votes as any other candidate.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/09/edward-snowden-voted-guardian-person-of-year-2013 Edward Snowden voted Guardian person of the year 2013] The Guardian December 9, 2013 ===Teleconference speaking engagements=== [[File:Edward Snowden's Surprise Appearance at TED.jpg|thumb|right|Speaking via telepresence robot, Snowden addresses the TED conference from Russia.]] In March 2014, Snowden spoke at the [[South by Southwest]] (SXSW) Interactive technology conference in [[Austin, Texas]], in front of 3,500 attendees. He participated by teleconference carried over multiple routers running the [[Google Hangouts]] platform. On-stage moderators were [[Christopher Soghoian]] and Snowden's legal counsel Wizner, both from the ACLU.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/03/10/tech/web/edward-snowden-sxsw/ |title=Edward Snowden speaks at SXSW, calls for public oversight of U.S. spy programs |last1=Griggs |first1=Brandon |last2=Gross |first2=Doug |date=March 10, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |work=CNN Tech}} Snowden said that the NSA was "setting fire to the future of the internet," and that the SXSW audience was "the firefighters."{{cite news |url=http://articles.philly.com/2014-03-12/news/48122662_1_edward-snowden-nsa-leaker-snowden-southwest-interactive |title=NSA leaker Snowden is the rock star of SXSW Interactive |last=DeLuca |first=Dan |date=March 12, 2014 |work=The Inquirer |publisher=Philly.com}}{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-03/10/edward-snowden-sxsw |title=Snowden: the NSA is 'setting fire to the future of the internet' |last=Clark |first=Liat |date=March 10, 2014 |work=Wired |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505113952/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-03/10/edward-snowden-sxsw |archivedate=May 5, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Edward-Snowden-pushes-Web-privacy-at-South-by-5305080.php |title=Edward Snowden pushes Web privacy at South by Southwest |last=Garling |first=Caleb |date=March 11, 2014 |work=San Francisco Chronicle}} Attendees could use Twitter to send questions to Snowden, who answered one by saying that information gathered by corporations was much less dangerous than that gathered by a government agency, because "governments have the power to deprive you of your rights." Representative [[Mike Pompeo]] (R-KS) of the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|House Intelligence Committee]], and later [[Director of the Central Intelligence Agency|director of the CIA]], had tried unsuccessfully to get the SXSW management to cancel Snowden's appearance; instead, SXSW director Hugh Forrest said that the NSA was welcome to respond to Snowden at the 2015 conference. Later that month, Snowden appeared by teleconference at the [[TED (conference)|TED]] conference in [[Vancouver]], British Columbia. Represented on stage by a robot with a video screen, video camera, microphones and speakers, Snowden conversed with TED curator [[Chris Anderson (entrepreneur)|Chris Anderson]], and told the attendees that online businesses should act quickly to encrypt their websites. He described the NSA's PRISM program as the U.S. government using businesses to collect data for them, and that the NSA "intentionally misleads corporate partners" using, as an example, the [[Bullrun (decryption program)|Bullrun decryption program]] to create backdoor access.{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-03/18/snowden-ted |title=Snowden: Big revelations to come, reporting them is not a crime |last=Rowan |first=David |date=March 18, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |work=Wired}} Snowden said he would gladly return to the U.S. if given [[Immunity from prosecution (international law)|immunity from prosecution]], but that he was more concerned about alerting the public about abuses of government authority. Anderson invited Internet pioneer [[Tim Berners-Lee]] on stage to converse with Snowden, who said that he would support Berners-Lee's concept of an "internet Magna Carta" to "encode our values in the structure of the internet."{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/business/2014/03/ed-snowden-meets-father-web-stage-ted/ |title=Ed Snowden Meets the Father of the World Wide Web |last=Wohlsen |first=Marcus |work=Wired |date=March 18, 2014}} On September 15, 2014, Snowden appeared via remote video link, along with Julian Assange, on [[Kim Dotcom|Kim Dotcom's]] ''Moment of Truth'' town hall meeting held in [[Auckland]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2014/sep/15/kim-dotcom-accused-nz-government-of-mass-spying-live |title=Kim Dotcom accuses New Zealand government of mass spying – live updates |first1=Michael |last1=Safi |first2=Hannah Jane |last2=Parkinson |date=September 15, 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |publisher=The Guardian}} He made a similar video link appearance on February 2, 2015, along with Greenwald, as the keynote speaker at the World Affairs Conference at [[Upper Canada College]] in [[Toronto]].{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/edward-snowden-tells-students-mass-data-collection-can-hamper-attempts-to-foil-attacks-1.2940798 |title=Edward Snowden tells students mass data collection can hamper attempts to foil attacks |date=February 2, 2015 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=February 21, 2015}} In March 2015, while speaking at the [[International Film Festival and Forum on Human Rights|FIFDH]] (international human rights film festival) he made a public appeal for [[Switzerland]] to grant him asylum, saying he would like to return to live in Geneva, where he once worked undercover for the Central Intelligence Agency.{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/06/edward-snowden-switzerland-asylum_n_6816302.html |title=Edward Snowden Wants Switzerland To Grant Him Asylum |work=The Huffington Post |first=Stephanie |last=Nebehay |date=March 6, 2015 |accessdate=June 11, 2015}} On November 10, 2015, Snowden appeared at the [[Newseum]], via remote video link, for [[PEN American Center|PEN American Center's]] "Secret Sources: Whistleblowers, National Security and Free Expression," event.{{cite web |url=http://www.pen.org/event/2015/10/22/secret-sources-whistleblowers-national-security-and-free-expression |title=Secret Sources: Whistleblowers, National Security, and Free Expression |date=November 10, 2015 |accessdate=November 24, 2015 |website=PEN America |publisher=PEN America |last= |first=}} In 2015, Snowden earned over $200,000 from digital speaking engagements in the U.S.{{Cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/edward-snowden-making-most-digital-000000490.html |title=In exile, Edward Snowden rakes in speaking fees while hoping for a pardon |publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] |date=August 11, 2016 |first1=Michael |last1=Isikoff |first2=Michael B. |last2=Kelley}} On March 19, 2016, Snowden delivered the opening keynote address of the [[LibrePlanet]] conference, a meeting of international [[free software]] activists and developers presented by the [[Free Software Foundation]]. The conference was held at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] and was the first such time Snowden spoke via teleconference using a full free software stack, end-to-end.{{technical statement|date=June 2016}}{{cite web |author1=Snowden, Edward |author2=Daniel Kahn Gillmor |title=Libreplanet 2016: The Last Lighthouse: Free Software In Dark Times |url=https://media.libreplanet.org/u/libreplanet/m/libreplanet-2016-the-last-lighthouse-3d51/ |website=media.libreplanet.org |publisher=Free Software Foundation |accessdate=June 2, 2016 |format=video, [[WebM]]}}{{cite web |author1=Nicholson, Deb |title=LibrePlanet begins with Snowden, ends with DRM protest |url=https://opensource.com/life/16/3/libreplanet-2016 |website=opensource.com |accessdate=June 2, 2016 |date=March 29, 2016}}{{cite web |author1=Gold, Jon |title=Edward Snowden: Privacy can't depend on corporations standing up to the government |url=http://www.networkworld.com/article/3046135/security/edward-snowden-privacy-cant-depend-on-corporations-standing-up-to-the-government.html |website=networkworld.com |accessdate=June 2, 2016 |date=March 19, 2016}}{{cite web |author1=Popa, Bogdan |title=Snowden Used Free Software Because He Was Afraid of Backdoors in Microsoft Apps |url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/snowden-used-free-software-because-he-was-afraid-of-backdoors-in-microsoft-apps-502039.shtml |publisher=''SoftPedia'' News |accessdate=June 2, 2016 |date=March 22, 2016 |quote=NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden attended the Free Software Foundation LibrePlanet 2016 conference remotely from Russia to discuss the advantages of free applications, explaining that he couldn’t trust Microsoft software when revealing government's surveillance programs in 2013.}} On July 21, 2016, Snowden and hardware hacker [[Bunnie Huang]], in a talk at [[MIT Media Lab]]'s Forbidden Research event, published research for a smartphone case, the so-called ''Introspection Engine'', that would monitor signals received and sent by that phone to provide an alert to the user if their phone is [[Cellphone surveillance|transmitting or receiving information when it shouldn't be]] (for example when it's turned off or in airplane mode), a feature described by Snowden to be useful for journalists or activists operating under hostile governments that would otherwise track their activities through their phones.{{Cite journal |url=https://www.tjoe.org/pub/direct-radio-introspection |title=Against the Law: Countering Lawful Abuses of Digital Surveillance |last=Huang |first=Andrew (bunnie) |last2=Snowden |first2=Edward surveillance activity |last=Palazzo |first=Chiara |date= |website= |publisher=The Telegraph|access-date=August 7, 2016}} ===The "Snowden Effect"=== {{Main|Snowden effect}} In July 2013, media critic [[Jay Rosen]] defined The Snowden Effect as "Direct and indirect gains in public knowledge from the cascade of events and further reporting that followed Edward Snowden's leaks of classified information about the surveillance state in the U.S."{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Jay|title=The Snowden Effect: definition and examples|url=http://pressthink.org/2013/07/the-snowden-effect-definition-and-examples/|work=Jay Rosen's PressThink|accessdate=February 18, 2015}} In December 2013, ''[[The Nation]]'' wrote that Snowden had sparked an overdue debate about national security and individual privacy.{{cite web|last=Alterman|first=Eric|title=What the Press Should Learn From the 'Snowden Effect'|url=http://www.thenation.com/blog/177686/what-press-should-learn-snowden-effect#|work=The Nation|accessdate=March 2, 2014}} In ''[[Forbes]]'', the effect was seen to have nearly united the U.S. Congress in opposition to the massive [[post-9/11]] domestic intelligence gathering system.{{cite news|last=Watson|first=Tom|title=The Snowden Effect Hits Congress: Will Effective Crowdsourced Lobbying Follow?|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomwatson/2013/07/18/the-snowden-effect-hits-congress-will-effective-crowdsourced-lobbying-follow/|work=Forbes|accessdate=March 2, 2014}} In its Spring 2014 Global Attitudes Survey, the [[Pew Research Center]] found that Snowden's disclosures had tarnished the image of the United States, especially in Europe and Latin America.{{Cite journal|url=http://www.pewglobal.org/2014/07/14/global-opposition-to-u-s-surveillance-and-drones-but-limited-harm-to-americas-image/|title=Global Opposition to U.S. Surveillance and Drones, but Limited Harm to America's Image|publisher=Pew Research Center|date=July 14, 2014}} ==Jewel v. {{Infobox NFL player | name = Emmett "Red Fox" McLemore | image = | caption = | birth_date = September 12, 1899 | birth_place = [[Lyons, Oklahoma]], United States | death_date = {{death_date and age|1973|05|19|1899|09|12}} | death_place = | height_ft = 5 | height_in = 8 | weight_lbs = 165 | position = [[End (American football)|End]] / [[Quarterback]] | college = [[Haskell Indian Nations University|Haskell Indian]], [[Pittsburg State University|Pittsburg State]] | number = 11, 30, 4 | pfr = McLeEm20 | teams = * [[Oorang Indians]] (1923) * [[Kansas City (NFL)|Kansas City Blues]] (1924) }} '''Emmett "Red Fox" McLemore''' (September 12, 1899 – May 19, 1973)<ref name="Necrology">{{cite web|title=1979 - 1970 Pro Football Necrology List |work=Pro Football Deaths 1973 |publisher=Oldest Living Pro Football Players |year=2012 |url=http://www.oldestlivingprofootball.com/19791970necrology.htm |accessdate=2012-05-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151010162550/http://www.oldestlivingprofootball.com/19791970necrology.htm |archivedate=2015-10-10 |df= }}</ref> was a professional [[American football|football]] player who played in the [[National Football League]] during the [[1923 NFL season|1923 season]]. That season, he joined the NFL's [[Oorang Indians]]. The Indians were a team based in [[LaRue, Ohio]], composed only of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]], and coached by [[Jim Thorpe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.profootballresearchers.org/Coffin_Corner/03-01-057.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127050226/http://profootballresearchers.org/Coffin_Corner/03-01-057.pdf |archivedate=2010-11-27 |df= }}</ref> Emmett was a [[Cherokee]].
On December 2, 1923, McLemore recorded a [[touchdown]] to [[Arrowhead (American football)|Arrowhead]] and made a [[Field goal (football)|field goal]] after a [[Joe Guyon]] [[interception]]. However, he missed two [[extra point]] kicks in a 22-19 loss to the [[Chicago Cardinals]]. During that same game a McLemore punt hit a Cardinals' player and was soon picked up by [[Ted Buffalo]] for a score. A week later on December 7, McLemore caught two passes from Guyon for touchdowns in a 19-0 victory over the [[Louisville Brecks]].
He spent the [[1924 NFL season|1924 season]] playing in 4 NFL games with the [[Kansas City (NFL)|Kansas City Blues]].
==References== *{{cite book | title=Jim Thorpe and the Oorang Indians: The N.F.L.'s Most Colorful Franchise| first=Robert L. | last=Whitman| oclc=717439558 | publisher=Marion County Historical Society | year=1984 |location=[Mount Gilead, OH]}} *[http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~maxymuk/home/ongoing/oorang.html Uniform Numbers of the NFL]

[[File:Magazine cover - Unknown no. 1 (1939-03).jpg|thumb|Russell's classic "[[Sinister Barrier]]" was the cover story for Unknown No. 1 (1939-03)|upright]] '''Eric Frank Russell''' (January 6, 1905 – February 28, 1978) was a [[British people|British]] [[author]] best known for his [[science fiction]] novels and short stories. Much of his work was first published in the United States, in [[John W. Campbell]]'s ''[[Astounding Science Fiction]]'' and other [[pulp magazine]]s. Russell also wrote [[horror fiction]] for ''[[Weird Tales]]'' and non-fiction articles on [[Charles Fort|Fortean]] topics. Up to 1955 several of his stories were published under [[pseudonym]]s, at least Duncan H. Munro and Niall(e) Wilde. == Biography == Russell was born in [[1905 in science fiction|1905]] near [[Sandhurst, Berkshire|Sandhurst]] in [[Berkshire]], where his father was an instructor at the [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst|Royal Military College]].{{cite web|title=Handlist of the Eric Frank Russell Collection 1937–1984 |url=http://www.archiveshub.ac.uk/news/0501efr.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121222192434/http://www.archiveshub.ac.uk/news/0501efr.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-12-22 }}{{cite book |last=Ingham |first=John L. |title=Into Your Tent: The Life, Work and Family Background of Eric Frank Russell |year=2010 |publisher= Plantech (U.K.) |isbn=978-0-9564576-0-8 }} Russell became a fan of science fiction and in 1934, while living near [[Liverpool]], he saw a letter in ''[[Amazing Stories]]'' from Leslie J. Johnson, another reader from the same area.{{cite book |last=Ashley |first=Michael |authorlink=Mike Ashley (writer) |title=The History of the Science Fiction Magazine, Volume 2 |year=1975 |publisher= Henry Regnery Company |isbn=0-8092-8002-7}} Russell met up with Johnson, who encouraged him to embark on a writing career. Together, the two men wrote a [[novella]], "Seeker of Tomorrow", that was published by [[F. Orlin Tremaine]] in the July 1937 number of ''Astounding Stories''.{{efn|Two novelettes by Russell alone preceded "Seeker for Tomorrow", in the February and April numbers of the monthly, and a shortstory followed in December, the third issue after Campbell succeeded Tremaine as editor. One more of his stories was published that year, by Walter H. Gillings in ''[[Tales of Wonder (magazine)|Tales of Wonder]]'' #1, the first issue of Britain's first professional SF magazine (1937, no month).
  Johnson had not yet published any speculative fiction. He and Russell also collaborated on one story published decades later, "Eternal Rediffusion" (''Weird Tales'', September 1973).}} Both Russell and Johnson became members of the [[British Interplanetary Society]]. Russell's first novel was ''Sinister Barrier'', cover story for the inaugural, May 1939 issue of ''[[Unknown (magazine)|Unknown]]''—''Astounding''{{-'}}s sister magazine devoted to [[fantasy]]. It is explicitly a Fortean tale, based on [[Charles Fort]]'s famous speculation "I think we're property", Russell explains in the foreword. An often-repeated legend has it that Campbell, on receiving the manuscript for ''Sinister Barrier'', created ''[[Unknown (magazine)|Unknown]]'' primarily as a vehicle for the short novel (pp. 9–94). There is no real evidence for it, despite a statement to that effect in the first volume of [[Isaac Asimov]]'s autobiography, ''In Memory Yet Green''. His second novel, ''Dreadful Sanctuary'' (serialized in ''Astounding'' during 1948) is an early example of [[conspiracy fiction]], in which a [[Paranoia|paranoid]] [[delusion]] of global proportions is perpetuated by a small but powerful [[secret society]].{{cite web |last=Langford |first=David | authorlink=David Langford | title = SF Books of the Damned | work = ''Originally published in ''Fortean Times | year =1996 | url = http://www.ansible.co.uk/writing/damned.html }} There are two different and mutually incompatible accounts of Russell's military service during [[World War II]]. The official, well-documented version is that he served with the [[Royal Air Force]], with whom he saw active service in Europe as a member of a Mobile Signals Unit. However, in the introduction to the 1986 [[Del Rey Books]] edition of Russell's novel ''Wasp'', [[Jack L. Chalker]] states that Russell was too old for active service, and instead worked for Military Intelligence in London, where he "spent the war dreaming up nasty tricks to play against the Germans and Japanese", including [[Operation Mincemeat]]. Russell's biographer John L. Ingham states however that "there is nothing, absolutely nothing, in his R.A.F. record to show that he was anything more than a wireless mechanic and radio operator". Russell took up writing full-time in the late 1940s. He became an active member of British [[science fiction fandom]] and the British representative of the [[Fortean Society]]. He won the first annual [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story]] in 1955 recognizing his humorous "[[Allamagoosa]]" as the year's best science fiction. The 1962 novel ''[[The Great Explosion]]'' won a [[Prometheus Hall of Fame Award]] in 1985 — the third naming of two works to the [[libertarian science fiction]] hall of fame. The 1957 novel ''Wasp'' has been a finalist for the honor, which is now limited to one work per year. The [[EMP Museum#Science Fiction Hall of Fame|Science Fiction and Fantasy Hall of Fame]] inducted Russell in 2000, its fifth class of two deceased and two living writers. ''Into Your Tent'', a thorough and detailed biography of Russell by John L. Ingham, was published in 2010 by Plantech (UK). ==Writings== [[File:Other worlds science stories 195005.jpg|thumb|right|Russell's novelette "Dear Devil" was the cover story in the May 1950 issue of ''[[Other Worlds (magazine)|Other Worlds Science Stories]]'']] [[File:Fantastic 195808.jpg|thumb|right|Russell's essay "Satan's Footprints" was cover-featured on the August 1958 issue of ''[[Fantastic Stories|Fantastic]]'']] Russell's full-length fiction includes the following: * ''[[Sinister Barrier]]'' (1939) * ''[[Dreadful Sanctuary]]'' (1948) * ''[[Sentinels From Space]]'' (1953), based on the earlier magazine story ''The Star Watchers'' (1951) * ''[[Three to Conquer]]'' (1956), based on the earlier magazine serial ''Call Him Dead'' (1955) * ''[[Men, Martians and Machines]]'' (1955), containing four related novellas * ''[[Wasp (novel)|Wasp]]'' (1958) * ''[[Next of Kin (novel)|Next of Kin]]'' (1959), published earlier as ''The Space Willies'' (1958) * ''[[The Great Explosion]]'' (1962) * ''[[With a Strange Device]]'' (1964), also published as ''The Mindwarpers''. Russell also wrote a large number of shorter works, many of which have been reprinted in collections such as ''[[Deep Space (collection)|Deep Space]]'' (1954), ''Six Worlds Yonder'' (1958), ''Far Stars'' (1961), ''Dark Tides'' (1962) and ''Somewhere a Voice'' (1965). His short story "[[Allamagoosa]]" (1955), which was essentially a science-fictional retelling of a traditional tall story called "The Shovewood", won the Hugo Award for Best Short Story. Russell wrote numerous non-fiction essays on Fortean themes, some of which were collected in a compendium of Forteana entitled ''Great World Mysteries'' (1957). His second non-fiction book was ''The Rabble Rousers'' (1963), a sardonic look at human folly including the [[Dreyfus affair]] and the [[Florida land boom]]. He also wrote ''Lern Yerself Scouse: The ABZ of Scouse'' (1966) under the pseudonym "Linacre Lane". Two omnibus collections of Russell's science fiction are available from [[NESFA Press]]: ''Major Ingredients'' (2000), containing 30 of his short stories, and ''Entities'' (2001) containing five novels. [[John Pelan]]'s Midnight House published ''Darker Tides'', a collection of Russell's [[Horror fiction|horror]] and [[weird fiction]], in 2006.Scott Connors, Review of "''Darker Tides'' by Eric Frank Russell". ''Weird Tales'',October–November 2006. (p.13) The 1995 novel ''Design for Great-Day'', published as by [[Alan Dean Foster]] and Eric Frank Russell, is an expansion by Foster of a 1953 short story of the same name by Russell. ==Writing style and themes== Russell had an easy-going, colloquial writing style that was influenced in part by American "[[hard-boiled]]" detective fiction of the kind popularized by ''[[Black Mask (magazine)|Black Mask]]'' magazine.{{cite book |last=Carr |first=Terry |authorlink=Terry Carr |title=Classic Science Fiction: The First Golden Age |year=1979 |publisher= [[Robson Books]] |isbn=0-86051-070-0}} Although British, Russell wrote predominantly for an American audience, and was often assumed to be American by readers. Much of Russell's science fiction is based on what might be described as fortean themes, with ''Sinister Barrier'' and ''Dreadful Sanctuary'' the most notable examples. Another common theme is the single resourceful human pitted against a ponderous alien [[bureaucracy]], as in the novels ''Wasp'' and ''Next of Kin'', as well as several shorter works. Russell is sometimes categorized as a humorous writer, and [[Brian Aldiss]] describes him as John W. Campbell's "licensed jester".{{cite book |last=Aldiss |first=Brian W. |title=Billion Year Spree |year=1973 |publisher= [[Weidenfeld & Nicolson]] |isbn=0-297-76555-8}} However, Russell's humour generally has a satirical edge, often aimed at [[authority]] and bureaucracy in its various forms. On other occasions, for example in the short stories "Somewhere a Voice" and "The Army Comes to Venus", his work has a deeper and more serious tone, in which the [[spirituality|spiritual]] aspects of humanity's endeavours and aspirations shine through. ==Critical Reception== Scott Connors, reviewing Russell's book ''Darker Tides'', stated that " Russell's prose displays a rare sense of irony and wit...and does the reader the compliment of presenting the story in an indirect fashion so that he has an investment in the tale." ==Cultural influences== Russell's short story "Jay Score" (1941) is unusual amongst the pulp fiction of its time in presenting a [[Black people|black]] character, the ship's doctor, without any [[Ethnic stereotype|racial stereotyping]]. Indeed, this story and its sequels (collected in ''[[Men, Martians and Machines]]'') may be considered an early example of the science fiction subgenre in which a spaceship is crewed by a [[Multiethnic society|multi-ethnic]], mixed human/non-human, complement (cf. the much later ''[[Star Trek]]''). Russell also appears to have originated the colloquial [[initialism]] "MYOB" for "[[mind your own business]]", which appears frequently in the novella ''[http://www.abelard.org/e-f-russell.htm "... And Then There Were None"]'' (''Astounding'', June 1951) and in the novel ''The Great Explosion'' based upon it. In 1970, Russell was paid £4689 by the [[The Beatles|Beatles]]'s company [[Apple Corps]] for the motion picture rights to his novel ''Wasp'', the contract being signed on behalf of Apple by [[Ringo Starr]]. The film was never made, but it remained one of the most lucrative deals Russell ever made. ==See also== {{Portal |Speculative fiction }} * [[Study in Still Life]] * [[Tower of Hanoi]] ==Notes== {{notelist |50em}} ==References== {{reflist |50em |refs= {{isfdb name |51}} ('''ISFDB'''). Select a particular edition (title) for more data at that level, such as a front cover image or linked contents. [http://www.isfdb.org/cgi-bin/ea.cgi?2096 "Leslie J. Johnson – Summary Bibliography"]. ISFDB. Retrieved 2013-04-20. ''The Locus Index to SF Awards: Index of Literary Nominees''. [[Locus Publications]]. Retrieved 2013-03-26. This was the official website of the hall of fame to 2004. }} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal |author=Jacob Edwards |year=2010 |title=Overlooked: the non-fiction of Eric Frank Russell |journal=[[Andromeda Spaceways Inflight Magazine]] |volume=45 |pages=74–77}} ==External links== * {{sfhof |951 | Eric Frank Russell}} * {{isfdb name|51}} * {{IBList|type=author|id=824|name=Eric Frank Russell}} * [http://www.maroney.org/hlavaty/documents/Eric_Frank_Russell.html Review of ''Major Ingredients''] * [http://members.iinet.net.au/~parallax/efr "Shadow Man" fan site by Narrelle Harris] * [http://www.philsp.com/articles/pastmasters_13.html Past Masters: Let Me Be Frank, or Welcome to the Allamagoosa Russell-Palooza] by Bud Webster, at Galactic Central * ''[http://www.abelard.org/e-f-russell.htm And then there were none]'' (1951)—the internet host notes "Anarchy in action—an excellent model of an anarchist or free society" {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Russell, Eric Frank}} [[Category:1905 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century English novelists]] [[Category:English horror writers]] [[Category:English science fiction writers]] [[Category:Fortean writers]] [[Category:Forteana]] [[Category:Hugo Award-winning writers]] [[Category:People from Sandhurst, Berkshire]] [[Category:Prometheus Award winners]] [[Category:Science Fiction Hall of Fame inductees]]

page.title: Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/220.253.26.184|220.253.26.184]] ([[User talk:220.253.26.184|talk]]) to last revision by Smasongarrison. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:2009 0121 clinton 290 1.jpg|thumb|Clinton takes the oath of office as Secretary of State, administered by Associate Judge Kathryn Oberly as [[Bill Clinton]] holds the [[Bible]].]] [[Hillary Clinton]] served as the [[List of Secretaries of State of the United States|67th]] [[United States Secretary of State]], under President [[Barack Obama]], from 2009 to 2013, overseeing the department that conducted the [[Foreign policy of Barack Obama]].
She was preceded in office by [[Condoleezza Rice]], and succeeded by [[John Kerry]]. She is also the only former [[First Lady of the United States]] to become a member of the [[United States Cabinet]]. {{Hillary Clinton series}}
==Nomination and confirmation== {{Wikinews|Hillary Clinton nominated as US Secretary of State}} Within a week after the November 4, 2008, presidential election, President-elect Obama and Clinton discussed over telephone the possibility of her serving as [[United States Secretary of State|U.S. Secretary of State]] in his administration.<ref name="reut111409">{{cite news |author=Holland, Steve |url=https://www.reuters.com/articlePrint?articleId=USTRE4AD04820081114 |title=Obama, Clinton discussed Secretary of State job |agency=Reuters|date=November 14, 2008 |accessdate=November 18, 2008}}</ref><ref name="pol101409">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1009/28278.html|title=Hillary Clinton: I'd have hired Barack Obama|author=Barr, Andy|newspaper=[[Politico]]|date=October 14, 2009|accessdate=October 14, 2009}}</ref> Clinton later related, "He said I want you to be my secretary of state. And I said, 'Oh, no, you don't.' I said, 'Oh, please, there's so many other people who could do this.'"<ref name="pol101409" /> Clinton initially turned Obama down, but he persisted.<ref name="cbs010710">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/01/07/60minutes/main6067628.shtml |title=Revelations From The Campaign |work=[[60 Minutes]] |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=January 8, 2010}}</ref><ref name="nytm-rock" /> Some Democratic senators welcomed the idea of her leaving, having been allied with Obama during the campaign, and believing that Clinton had risked party disunity by keeping her candidacy going for so long.<ref name="wolffe-314" />
Obama and Clinton held a meeting on the subject on November 11.<ref name="reut111908">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/joeBiden/idUSTRE4AH7W020081119 |title=Bill Clinton offers steps to help wife get State job |author=Holland, Steve |agency=Reuters |date=November 19, 2008 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> When the possibility became public on November 14, it came as a surprising and dramatic move, especially given the long, sometimes bitter battle the two had waged during the [[Democratic Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2008|2008 Democratic Party presidential primaries]].<ref name="reut111409" /><ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950CE5DF133CF936A25752C1A96E9C8B63 |title=Obama's Talk With Clinton Creates Buzz |author=Calmes, Jackie |author2=Cooper, Helene |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 15, 2008 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> Obama had specifically criticized Clinton's foreign policy credentials during the contests, and the initial idea of him appointing her had been so unexpected that she had told one of her own aides, "Not in a million years."<ref name="nytm-rock" /> However, it has been reported that Obama had been thinking of the idea as far back as the [[2008 Democratic National Convention]].<ref name="wolffe-313">Wolffe, ''Renegade'', p. 313.</ref> Despite the aggressiveness of the campaign and the still-lingering animosities between the two campaign staffs,<ref>Wolffe, ''Renegade'', pp. 205–207.</ref> as with many primary battles, the political differences between the candidates were never that great,<ref name="inc-134">Libert and Faulk, ''Barack, Inc.'', pp. 133–134.</ref> the two rivals had reportedly developed a respect for one another,<ref name="wolffe-313" /> and she had campaigned for him in the general election.<ref name="nytm-rock" />
Consideration of Clinton was seen as Obama wanting to assemble a "team of rivals" in his administration, à la [[Abraham Lincoln]].<ref name="nytm-rock" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1860727,00.html |title= Why Obama Wants Hillary for His 'Team of Rivals' |author=Tumulty, Karen |author2=Calabresi, Massimo |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=November 20, 2008 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref><ref name="usa061109" /> The notion of rivals successfully working together also found applicability in other fields, such as [[George Marshall]] and [[Dwight Eisenhower]] in relation to [[Operation Overlord]] during World War II and [[Indra Nooyi]] keeping on her top rival for CEO at [[Pepsico]].<ref name="inc-134" /> At the same time, the choice gave Obama an image of being self-assured.<ref>Libert and Faulk, ''Barack, Inc.'', p. 52.</ref>
Clinton was conflicted whether she wanted to take the position or remain in the Senate, and agonized over her decision.<ref name="nytm-rock" /><ref name="reut111908" /><ref name="nyt111808">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/19/us/politics/19clinton.html |title=Clinton Said to Be Unsure About Cabinet Job |author=Hernandez, Raymond |author2=Luo, Michael |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 18, 2008 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> While the Senate leadership had discussed possible leadership positions or other promotions in rank with her even before the cabinet position became a possibility, nothing concrete had been offered.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/21/us/politics/21obama.html |title=An Option for Clinton: Enhanced Senate Role |author=Baker, Peter |authorlink=Peter Baker (author) |author2=Cooper, Helene |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 20, 2008 |accessdate=April 10, 2010}}</ref> The prospect of her ever becoming [[Senate Majority Leader]] seemed dim.<ref name="wolffe-314" /> A different complication was [[Bill Clinton]]; she told Obama: "There's one last thing that's a problem, which is my husband. You've seen what this is like; it will be a circus if I take this job", making reference to the volatile effect Bill Clinton had had during the primaries.<ref name="cbs010710" /> In addition, there was a specific concern whether the financial and other involvements of [[Post-presidency of Bill Clinton|Bill Clinton's post-presidential activities]] would violate any conflict-of-interest rules for serving cabinet members.<ref name="nyt111808" /> There was as well considerable media speculation about what effect taking the position would have on her political career and any possible future presidential aspirations.<ref name="nyt111808" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.observer.com/2008/politics/secretary-state-prize-rarely-stepping-stone |title=Secretary of State: A Prize, but Rarely a Steppingstone |author=Kornacki, Steve |newspaper=[[The New York Observer]] |date=November 17, 2008 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> Clinton wavered over the offer, but as she later related, "But, you know, we kept talking. I finally began thinking, look, if I had won and I had called him, I would have wanted him to say yes. And, you know, I'm pretty old-fashioned, and it's just who I am. So at the end of the day, when your president asks you to serve, you say yes, if you can."<ref name="pol101409" /> [[Chief of Protocol of the United States]] [[Capricia Penavic Marshall]], who had known Clinton since her First Lady days, later confirmed the same rationale: "When asked to serve, she does. And her president asked."<ref name="nytm-rock" />
On November 21, reports indicated that Clinton had accepted the position.<ref name="npr112108">{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=97327730 |title=Obama Set On Key Cabinet Nominees |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=November 21, 2008 |accessdate=November 21, 2008}}</ref> On December 1, President-elect Obama formally announced that Clinton would be his nominee for Secretary of State.<ref name="sky120108">{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Barack-Obama-Makes-Hillary-Clinton-Secretary-Of-State-And-Unveils-Defence-Team/Article/200812115168344?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_3&lid=ARTICLE_15168344_Barack_Obama_Makes_Hillary_Clinton_Secretary_Of_State_And_Unveils_Defence_Team |title=Obama Confirms Hillary In Top Job |publisher=[[Sky News]] |date=December 1, 2008 |accessdate=December 1, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207203221/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Barack-Obama-Makes-Hillary-Clinton-Secretary-Of-State-And-Unveils-Defence-Team/Article/200812115168344?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_3&lid=ARTICLE_15168344_Barack_Obama_Makes_Hillary_Clinton_Secretary_Of_State_And_Unveils_Defence_Team |archivedate=February 7, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Clinton said she was reluctant to leave the Senate, but that the new position represented a "difficult and exciting adventure".<ref name="sky120108" /> As part of the nomination, Bill Clinton agreed to accept a number of conditions and restrictions regarding his ongoing activities and fundraising efforts for the [[William J. Clinton Presidential Center and Park|Clinton Presidential Center]] and [[Clinton Global Initiative]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/30/washington/30clinton.html |title=Bill Clinton to Name Donors as Part of Obama Deal |author=Baker, Peter |authorlink=Peter Baker (author) |work=The New York Times |date=November 29, 2008 |accessdate=December 1, 2008}}</ref>
The appointment required a [[Saxbe fix]],<ref name="cnn120408" /> which was passed and signed into law in December 2008 before confirmation hearings began.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/19/bush-approves-bill-reducing-secretary-of-states-pay/ |title=Bush Approves Bill Reducing Secretary of State's Pay |author=Falcone, Michael |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 19, 2008 |accessdate=December 19, 2008}}</ref> Confirmation hearings before the [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] began on January 13, 2009, a week before the Obama inauguration. Clinton stated during her confirmation hearings that she believed that "the best way to advance America's interests in reducing global threats and seizing global opportunities is to design and implement global solutions" and "We must use what has been called '[[smart power]]', the full range of tools at our disposal—diplomatic, economic, military, political, legal and cultural—picking the right tool or combination of tools for each situation. With smart power, diplomacy will be the vanguard of our foreign policy."<ref>{{cite web|last=Clinton |first=Hillary Rodham |url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/01/115196.htm |title=Nomination Hearing To Be Secretary of State |publisher=[[U.S. State Department]] |date=January 13, 2009 |accessdate=January 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124153303/http://state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/01/115196.htm |archivedate=January 24, 2009 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On January 15, the Committee voted 16–1 to approve Clinton.<ref name="ap011509">{{cite news |author=Flaherty, Anne |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory?id=6651858 |title=Senate Panel Backs Clinton as Secretary of State |agency=Associated Press|publisher=ABC News|date=January 15, 2009|accessdate=May 9, 2009}} {{dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Republican Senator [[David Vitter]] of Louisiana was the lone dissenting vote in the committee.<ref name="ap011509" /> By this time, Clinton's public favorable/unfavorable rating had reached 65 percent, the highest point in her public career since the [[Lewinsky scandal]] during her time as First Lady,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/113740/Senate-Hearings-Begin-Hillary-Clintons-Image-Soars.aspx |title=As Senate Hearings Begin, Hillary Clinton's Image Soars |author=Jones, Jeffrey M. |publisher=The Gallup Organization |date=January 13, 2009 |accessdate=January 16, 2009}}</ref> and 71 percent of the public approved of the nomination to the cabinet.<ref name="cnn120408">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/12/04/clinton.eligible/index.html |title=Clinton's nomination popular, but is it constitutional? |author=Hayes, Samantha |publisher=CNN |date=December 4, 2008 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref>
Even before taking office, Clinton was working together with Bush administration officials in assessing national security issues. The night before the [[First inauguration of Barack Obama|inauguration of the new president]], contingency plans against a purported plot by [[Somali people|Somali]] extremists against Obama and the inauguration was being discussed. Clinton argued that typical security responses were not tenable: "Is the Secret Service going to whisk him off the podium so the American people see their incoming president disappear in the middle of the inaugural address? I don't think so."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/17/magazine/17Terror-t.html |title=Obama's War Over Terror |author=Baker, Peter |authorlink=Peter Baker (author) |magazine=[[The New York Times Magazine]] |date=January 4, 2010}}</ref> (The threat turned out to not exist.)
On January 21, 2009, Clinton was confirmed in the full Senate by a vote of 94–2.<ref name="kate phillips">{{cite news |url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/21/senate-debates-clinton-confirmation/ |title=Senate Confirms Clinton as Secretary of State|last=Phillips|first=Kate|date=January 21, 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=May 10, 2009}}</ref> Vitter and Republican Senator [[Jim DeMint]] of South Carolina voted against the confirmation.<ref name="kate phillips" />
Clinton took the oath of office of Secretary of State that same day. Just before being sworn in as Secretary of State, Clinton resigned her Senate seat effective just hours before her oath as Secretary of State.<ref>{{cite news |title=Clinton sworn in at State Dept. and then resigns Senate |first=Brian |last=Tumulty |work=The Journal News |date=January 21, 2009 |url=http://polhudson.lohudblogs.com/2009/01/21/clinton-has-resigned-the-senate-sworn-in-at-state-dept/ |accessdate=January 22, 2009}}</ref> She became the first former First Lady to serve in the [[United States Cabinet]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/politicaljunkie/2008/12/obama_brings_hillary_to_cabine.html |title=Obama Brings Hillary to Cabinet, GOP to Ariz. State House |author=Rudin, Ken |publisher=NPR |date=December 1, 2008 |accessdate=May 9, 2009}}</ref> She also became the first Secretary of State to have previously been an elected official since [[Edmund Muskie]]'s less-than-a-year stint in 1980,<ref name="time-stateof" /> with [[Christian Herter]] during the [[Eisenhower administration]] being the last one before that. In being selected by her formal rival Obama, she became only the fourth person in the preceding hundred years to join the cabinet of someone they had run against for their party's presidential nomination that election year ([[Jack Kemp]] ran against and was later chosen by [[George H. W. Bush]] to be [[United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development|Secretary of HUD]] in 1988, [[George W. Romney]] by [[Richard Nixon]] for Secretary of HUD in 1968, and [[Philander Knox]] by [[William Howard Taft]] for Secretary of State in 1908 preceded her; Obama's pick of [[Tom Vilsack]] for [[United States Secretary of Agriculture|Secretary of Agriculture]] followed her a couple of weeks later to be the next such person).
(On January 29, 2009, the constitutionality of her Saxbe fix was challenged in court by [[Judicial Watch]];<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsvine.com/_news/2009/01/29/2371601-lawsuit-argues-clinton-ineligible-for-state-post |title=Lawsuit argues Clinton ineligible for state post |author=Pickler, Nedra |agency=Associated Press |publisher=[[Newsvine]] |date=January 29, 2009 |accessdate=May 9, 2009}}</ref> on October 30, 2009, the courts dismissed the case.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601110&sid=aZ3j1lzT_GRA |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120721100538/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601110&sid=aZ3j1lzT_GRA |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 21, 2012 |title=Clinton Wins Dismissal of Suit Challenging Selection |author=O'Reilly, Cary |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=October 30, 2009 |accessdate=October 31, 2009 }}</ref>)
==Staff== During the [[Presidential transition of Barack Obama|Obama presidential transition]], Clinton described her own transition as "difficult ... in some respects, because [she] never even dreamed of it."<ref name="usa061109" /> Then, and in the early days of her tenure, there was considerable jockeying for jobs within the department among those in "[[Hillaryland]]", her longtime circle of advisors and staff aides, as well as others who had worked with her in the past, with not as many jobs as those desiring of them.<ref name="pol021009">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0209/18642.html |title=Clintonites jostle for jobs at State |author=Parnes, Amie |newspaper=[[Politico]] |date=February 10, 2009 |accessdate=November 14, 2009}}</ref><ref name="tnr-crowley" /> Obama gave Clinton more freedom to choose her staff than he did to any other cabinet member.<ref name="wolffe-314">Wolffe, ''Renegade'', p. 314.</ref><ref name="inc-134" />
Clinton's former campaign manager, [[Maggie Williams]], handled the staff hiring process.<ref name="pol021009" /> Longtime counsel to both Clintons [[Cheryl Mills]] served as the secretary's Counselor and Chief of Staff.<ref name="tnr-crowley">{{cite news |url=http://www.tnr.com/article/hillarys-state-0 |title=Hillary's State |author=Crowley, Michael |authorlink=Michael Crowley (journalist) |magazine=[[The New Republic]] |date=March 4, 2009 |accessdate=November 14, 2009}}</ref> [[James B. Steinberg]] was named [[United States Deputy Secretary of State|Deputy Secretary of State]].<ref name="tnr-crowley" /> [[Jacob Lew|Jacob "Jack" Lew]], once Bill Clinton's Director of the [[Office of Management and Budget]], was named [[Deputy Secretary of State for Management and Resources]], a new position.<ref name="pol-lew">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/01/obama-picks-jack-lew-to-replace-tim-geithner-as-treasury-secretary-85952.html |title=Obama picks Jack Lew to replace Tim Geithner as Treasury secretary |author=Schatz, Joseph J. |author2=Snell, Kelsey |newspaper=Politico |date=January 9, 2013}}</ref> This was an unusual step intended by Hillary Clinton to push to the forefront the emphasis on getting higher budget allocations from Congress and overlooking internal workings.<ref name="tnr-crowley" /><ref name="pol-lew" /> [[Anne-Marie Slaughter]] was appointed [[Director of Policy Planning]] with a view towards long-term policy towards Asia.<ref name="tnr-crowley" /> [[Huma Abedin]], Clinton's longtime personal assistant, was Deputy Chief of Staff for the secretary and remained a key member of Clinton's operation.<ref name="pol021009" /><ref name="pol-5-things" />
Much like she did at [[Senate career of Hillary Clinton#First term|the beginning of her Senate career]], Clinton kept a low profile during her early months and worked hard to familiarize herself with the culture and institutional history of the department.<ref name="tnr-crowley" /> She met or spoke with all of the living former secretaries, and especially relied upon her close friendship with [[Madeleine Albright]].<ref name="tnr-crowley" />
At the start of her tenure, Obama and Clinton announced several high-profile special envoys to trouble spots in the world, including former [[Senate Majority Leader]] [[George J. Mitchell|George Mitchell]] as Mideast envoy and [[Richard Holbrooke]] as envoy to South Asia and Afghanistan.<ref name="pol012209">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0109/17811.html |title=U.S. foreign policy: Who's in charge? |author=Smith, Ben |newspaper=[[Politico]] |date=January 22, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> On January 27, 2009, Secretary of State Clinton appointed [[Todd Stern]] as the department's Special Envoy for Climate Change.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/01/115409.htm|title=Secretary Clinton Announces Appointment of Special Envoy for Climate Change Todd Stern|publisher=|access-date=July 11, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161111201834/http://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/01/115409.htm|archive-date=November 11, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
By May 2009, Clinton and the Obama administration intended to nominate [[Paul Farmer]], co-founder of [[Partners in Health]], as Administrator of the [[United States Agency for International Development]] (USAID),<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=May 19, 2009 |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/05/15/health_pioneer_may_get_obama_post/ |title=Health pioneer may get Obama post |author=Smith, James F. |accessdate=November 14, 2009}}</ref> but by August 2009 his nomination was reportedly scotched by the White House for reasons unknown.<ref name="fp080409">{{cite news |url=http://thecable.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2009/08/04/paul_farmer_out_for_usaid/ |title=Paul Farmer out for USAID? |author=Rozen, Laura |magazine=[[Foreign Policy]] |date=August 4, 2009 |accessdate=November 14, 2009}}</ref><ref name="wi111109">{{cite news |url=http://washingtonindependent.com/67461/new-usaid-chief-faces-internal-skepticism |title=New USAID Chief Faces Internal Skepticism |author=Ackerman, Spencer |authorlink=Spencer Ackerman |newspaper=[[The Washington Independent]] |date=November 11, 2009 |accessdate=November 14, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330220414/http://washingtonindependent.com/67461/new-usaid-chief-faces-internal-skepticism |archivedate=March 30, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> This caused Clinton, while visiting USAID, to publicly criticize the long vetting process for administration appointments<ref name="fp080409" /> calling it a "nightmare" and "frustrating beyond words."<ref name="wi111109" /> In November 2009, an unconventional choice was nominated instead, [[Rajiv Shah]], a young [[Under Secretary of Agriculture for Research, Education, and Economics]].<ref name="wi111109" /> Clinton said, "He has a record of delivering results in both the private and public sectors, forging partnerships around the world, especially in Africa and Asia, and developing innovative solutions in global health, agriculture, and financial services for the poor."<ref name="wi111109" />
Despite some early press predictions,<ref name="tnr-crowley" /> in general Clinton's departmental staff has avoided the kind of leaks and infighting that troubled [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2008|her 2008 presidential campaign]].<ref name="pol-5-things">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1109/29210.html |title=Five things learned from Hillary Clinton's trip |author=Rozen, Laura |newspaper=[[Politico]] |date=November 7, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> One possibly lingering line of internal tension was resolved in early 2011 when State Department spokesperson [[P. J. Crowley]] resigned after making personal comments about in-captivity leaker [[Chelsea Manning]] and her treatment by the Department of Defense.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/bensmith/0311/Crowley_leaves_an_enigmatic_Hillaryland.html |title=Crowley leaves an enigmatic Hillaryland |author=Smith, Ben |work=[[Politico]] |date=March 13, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref> In other changes, Jacob Lew left in late 2010 to join the White House as [[Office of Management and Budget]] and was replaced as Deputy Secretary of State for Management and Resources by [[Thomas R. Nides]] (Lew would eventually become [[White House Chief of Staff]] and then the pick for [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|U.S. Treasury Secretary]] for Obama's second term),<ref name="pol-lew" /> and Steinberg left in mid-2011 and was replaced as Deputy Secretary by career diplomat [[William Joseph Burns|William J. Burns]].
==Early themes and structural initiatives== During the transition period, Clinton sought to build a more powerful State Department.<ref name="nyt122208">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/23/us/politics/23diplo.html |title=Clinton Moves to Widen Role of State Dept. |author=Landler, Mark |author2=Cooper, Helene |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 22, 2008 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> She began a push for a larger international affairs budget and an expanded role in global economic issues.<ref name="nyt122208" /> She cited the need for an increased U.S. diplomatic presence, especially in Iraq where the [[United States Defense Department|U.S. Defense Department]] had conducted diplomatic missions.<ref name="nyt122208" /> [[U.S. Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]] agreed with her, and also advocated larger State Department budgets.<ref name="time-stateof" /> Indeed, the two, and their respective departments, would have a productive relationship, unlike the often fraught relations between State and Defense and their secretaries seen in prior administrations.<ref>{{cite book |first=Robert |last=Gates |authorlink=Robert Gates |title=Duty: Memoirs of a Secretary at War |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf |location=New York |year=2014 |isbn=0-307-95947-3 |page=283}}</ref>
In the Obama administration's proposed [[2010 United States federal budget]] of February 2009, there was a proposed 9.5 percent budget increase for the State Department and other international programs, from $47.2 billion in fiscal year 2009 to $51.7 billion in fiscal year 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123566588886384023 |title=Budget Plan Is Short on State Department Specifics |author=Dreazen, Yochi J. |authorlink=Yochi Dreazen |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=February 26, 2009 |accessdate=November 8, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gpoaccess.gov/usbudget/fy10/pdf/budget/state.pdf |title=Department of State and Other International Programs |publisher=[[United States Government Printing Office]] |accessdate=November 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106171228/http://www.gpoaccess.gov/usbudget/fy10/pdf/budget/state.pdf |archivedate=January 6, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> By the time of Clinton's May 2009 testimony before the [[United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs]], numbers had been restated following rounds of general federal budget cuts,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/08/us/politics/08budget.html |title=Obama Unveils New Budget Cuts |author=Calmes, Jackie |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 7, 2009 |accessdate=November 8, 2009}}</ref> and the proposed fiscal year 2010 budget request for the State Department and [[USAID]] was $48.6 billion, a 7 percent increase.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/05/123679.htm |title=FY 2010 Budget for the Department of State: Hillary Rodham Clinton, Secretary of State, Before the
