Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs |author=Clinton, Hillary Rodham |authorlink=Hillary Clinton |publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]] |date=May 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 8, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091124042510/http://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/05/123679.htm |archive-date=November 24, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> That became the amount of increase that was obtained.<ref>Hudson and Leidl, ''The Hillary Doctrine'', p. 52.</ref>
Clinton also brought a message of departmental reform to the position, especially in regarding foreign aid programs as something that deserves the same status and level of scrutiny as diplomatic initiatives.<ref name="time-stateof">{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/politics/article/0,8599,1934843,00.html |title=The State of Hillary: A Mixed Record on the Job |author=Klein, Joe |authorlink = Joe Klein |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=November 5, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Hillary Clinton arrives at State Dept. 1-22-09 HRC-arrival-1.22.09 600 1.jpg|thumb|left|Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrives at the State Department on her first day greeted by a standing room only crowd of Department employees.]]
Clinton spent her initial days as Secretary of State telephoning dozens of world leaders.<ref name="nyt012709">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/28/washington/28diplo.html |title=Clinton Sees an Opportunity for Iran to Return to Diplomacy |author=Landler, Mark |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 27, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2009}}</ref> She said the world was eager to see a new American foreign policy and that, "There is a great exhalation of breath going on around the world. We've got a lot of damage to repair."<ref name="nyt012709" /> She did indicate that not every past policy would be repudiated, and specifically said it was essential that the [[six-party talks]] over the [[North Korea and weapons of mass destruction|North Korean nuclear weapons program]] continue.<ref name="afp012709" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/asection/la-fg-clinton28-2009jan28,0,5875432.story |title=World breathes sigh of relief, Hillary Clinton says |author=Richter, Paul |work=Los Angeles Times |date=January 28, 2009 |accessdate=January 30, 2009}}</ref> Clinton re-emphasized her views during her first speech to State Department employees when she said, "There are three legs to the stool of American foreign policy: defense, diplomacy, and development. And we are responsible for two of the three legs. And we will make clear, as we go forward, that diplomacy and development are essential tools in achieving the long-term objectives of the United States. And I will do all that I can, working with you, to make it abundantly clear that robust diplomacy and effective development are the best long-term tools for securing America's future."<ref>{{cite web |last=Clinton |first=Hillary |url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/01/115262.htm |title=Arrival at the Department of State |publisher=State Department |date=January 22, 2009 |accessdate=February 8, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204230358/http://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/01/115262.htm |archive-date=February 4, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Clinton also soon visited the [[United States Agency for International Development]], where she met employees and said they would be getting extra funds and attention during the new administration.<ref name="afp012709">{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h8Nz42mnD4KInXaR7sSafwvKDAsA |title=Hillary Clinton leaves quick stamp on US State Department |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=January 27, 2009 |accessdate=February 8, 2009}}</ref>
She kept a low profile when diplomatic necessity or Obama's involvement required it, but maintained an influential relationship with the president and in foreign policy decisions.<ref name=nyt040109 /><ref name="nyt050109" /> Her first 100 days found her travelling over {{convert|70000|mi|km}}, having no trouble adapting to being a team player subordinate to Obama, and gaining skills as an executive.<ref name="nyt050109">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/02/world/02clinton.html |title=Her Rival Now Her Boss, Clinton Settles Into New Role |author=Landler, Mark |work=The New York Times |date=May 1, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/04/28/opinion/diplomatic/main4975241.shtml |title=100 Days Of Diplomacy: A False Yardstick |author=Wolfson, Charles |publisher=CBS News |date=April 28, 2009 |accessdate=May 2, 2009}}</ref> Nevertheless, she remained an international celebrity with a much higher profile than most Secretaries of State.<ref name="time-stateof" /> Her background as an elected official gave her insight into the needs and fears of elected officials of other countries.<ref name="time-stateof" />
By the summer of 2009, there was considerable analysis and speculation in the media of what kind of role and level of influence Clinton had within the Obama administration, with a variety of assessments being produced.<ref name="usa061109">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/printedition/news/20090611/1aclinton11_cv.art.htm |title=In a supporting role, Clinton takes a low-key approach at State Dept. |author=Dilanian, Ken |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=June 11, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref><ref name="nyt071509">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/16/us/politics/16clinton.html |title=For Clinton, '09 Campaign Is for Her Turf |author=Landler, Mark |work=The New York Times |date=July 15, 2009 |accessdate=August 6, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2009/06/hillary_clinton_as_secretary_o.html |title=The Good Soldier: Hillary Clinton As Secretary of State |author=Keating, Peter |magazine=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=June 14, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0609/24067.html |title=Hillary Clinton toils in the shadows |author=Smith, Ben |newspaper=[[Politico]] |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> A prominent mid-July speech to the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] reasserted her role;<ref name="nyt071509" /> she said, "We cannot be afraid or unwilling to engage. Our focus on diplomacy and development is not an alternative to our national security arsenal."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/31927044 |title=Clinton warns Iran on engagement |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[msnbc.com]] |date=July 15, 2009 |accessdate=November 8, 2009}}</ref>
In July 2009, Clinton announced a new State Department initiative, the [[Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review]], to establish specific objectives for the State Department's diplomatic missions abroad.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/july/125949.htm |title=Town Hall Meeting to Announce the Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review (QDDR) |author=Clinton, Hillary Rodham |authorlink = Hillary Rodham Clinton |publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]] |date=July 10, 2009 |accessdate=November 8, 2009}}</ref> The most ambitious of Clinton's departmental reforms, it is modeled after the Defense Department's [[Quadrennial Defense Review]], which Clinton was familiar with from her days on the [[Senate Armed Services Committee]].<ref name="cbs071709">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/07/17/opinion/diplomatic/main5169849.shtml |title=Hillary Clinton's 6-Month Checkup |author=Wolfson, Charles |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=July 17, 2009 |accessdate=November 8, 2009}}</ref> [[Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review#The first review|The first such Review]] came out in December 2010. Entitled ''Leading Through Civilian Power'', its 220 pages centered on the notion of elevating "civilian power" as a cost-effective way of responding to international challenges and defusing crises.<ref name="wapo-qddr1">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/15/AR2010121507474.html |title=State Dept. review calls for emphasis on averting global crises |author=Sheridan, Mary Beth |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=December 16, 2010 |accessdate=January 4, 2011}}</ref><ref name="csm-qddr1">{{cite news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Foreign-Policy/2010/1215/Hillary-Clinton-s-vision-for-foreign-policy-on-a-tight-budget |title=Hillary Clinton's vision for foreign policy on a tight budget |author=LaFranchi, Howard |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=December 15, 2010 |accessdate=January 15, 2011}}</ref><ref name="nw-doctrine" /> It also sought the elevation of U.S. ambassadors in coordinating work of all abroad-tasked U.S. agencies.<ref name="wapo-qddr1" /> Clinton said of the underlying message, "Leading with civilians saves lives and money."<ref name="csm-qddr1" /> She also resolved to get Congress to approve the QDDR as a required part of the State Department planning process, saying, "I am determined that this report will not merely gather dust, like so many others."<ref name="csm-qddr1" /> Another theme of the report was the goal of empowering the female population in developing countries around the world; the QDDR mentioned women and girls some 133 times.<ref name="nw-doctrine" /> In part this reflected incorporation into the QDDR of [[the Hillary Doctrine]], which stipulates that [[women's rights]] and [[violence against women]] around the world should be considered issues of [[national security]] to the United States.<ref>Hudson and Leidl, ''The Hillary Doctrine'', pp. 4, 53.</ref> In addition, by attempting to institutionalize her goals in this area, Clinton – along with [[Anne-Marie Slaughter]] and [[Melanne Verveer]], who also worked heavily in these efforts – were hoping that her initiatives and concerns towards the empowerment of women would persist past Clinton's time in office as well as break a past pattern of chauvinism in the department.<ref name="nw-doctrine" />
In September, Clinton unveiled the Global Hunger and Food Security Initiative at the annual meeting of her husband's [[Clinton Global Initiative]].<ref name="state092509">{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/09/129644.htm |title=Remarks at the Clinton Global Initiative Closing Plenary |author=Clinton, Hillary Rodham |authorlink=Hillary Rodham Clinton |publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]] |date=September 25, 2009 |accessdate=November 9, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091107185230/http://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/09/129644.htm |archive-date=November 7, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="afp092509">{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jvW_Cw0mHaP8QNmbccjJk62ZCT3Q |title=Clinton unveils US food security initiative |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=September 25, 2009 |accessdate=November 9, 2009}}</ref> The goal of the new initiative is to battle hunger worldwide on a strategic basis as a key part of U.S. foreign policy, rather than just react to food shortage emergencies as they occur.<ref name="afp092509" /> The secretary said that "Food security is not just about food. But it is all about security: economic security, environmental security, even national security. Massive hunger poses a threat to the stability of governments, societies and borders."<ref name="state092509" /><ref name="afp092509" /> The initiative seeks to develop agricultural economies, counter malnourishment, increase productivity, expand trade, and spur innovation in developing nations. Clinton said that women would be placed at the center of the effort, as they constitute a majority of the world's farmers.<ref name="afp092509" /> The next month, to mark [[World Food Day]], Clinton said, "Fighting hunger and poverty through sustainable agricultural development, making sure that enough food is available and that people have the resources to purchase it, is a key foreign policy objective of the Obama administration."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hMX65hK0wFXqZf-8cPRS9qzOUx_Q |title=Fight against hunger key to security: Clinton |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=October 26, 2009 |accessdate=November 10, 2009}}</ref>
During October 2009, Clinton said, "this is a great job. It is a 24/7 job"<ref name="wapo101309">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/10/12/AR2009101202868.html |title=Clinton Says No to Another Presidential Bid |author=Kornblut, Anne E. |authorlink=Anne E. Kornblut |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=October 13, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> and "this job is incredibly all-encompassing."<ref name="pol101409" /> She said she never thought about if she were making the same foreign policy decisions as president, and had no intention of ever running for that office again.<ref name="pol101409" /><ref name="wapo101309" /> While some friends and former advisers thought she was primarily saying that to focus attention on her current role and that she might change her mind about running for president in the future, others felt that she was genuinely content with the direction her career and life had taken and no longer had presidential ambitions.<ref>Kornblut, ''Notes from the Cracked Ceiling'', pp. 253–254.</ref>
By the close of 2009 there were 25 female ambassadors posted by other nations to Washington; this was the highest number ever.<ref name=hillaryeffect>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/10/AR2010011002731.html|title='Hillary effect' cited for increase in female ambassadors to U.S.|author=Mary Jordan|work=The Washington Post|date=January 11, 2010}}</ref> This was dubbed the "Hillary effect" by some observers: "Hillary Clinton is so visible" as secretary of state, said [[Amelia Matos Sumbana]], the [[Mozambique – United States relations|Mozambique Ambassador to the United States]], "she makes it easier for presidents to pick a woman for Washington."<ref name=hillaryeffect /> An added fact, of course, was that two other recent U.S. Secretaries of State were women, but Clinton's international fame from her days as First Lady of the United States made her impact in this respect the greatest of the group.<ref name=hillaryeffect />
Clinton also included in the State Department budget for the first time a breakdown of programs that specifically concerned themselves with the well-being of women and girls around the world.<ref name="nw-doctrine" /> By fiscal 2012, the department's budget request for such work was $1.2 billion, of which $832 million was for global health programs.<ref name="nw-doctrine" /> Additionally, she initiated the [[Women in Public Service Project]], a joint venture between the State Department and the [[Seven Sisters (colleges)|Seven Sisters colleges]]. The goal was to entice more women into entering public service, such that within four decades an equal number of men and women would be working in the field.<ref name="elle-2012" />
One specific cause Clinton advocated almost from the start of her tenure was the adoption of [[cookstove]]s in the developing world, to foster cleaner and more environmentally sound food preparation and reduce smoke dangers to women. In September 2010, she announced a partnership with the [[United Nations Foundation]] to provide some 100 million such stoves around the world within the next ten years, and in subsequent travels she urged foreign leaders to adopt policies encouraging their use.<ref name="nytm-rock">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/01/magazine/hillary-clintons-last-tour-as-a-rock-star-diplomat.html |title=Last Tour of the Rock-Star Diplomat |author=Myers, Steven Lee |magazine=[[The New York Times Magazine]] |date=July 1, 2012 |pages=18–23, 49}}</ref>
In February 2010 testimony before the [[United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs|Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs]], Secretary Clinton complained about the slow pace of Senate confirmations of Obama's nominations to diplomatic positions, a number of which were delayed for political reasons and had been subject to [[Secret hold|holds]] by individual Republican senators.<ref name="abc022410">{{cite news |url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2010/02/washington-political-battles-hurt-us-image-and-obama-agenda-says-sec-clinton.html |title=Washington Political Battles Hurt U.S. Image and Obama Agenda, says Sec. Clinton |author=Radia, Kirit |author2=Blakely, Jonathan |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=February 24, 2010 |accessdate=February 27, 2010}}</ref> Clinton said the problem damaged America's image abroad: "It became harder and harder to explain to countries, particularly countries of significance, why we had nobody in position for them to interact with."<ref name="abc022410" />
In 2009, and again in 2010 and 2011, Clinton stated that she was committed to serving out her full term as secretary, but would not commit to serving a second term should Obama be re-elected.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2011/01/hillary-clinton-wont-commit-to.html |title=Hillary Clinton reaffirms: I won't commit to a second term (video) |author=Kolawole, Emi |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 19, 2011 |accessdate=February 4, 2011}}</ref>
She later used U.S. allies and what she called "convening power" to help keep the Libyan rebels unified as they eventually overthrew the [[Gaddafi regime]].<ref name="time-smart" />
Throughout her tenure, Clinton has looked towards "[[smart power]]" as the strategy for asserting U.S. leadership and values, combining military strength with U.S. capacities in global economics, development aid, and technology.<ref name="time-smart" /> In late 2011 she said, "All power has limits. In a much more networked and multipolar world we can't wave a magic wand and say to China or Brazil or India, 'Quit growing. Quit using your economies to assert power' ... It's up to us to figure out how we position ourselves to be as effective as possible at different times in the face of different threats and opportunities."<ref name="time-smart" />
Clinton has also greatly expanded the State Department's use of [[social media]], including [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]], both to get its message out and to help empower people vis à via their rulers. Clinton said, "We are in the age of participation, and the challenge ... is to figure out how to be responsive, to help catalyze, unleash, channel the kind of participatory eagerness that is there." She has tried to institutionalize this change, by making social media a focus for foreign service officers and up to the ambassadorial level. (Other Clinton initiatives were run solely out of her office and were at risk of disappearing after she left office.) By late 2011, the department had 288 Facebook accounts and 192 Twitter feeds. The change was enough for daughter [[Chelsea Clinton]] to refer to the secretary as "TechnoMom".<ref name="time-smart" />
==Regional issues and travels: 2009== [[File:President Obama, Secretary Clinton and Prime Minister Brown at the 2009 NATO summit.jpg|thumb|right|Obama and Clinton speaking with one another at the [[2009 Strasbourg–Kehl summit|21st NATO summit]] in April 2009]]
In February 2009, Clinton made her first trip as secretary to Asia, visiting Japan, Indonesia, South Korea, and China on what she described as a "listening tour" that was "intended to really find a path forward."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-02/22/content_10868987.htm |title=A glance at features of Hillary Clinton's Asian tour |author=Zhao Yi |agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |date=February 22, 2009 |accessdate=March 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225031820/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-02/22/content_10868987.htm |archivedate=February 25, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> She continued to travel heavily in her first months in office, often getting very enthusiastic responses by engaging with the local populace.<ref name=nyt040109>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/02/world/europe/02diplo.html |title=Lower Profile for Clinton, but Her Influence Rises |author=Landler, Mark |work=The New York Times |date=April 1, 2009 |accessdate=April 6, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/21/world/asia/21diplo.html |title=Clinton Reshapes Diplomacy by Tossing the Script |author=Landler, Mark |work=The New York Times |date=February 20, 2009 |accessdate=April 6, 2009}}</ref>
In early March 2009, Clinton made her first trip as secretary to Israel.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-03-02-voa57.cfm |title=Hillary Clinton Begins First Foray Into Israel-Palestinian Conflict |author=Luis Ramirez |publisher=[[VOA]] |date=March 2, 2009 |accessdate=March 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304053744/http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-03-02-voa57.cfm |archivedate=March 4, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> During this time, Clinton announced that the US government will dispatch two officials to the Syrian capital to explore Washington's relationship with Damascus.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/03/03/clinton.mideast/ |title=Clinton: 2 U.S. officials to visit Syria |publisher=CNN |date=March 3, 2009 |accessdate=March 3, 2009}}</ref> On March 5, Clinton attended the NATO foreign ministers meeting in Brussels.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0309/19697.html |title=For Clinton, Iran is Middle East key |author=David s. cloud|work=[[Politico]] |date=March 6, 2009 |accessdate=March 6, 2009}}</ref> At this meeting, Clinton proposed including Iran at a conference on Afghanistan. Clinton said the proposed conference could be held on March 31 in the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2009/03/05/2009-03-05_secretary_of_state_hillary_clinton_invit.html |title=Secretary of State Hillary Clinton invites Iran to Afghan talks table |author= Richard Sisk |work=[[New York Daily News]] |date=March 6, 2009 |accessdate=March 6, 2009}}</ref> On March 6, a photo-op with Russian Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] intended to demonstrate the U.S. and Russia pressing the "[[reset button]]" on their relationship, in an effort to mend frayed ties, went a bit awry due to a mistranslation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/03/06/clinton-goofs-russian-translation-tells-diplomat-wants-overcharge-ties/ |title=Clinton Goofs on Russian Translation, Tells Diplomat She Wants to 'Overcharge' Ties |publisher=Fox News |date=March 6, 2009}}</ref> (The word the Americans chose, "peregruzka", meant "overloaded" or "overcharged", rather than "reset".) The episode became known as the [[Russian reset]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7930047.stm |title=Button gaffe embarrasses Clinton |publisher=BBC News|date=March 7, 2009}}</ref>
During March 2009, Clinton prevailed over [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]] on an internal debate to send an additional 20,000 troops to [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/printedition/news/20090611/1aclinton11_cv.art.htm |title=In a supporting role, Clinton takes a low-key approach at State Dept. |author=Dilanian, Ken |work=[[USA Today]] |date=June 11, 2009 |accessdate=July 22, 2009}}</ref>
In June 2009, Clinton had surgery to repair a right [[Elbow#Fractures|elbow fracture]] caused by a fall in the State Department basement.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSTRE55I4K820090619 |title=Clinton has surgery to fix broken elbow |agency=Reuters|date=June 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 20, 2009 |first=Sue |last=Pleming}}</ref> The painful injury and recuperation caused her to miss two foreign trips.<ref name="nyt071509" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2009/07/01/clinton_cancels_trip_to_russia.html |title=Clinton Cancels Trip to Russia |author=Kessler, Glenn |authorlink=Glenn Kessler (journalist) |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 1, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> Nevertheless, during President Obama's trip without her to Russia, Clinton was named as co-coordinator, along with Russian Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]], of a newly created U.S.-Russian Presidential Commission to discuss nuclear, economic, and energy and environmental policies relating to the two countries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/07/06/Moscow-visit-due-for-Hillary-Clinton/UPI-83131246902671/ |title=Moscow visit due for Hillary Clinton |agency=United Press International |date=July 6, 2009 |accessdate=November 8, 2009}}</ref>
Clinton returned to the diplomatic scene and responded to the ongoing [[2009 Honduran constitutional crisis]], in which plans for the [[Honduran fourth ballot box referendum]] had led to the [[2009 Honduran coup d'état]], and which was becoming Latin America's worst political crisis in some years.<ref name="nyt-hond-deal" /> In early July, she sat down with ousted [[President of Honduras]] [[Manuel Zelaya]], who agreed on a U.S.-backed proposal to begin talks with the ''de facto'' [[Roberto Micheletti]] government.<ref name=ReutersJuly7>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUSTRE56424C20090707?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0|title=Honduras' Zelaya says to meet coup backers on Thursday|agency=Reuters|date=July 7, 2009|accessdate=July 7, 2009}}</ref> Later, in September, Zelaya returned to the country, and [[President of Costa Rica]] [[Óscar Arias]], who had become a mediator in the matter, as well as Clinton expressed hope that Zelaya's return could break the impasse with the Micheletti government. In particular, Clinton said, "Now that President Zelaya is back it would be opportune to restore him to his position under appropriate circumstances – get on with the election that is currently scheduled for November, have a peaceful transition of presidential authority and get Honduras back to constitutional and democratic order."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2009-09-21/world/honduras.ousted.president_1_president-zelaya-brazilian-embassy-honduras?_s=PM:WORLD |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130120081236/http://articles.cnn.com/2009-09-21/world/honduras.ousted.president_1_president-zelaya-brazilian-embassy-honduras?_s=PM:WORLD |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 20, 2013 |title=Zelaya returns to Honduras |publisher=CNN |date=September 21, 2009 }}</ref> At the end of October, Clinton took a leading role in convincing Micheletti to accept a deal – which she termed an "historic agreement" – in which Zelaya would return to power in advance of general elections in which neither figure was running.<ref name="nyt-hond-deal" /> Micheletti said that Clinton had been insistent on this point: "I kept trying to explain our position to her, but all she kept saying was, 'Restitution, restitution, restitution.'"<ref name="nyt-hond-deal">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/31/world/americas/31honduras.html |title=Deal Set to Restore Ousted Honduran President |author=Thompson, Ginger |author2=Malkin, Elisabeth |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 30, 2009}}</ref> That agreement broke down, despite efforts of the State Department to revive it,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091111/ap_on_re_la_am_ca/lt_honduras_coup |title=US diplomat in Honduras trying to revive pact|date=November 11, 2009 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Yahoo! News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091112153827/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091111/ap_on_re_la_am_ca/lt_honduras_coup |archivedate=November 12, 2009}}</ref> and Clinton and the U.S. ended up supporting the winner of the [[Honduran general election, 2009|2009 Honduran general election]], [[Porfirio Lobo Sosa]], with Clinton characterizing the elections as "free and fair" and Lobo as holding a strong commitment to democracy and the rule of constitutional law.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10256459 |title=Hillary Clinton urges the OAS to readmit Honduras |publisher=BBC News |date=June 7, 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Hillary Clinton and Hugo Chavez.png|thumb|left|Clinton meets with President [[Hugo Chávez]] at the [[Summit of the Americas]] on April 19, 2009]]
Clinton co-chaired the high-level [[U.S.–China Strategic and Economic Dialogue]] in Washington, D.C. on July 27–28, 2009 and led the Strategic Track for the United States.
In August 2009, Clinton embarked on her longest trip yet, to a number of stops in Africa.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/08/03/clinton.africa.trip/index.html |title=Clinton's trip to Africa her biggest yet |author=Dougherty, Jill |publisher=CNN |date=August 3, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref> On August 10, 2009, at a public event in [[Kinshasa]], a Congolese student asked her what her husband, "Mr Clinton", thought of a Chinese trade deal with the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]. Clinton looked irritated at the question and replied, "Wait, you want me to tell you what my husband thinks? My husband is not the secretary of state, I am. So you ask my opinion, I will tell you my opinion. I am not going to be channeling my husband." The incident was played in newsrooms around the world. Clinton aides suggested there might have been a mistranslation, but that was not the case; however the student had later apologized to her, saying he had meant to ask what "Mr Obama" thought.<ref name="nyt-pique">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/13/world/africa/13clinton.html |title=Clinton's Flash of Pique in Congo |author=Gettleman, Jeffrey |newspaper=The New York Times |date=August 12, 2009}}</ref>
In October 2009, Clinton's intervention – including juggling conversations on two mobile phones while sitting in a limousine<ref name="nyt-me-test" /> – overcame last-minute snags and saved the signing of an [[2009 Armenia–Turkey Accord|historic Turkish–Armenian accord]] that established diplomatic relations and opened the border between the two long-hostile nations.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1929584,00.html |title=Turkey, Armenia Sign Historic Accord |author=Lee, Matthew |agency=Associated Press |magazine=Time |date=October 10, 2009 |accessdate=October 14, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091104182204/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1929584,00.html |archivedate=November 4, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2009/10/20091010181935891322.html|title=Turkey-Armenia ink historic accord|date=October 10, 2009|accessdate=October 10, 2009|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]}}</ref>
[[File:Hillary Rodham Clinton in Pakistan.jpg|thumb|Clinton with Pakistani Prime Minister [[Yousaf Raza Gillani]] during an October 2009 visit to [[Islamabad]].]] In late October 2009, Clinton travelled to Pakistan, where she had staged a memorable visit in 1995 while First Lady.<ref name="time-stateof" /> Her arrival was followed within hours by the [[28 October 2009 Peshawar bombing]]; in response, Clinton said of those responsible, "They know they are on the losing side of history but they are determined to take as many lives with them as their movement is finally exposed for the nihilistic, empty effort that it is."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/10/28/pakistan.blast/index.html |title=Survivors recount narrow escape from deadly Peshawar market bombing |publisher=CNN |date=October 29, 2009 |accessdate=January 23, 2010}}</ref> In addition to meeting with Prime Minister [[Yousaf Raza Gillani]], she also staged numerous public appearances.<ref name="time-stateof" /><ref name="pol-5-things" /> In those, she let students, talk show hosts, and tribal elders repeatedly complain about and criticize American foreign policy and American actions.<ref name="time-stateof" /><ref name="pol-5-things" /> Occasionally, she pushed back in a more blunt fashion than usual for diplomats, explicitly wondering why Pakistan had not been more successful in combating [[al Qaeda]] "if they wanted to."<ref name="pol-5-things" /> Member of Parliament and government spokesperson [[Farahnaz Ispahani]] said, "In the past, when the Americans came, they would talk to the generals and go home. Clinton's willingness to meet with everyone, hostile or not, has made a big impression – and because she's Hillary Clinton, with a real history of affinity for this country, it means so much more."<ref name="time-stateof" />
On the same trip, Clinton visited the Middle East, in an effort to restart the [[Israeli–Palestinian peace process]]. <!-- This needs more, need to sort this mess out -->
In November 2009, Secretary Clinton led the U.S. delegation at the [[Berlin Wall#20th Anniversary celebrations|20th anniversary celebrations]] of the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politicsdaily.com/2009/11/06/hillary-clinton-to-lead-u-s-delegation-at-berlin-wall/ |title=Hillary Clinton To Lead U.S. Delegation At Berlin Wall |author=Weber, Christopher |newspaper=[[Politics Daily]] |date=November 6, 2009}}</ref> There, she said: "Our history did not end the night the wall came down, it began anew. ... To expand freedom to more people, we cannot accept that freedom does not belong to all people. We cannot allow oppression defined and justified by religion or tribe to replace that of ideology."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/6527791/Berlin-Wall-anniversary-Hillary-Clinton-calls-for-greater-freedom-throughout-the-world.html |title=Berlin Wall anniversary: Hillary Clinton calls for greater freedom throughout the world |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=November 8, 2009 |location=London}}</ref>
In December 2009, Clinton attended the [[Copenhagen United Nations Climate Change Conference]], where she pushed forward a last-minute proposal of significant new amounts of foreign aid to help developing countries deal with the effects of global warming, in an attempt to unstick stuck negotiations and salvage some sort of agreement at the conference.<ref name="wapo121809">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/17/AR2009121700165.html |title=U.S. pledges aid, urges developing nations to cut emissions |first=Juliet |last=Eilperin |first2=Anthony |last2=Faiola |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date= December 18, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1209/30723.html |title=Hillary Clinton tries to save Copenhagen talks |author=Thrush, Glenn |newspaper=[[Politico]] |date=December 17, 2009}}</ref> The secretary said, "We're running out of time. Without the accord, the opportunity to mobilize significant resources to assist developing countries with mitigation and adaptation will be lost."<ref name="wapo121809" /> The amount of aid she proposed, $100 billion, was in the modest terms of the [[Copenhagen Accord]] that was agreed to by the summit.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/34475636/ns/us_news-environment/ |title=U.S., others broker modest climate deal |publisher=[[msnbc.com]] |date=December 19, 2009}}</ref>
Secretary Clinton finished the year with very high approval ratings.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1209/30679.html |title=Poll: Clinton approval soars |author=Javers, Eamon |newspaper=[[Politico]] |date=December 16, 2009}}</ref> She also narrowly edged out former Alaska Governor [[Sarah Palin]] in being [[Gallup's most admired man and woman poll|America's most-admired woman, per a Gallup finding]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2009-12-29-admire-gallup-poll_N.htm |title=Poll: Americans most admire Obama, Clinton, Palin |author=Page, Susan |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=December 30, 2009}}</ref>
==Regional issues and travels: 2010== [[File:ClintonAmorim.JPG|right|thumb|Secretary Clinton met with [[Celso Amorim]], [[Foreign Minister of Brazil]], in March 2010 at the [[Palácio do Itamaraty]] in [[Brasília]]]] In January 2010, Secretary Clinton cut short a trip to the [[Asia-Pacific]] region in order to see firsthand the destructive effects of the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]] and to meet with President of Haiti [[René Préval]].<ref name=hillarytohaiti>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE60E5NA20100115?type=politicsNews|title=Hillary Clinton to go to Haiti on Saturday |agency=Reuters|date=January 15, 2010 |first=Andrew |last=Quinn}}</ref> Clinton said she would also evaluate the relief effort and help evacuate some Americans. She stressed that her visit was designed not to interfere with ongoing efforts: "It's a race against time. Everybody is pushing as hard as they can."<ref name=hillarytohaiti /> The Clintons had a special interest in Haiti going back decades, to their delayed honeymoon there<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/more-info/story/1001856.html |title=Clintons honeymoon in Haiti |work=[[The Miami Herald]]|date=April 2009}} {{dead link|date=April 2012}}</ref> up to Bill Clinton being the United Nations Special Envoy to Haiti at the time of the earthquake.
In a major speech on January 21, 2010, Clinton, speaking on behalf of the U.S., declared that "We stand for a single Internet where all of humanity has equal access to knowledge and ideas", while highlighting how "even in authoritarian countries, information networks are helping people discover new facts and making governments more accountable."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2010/01/135519.htm |title=Remarks on Internet Freedom |publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]] |accessdate=December 18, 2010 |author=Clinton, Hillary Rodham |date=January 21, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103202130/https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2010/01/135519.htm |archivedate=January 3, 2014}}</ref> She also drew analogies between the [[Iron Curtain]] and the free and unfree Internet.<ref name="lat012310" /> Her speech, which followed a controversy surrounding [[Google]]'s changed policy toward [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|China and censorship]], appears to mark a split between authoritarian capitalism and the Western model of free capitalism and Internet access.<ref name="lat012310">{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation-and-world/la-fg-google-china23-2010jan23,0,3919601.story |title=Sino-U.S. ties hit new snag over Internet issues |first=Paul |last=Richter |first2=David |last2=Pierson |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=January 23, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.opendemocracy.net/johnny-ryan-stefan-halper/google-vs-china-capitalist-model-virtual-wall|title=Google vs China: capitalist model, virtual wall|publisher=[[OpenDemocracy]]|date=January 22, 2010|first=Johnny |last=Ryan |first2=Stefan |last2=Halper}}</ref> Chinese officials responded strongly, saying Clinton's remarks were "harmful to Sino-American relations" and demanded that U.S. officials "respect the truth", and some foreign policy observers thought that Clinton had been too provocative.<ref name="lat012310" /> But the White House stood behind Clinton, and demanded that China provide better answers regarding the [[Operation Aurora|recent Chinese cyberattack against Google]].<ref name="nyt012210">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/23/world/asia/23china.html |title=China Rebuffs Clinton on Internet Warning |first=Mark |last=Landler |first2=Edward |last2=Wong |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 22, 2010}}</ref> Clinton's speech garnered marked attention among diplomats, as it was the first time a senior American official had clearly put forth a vision in which the Internet was a key element of American foreign policy.<ref name="nyt012210" />
By early 2010, the Obama administration's efforts towards forging a new relationship with Iran had failed to gain headway, and the U.S. adopted a policy of adopting international sanctions against it and isolating it diplomatically in order to curtail the [[Nuclear program of Iran|that country's nuclear program]].<ref name="nyt-021710-iran">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/17/world/middleeast/17diplo.html |title=Iran Policy Now More in Sync With Clinton's Views |first=Mark |last=Landler |newspaper=The New York Times |date=February 16, 2010}}</ref> This was a policy more in line with Clinton's thinking and went back to disagreements she and Obama had had during the 2008 presidential campaign.<ref name="nyt-021710-iran" /> Clinton was put in charge of rallying support in the United Nations for these sanctions<ref name="nyt-021710-iran" /> and spent considerable time over the following months and years doing so.<ref name="nytm-rock" /><ref name="pol-hrc-iran">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/07/hillary-clinton-iran-nuclear-deal-120078.html |title=Hillary Clinton endorses nuclear deal |first=Michael |last=Crowley |work=Politico |date=July 14, 2015}}</ref> At times Clinton suggested the possibility of military action against Iran should economic and diplomatic actions fail to deter it from its nuclear ambitions.<ref name="pol-hrc-iran" />
In February 2010, Clinton made her first visit to Latin America as secretary. The tour would take her to Uruguay, Chile, Brazil, Costa Rica and Guatemala and Argentina. She first visited [[Buenos Aires]] and talked to Argentine President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]]. They discussed [[Falkland Islands sovereignty dispute|Falkland Islands sovereignty]] and the issue of oil in the Falklands.<ref name="cnn030210">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/03/02/falkland.clinton/index.html |title=Clinton pushes talks in Falklands dispute |publisher=CNN |date=March 2, 2010 |accessdate=March 2, 2010}}</ref> Clinton said that "We would like to see Argentina and the United Kingdom sit down and resolve the issues between them across the table in a peaceful, productive way."<ref name="cnn030210" /> Clinton offered to help facilitate such discussions, but did not agree to an Argentinian request that she mediate such talks.<ref name="cnn030210" /><ref name="bbc030210">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8544634.stm |title=UK rejects Hillary Clinton's help in Falklands dispute |publisher=BBC News |date=March 2, 2010 |accessdate=March 2, 2010}}</ref> Within 12 hours of Clinton's remarks, [[Downing Street]] categorically rejected a U.S. role: "We welcome the support of the secretary of state in terms of ensuring that we continue to keep diplomatic channels open but there is no need for [direct involvement]."<ref name="bbc030210" /> Clinton then went on to [[Santiago]], Chile to witness the aftereffects of the [[2010 Chile earthquake]] and to bring some telecommunications equipment to aid in the rescue and recovery efforts.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Americas/2010/0302/Chile-earthquake-Hillary-Clinton-arrives-with-satellite-phones |title=Chile earthquake: Hillary Clinton arrives with satellite phones |author=Llana, Sara Miller |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=March 2, 2010}}</ref>
In April 2010, there was a flurry of speculation that Clinton would be nominated to the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] to fill the vacancy created by Justice [[John Paul Stevens]]' retirement, including a plug from ranking [[Senate Judiciary Committee]] member [[Orrin Hatch]].<ref name="abc041310" /><ref name="pol041310">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0410/35686.html |title=A Hillary Clinton trial balloon's short flight |author=Ben Smith |authorlink=Ben Smith (journalist) |newspaper=[[Politico]] |date=April 13, 2010}}</ref> The notion was quickly quashed by the White House, which said, "The president thinks Secretary Clinton is doing an excellent job as secretary of state and wants her to remain in that position."<ref name="abc041310">{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Supreme_Court/obamas-supreme-court-short-list-includes-women/story?id=10359170 |title=Obama's Supreme Court Short List Includes Six Women |author=Tapper, Jake |authorlink=Jake Tapper |work=[[Good Morning America]] |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=April 13, 2010}}</ref> A State Department spokesperson said that Clinton "loves her present job and is not looking for another one."<ref name="pol041310" />
By mid-2010, Clinton and Obama had clearly forged a good working relationship without power struggles; she was a team player within the administration and a defender of it to the outside, and was careful to make sure that neither she nor her husband would upstage him.<ref name="elle-2012" /><ref name="nyt-relat">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/19/us/politics/19policy.html |title=From Bitter Campaign to Strong Alliance |author=Landler, Mark |author2=Cooper, Helene |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 19, 2010}}</ref> He in turn was accommodating to her viewpoints and in some cases adopted some of her more hawkish approaches.<ref name="nyt-relat" /> She met with him weekly, but did not have the close, daily relationship that some of her predecessors had had with their presidents, such as [[Condoleezza Rice]] with [[George W. Bush]], [[James Baker]] with [[George H. W. Bush]], or [[Henry Kissinger]] with [[Richard Nixon]].<ref name="nyt-relat" /> Nevertheless, he had trust in her actions.<ref name="nytm-rock" />
During an early June 2010 visit to [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], and [[Peru]], Clinton dealt with questions at every stop about the recently passed and widely controversial [[Arizona SB 1070]] anti-illegal immigration law, which had damaged the image of the U.S. in Latin America.<ref name="nyt061810" /> When answering a question from local television reporters in [[Quito]] about it, she said that President Obama was opposed to it and that "The Justice Department, under his direction, will be bringing a lawsuit against the act."<ref name="nyt061810">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/19/us/politics/19arizona.html |title=Justice Dept. Will Fight Arizona on Immigration |author=Archibold, Randal C. |author2=Landler, Mark |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 18, 2010}}</ref> This was the first public confirmation that the Justice Department would act against the law;<ref name="nyt061810" /> a month later, it became official as the lawsuit ''[[United States of America v. Arizona]]''. While at a hotel bar in [[Lima]], she completed an agreement with a representative of China over which companies could be specified in a UN resolution sanctioning the [[nuclear program of Iran]].<ref name="nyt-me-test" /> Returning to SB 1070, in August 2010 she included the dispute over it in a report to the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]], as an example to other countries of how fractious issues can be resolved under the rule of law.<ref name="fox083010">{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/08/30/state-department-stands-decision-include-arizona-human-rights-report/ |title=State Department Stands By Decision to Include Arizona in U.N. Human Rights Report |publisher=[[Fox News]] |date=August 30, 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Clinton and Gates on DMZ.png|left|thumb|Clinton and [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]] tour the [[Korean Demilitarized Zone|DMZ]] on July 21, 2010.]] In July 2010, Clinton visited Pakistan for the second time as secretary, announcing a large new U.S. economic assistance package to that country as well as a U.S.-led bilateral trade agreement between Pakistan and Afghanistan.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/07/18/AR2010071803086.html |title=U.S. hopes Afghanistan-Pakistan trade deal boosts cooperation in war effort |author=DeYoung, Karen |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 19, 2010}}</ref> She then traveled to Afghanistan for the [[Kabul Conference, 2010|Kabul Conference]] on the situation there, during which President [[Hamid Karzai]] vowed to implement much-promised legal, political, and economic reforms in exchange for a continued Western commitment there.<ref name="wapobg072110">{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/asia/articles/2010/07/21/karzai_pledge_gets_international_endorsement/ |title=Karzai pledge gets international endorsement |author=DeYoung, Karen |author2=Partlow, Joshua |agency=''[[The Washington Post]]'' |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=July 21, 2010}}</ref> Clinton said that despite the scheduled U.S. drawdown there in 2011, the U.S. has "no intention of abandoning our long-term mission of achieving a stable, secure, peaceful Afghanistan. Too many nations – especially Afghanistan – have suffered too many losses to see this country slide backward."<ref name="wapobg072110" /> She then went on to [[Seoul]] and the [[Korean Demilitarized Zone]] where she and Defense Secretary [[Robert Gates]] met with South Korean Foreign Minister [[Yu Myung-hwan]] and Minister of National Defense [[Kim Tae-Young (R.O.K. Army general)|Kim Tae-young]] in a '2+2 meeting' to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the [[Korean War]]. There she said that the U.S. experience in staying in Korea for decades had led to a successful result, which might also be applicable to Afghanistan.<ref name="nyt072310" /> Finally, she went to [[Hanoi]], [[Vietnam]], for the [[ASEAN Regional Forum]], wrapping up what ''[[The New York Times]]'' termed "a grueling trip that amounted to a tour of American wars, past and present".<ref name="nyt072310">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/24/world/asia/24diplo.html |title=Offering to Aid Talks, U.S. Challenges China on Disputed Islands |author=Landler, Mark |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 23, 2010}}</ref> There she injected the U.S. into the long-running disputes over the sovereignty of the [[Paracel Islands]] and [[Spratly Islands]], much to the displeasure of the Chinese who view the [[South China Sea]] as part of their core interests, by saying "The United States has a national interest in freedom of navigation, open access to Asia's maritime commons and respect for international law in the South China Sea."<ref name="nyt072310" />
By this time, Secretary Clinton was quite busy with another role of a kind, "M.O.T.B." as she wrote in State Department memos, making reference to her being the mother of the bride in daughter [[Chelsea Clinton]]'s July 31, 2010, wedding to Marc Mezvinsky.<ref name="nyt072510">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/26/nyregion/26rhinebeck.html |title=Wedding Is Talk of the Town, but Nobody's Talking |author=Foderaro, Lisa W. |author2=Haughney, Christine |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 25, 2010}}</ref> She confessed in an interview in [[Islamabad]] less than two weeks before the wedding that she and her husband were both nervous wrecks, and that "You should assume that if he makes it down the aisle in one piece it's going to be a major accomplishment. He is going to be so emotional, as am I."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2010/07/19/2010-07-19_bill_and_i_are_nervous_wrecks_hillary_clinton_says_of_daughter_chelseas_upcoming.html#ixzz0vEGaG4b9 |title=Bill and I are nervous wrecks, Hillary Clinton says of daughter Chelsea's upcoming wedding |agency=[[Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[New York Daily News]] |date=July 19, 2010}}</ref> The event itself gained a large amount of media attention.<ref name="nyt072510" />
In a September 2010 speech before the [[Council on Foreign Relations]], Clinton emphasized the continuing primacy of American power and involvement in the world, declaring a "new American moment".<ref name="nyt-cfr10">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/09/world/09diplo.html |title=In a Speech on Policy, Clinton Revives a Theme of American Power |author=Landler, Mark |authorlink=Mark Landler |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 9, 2010 |page=A8}}</ref> Making reference to actions from reviving the Middle East talks to U.S. aid following the [[2010 Pakistan floods]], Clinton said that "The world is counting on us" and that "After years of war and uncertainty, people are wondering what the future holds, at home and abroad. So let me say it clearly: The United States can, must, and will lead in this new century."<ref name="nyt-cfr10" />
With Democrats facing possible large losses in the [[United States elections, 2010|2010 midterm elections]] and President Obama struggling in opinion polls, idle speculation in Washington media circles concerning Obama's chances in the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]] led to the notion that Clinton would take over as Obama's vice-presidential running mate in 2012 to add to his electoral appeal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2010-08-12/obama-needs-hillary-clinton-as-vp-to-win-in-2012/?cid=hp:mainpromo2 |title=Obama Needs Hillary Clinton as VP to Win in 2012 |author=Varadarajan, Tunku |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=August 12, 2010}}</ref> Some versions of this idea had Vice President Biden replacing her as Secretary of State if Obama won.<ref name="nyt-cfr10" /><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704388504575419421407147424 |title=Hillary for Vice President? |author=Fund, John |authorlink = John Fund |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=August 10, 2010}}</ref> That it would ever happen was unlikely,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/blogs/the-gaggle/2010/08/12/don-t-believe-the-hillary-for-vp-meme.html |title=Don't Believe the Hillary Clinton–for–VP Meme |work=[[Newsweek]], The Gaggle |date=August 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815235141/http://www.newsweek.com/blogs/the-gaggle/2010/08/12/don-t-believe-the-hillary-for-vp-meme.html |archivedate=2010-08-15 |accessdate=October 4, 2013}}</ref> but did not stop the chatter; when the job swap idea was mentioned in public to Clinton, she smiled and shook her head.<ref name="nyt-cfr10" /> A couple of months later, Obama shot down the idea, saying the notion was "completely unfounded" and that "they are both doing outstanding jobs where they are."<ref>{{cite news |title=Obama says he's sticking with Biden |work=[[USA Today]]: [[Asbury Park Press]] |date=October 20, 2010 |page=A8}}</ref> (In late 2011, however, with Obama's popularity on the decline, White House Chief of Staff [[William M. Daley]] did conduct some research into the idea of Clinton replacing Biden, but the notion was dropped when the results showed no appreciable improvement for Obama.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/01/us/politics/book-details-consideration-of-replacing-biden-on-2012-ticket.html |title=Book Details Obama Aides' Talks About Replacing Biden on 2012 Ticket |author=Martin, Jonathan |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 31, 2013}}</ref>)
[[File:Clinton Netanyahu Abbas Mitchell 2 Sep 2010.jpg|thumb|right|Clinton at the [[Harry S Truman Building|Department of State building]] with President [[Mahmoud Abbas]] of the Palestinian Authority, Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] of Israel, and U.S. Special Envoy [[George J. Mitchell]], at the start of direct talks on September 2, 2010]] Over the summer of 2010, the stalled [[Israeli–Palestinian peace process]] was potentially revived when the various parties involved agreed to direct talks for the first time in a while.<ref name="ap090110">{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wirestory?id=11523733&page=1 |title=Obama Opens Long-Shot Talks on Mideast Peace |author=Burns, Robert |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=September 1, 2010}}</ref> While President Obama was the orchestrator of the movement, Secretary Clinton had gone through months of cajoling just to get the parties to the table, and helped convince the reluctant Palestinians by getting support for direct talks from Egypt and Jordan.<ref name="nyt-me-test" /><ref name="ap090110" /> She then assumed a prominent role in the talks; Speaking at a September 2 meeting at the State Department between Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] of Israel and President [[Mahmoud Abbas]] of the Palestinian Authority, she acknowledged that, "We've been here before, and we know how difficult the road ahead will be."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/03/world/middleeast/03diplo.html |title=Settlements in West Bank Are Clouding Peace Talks |author=Landler, Mark |authorlink=Mark Landler |author2=Cooper, Helene |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 2, 2010}}</ref> Her role in the ongoing talks would be to take over from U.S. Special Envoy for Middle East Peace [[George J. Mitchell]] when discussions threatened to break down.<ref name="nyt-me-test">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/05/world/middleeast/05clinton.html |title=In Middle East Peace Talks, Clinton Faces a Crucial Test |author=Landler, Mark |authorlink = Mark Landler |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 5, 2010 |page=A1}}</ref> The talks were generally given little chance to succeed, and Clinton faced the history of many such past failures, including the near miss of her husband at the [[2000 Camp David Summit]].<ref name="nyt-me-test" /> Nevertheless, her prominent role in them thrust her further into the international spotlight and had the potential to affect her legacy as secretary.<ref name="nyt-me-test" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/mideast-peace-talks-hillary-clinton-takes-lead-israeli/story?id=11538162&page=1 |title=Eyes on Hillary Clinton as She Leads Mideast Peace Talks |author=Tapper, Jake |authorlink=Jake Tapper |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=September 2, 2010}}</ref>
In October, Clinton embarked on a seven-nation tour of Asia and Oceania. In New Zealand she signed the "Wellington Declaration", which normalized the diplomatic and military relationship between it and the United States.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/4310540/Clinton-crushes-25-years-of-ice |title=Clinton crushes 25 years of ice |author=Watkins, Tracy |date=November 5, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Dominion Post (Wellington)|The Dominion Post]] |location=Wellington}}</ref> The signing marked twenty-five years after the United States suspended [[ANZUS]] treaty obligations with New Zealand in the wake of the ''[[USS Buchanan (DDG-14)|USS Buchanan]]'' incident.
Clinton maintained her high approval ratings during 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/1618/Favorability-People-News.aspx#2 |title=Favorability: People in the News: Hillary Clinton |publisher=[[Gallup Poll]] |accessdate=December 6, 2010}}</ref> An aggregation of polls taken during the late portion or all of 2010 showed that Clinton (and her husband as well) had by far the best favorable-unfavorable ratings of any key contemporary American political figure.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/11/17/is-pelosi-americas-most-unpopular-politician/#more-3615 |title=Is Pelosi America's Most Unpopular Politician? |author=Silver, Nate |authorlink=Nate Silver |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 17, 2010}}</ref>
In late November, [[United States diplomatic cables leak|WikiLeaks released confidential State Department cables]], selections of which were then published by several major newspapers around the world. The leak of the cables led to a crisis atmosphere in the State Department, as blunt statements and assessments by U.S. and foreign diplomats became public.<ref name="wapo-dctl">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/11/29/AR2010112906258.html |title=Clinton treads carefully in leading massive damage-control campaign |author=Sheridan, Mary Beth |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 30, 2010}}</ref> Clinton led the damage control effort for the U.S. abroad, and also sought to bolster the morale of shocked Foreign Service officers.<ref name="wapo-dctl" /> In the days leading up to the publication of the cables, Clinton called officials in Germany, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Britain, France, Afghanistan, Canada, and China to alert them to the pending disclosures.<ref name="wapo-dctl" /> She did note that some foreign leaders were accepting of the frank language of the cables, with one telling her, "Don't worry about it. You should see what we say about you."<ref name="wapo-dctl" /><ref name="cnn-sweep" /> She harshly criticized [[WikiLeaks]], saying: "Let's be clear: This disclosure is not just an attack on America's foreign policy interests. It is an attack on the international community – the alliances and partnerships, the conversations and negotiations that safeguard global security and advance economic prosperity."<ref name="wapo-dctl" /> The State Department went into immediate "[[war room]]" mode in order to deal with the effects of the disclosures, and began implementing measures to try to prevent another such leak from happening in the future.<ref name="cnn-sweep" />
[[Spying on United Nations leaders by United States diplomats|A few of the cables released by WikiLeaks concerned Clinton directly]]: they revealed that directions to members of the foreign service had gone out in 2009 under Clinton's name to gather biometric details on foreign diplomats, including officials of the United Nations and U.S. allies.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/nov/28/us-embassy-cables-spying-un |title=US diplomats spied on UN leadership |author=Booth, Roger |author2= Borger, Julian|date=November 28, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=London}}</ref> These included Internet and intranet usernames, e-mail addresses, web site URLs useful for identification, credit card numbers, frequent flier account numbers, work schedules, and other targeted biographical information in a process known as the National Humint Collection Directive.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cables show US sought personal info of foreign diplomats at UN |date=November 29, 2010 |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-11-29/us/28233885_1_unsc-national-humint-collection-directive-foreign-diplomats |newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |agency=[[Press Trust of India]]}}</ref><ref name="nyt-cables">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/29/world/29spy.html |title=U.S. Expands Role of Diplomats in Spying |author=Mazzetti, Mark |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 28, 2010}}</ref> State Department spokesman [[Philip J. Crowley]] said that Clinton had not drafted the directive and that the Secretary of State's name is systematically attached to the bottom of cables originating from Washington;<ref>{{cite news |title=Arrest Warrant for WikiLeaks Chief as Chaos Spreads |author=Tandon, Shaun|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/international/americas/2010/12/02/282146/Arrest-warrant.htm |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|newspaper=[[The China Post]] |date=December 2, 2010 }}</ref> it was unclear whether Clinton had actually seen them.<ref name="nj-cables">{{cite news |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/whitehouse/hillary-clinton-didn-t-turn-diplomats-into-spies-20101130 |title=What Hillary Clinton Didn't Do |author=Ambinder, Marc |authorlink=Marc Ambinder |newspaper=[[National Journal]] |date=November 30, 2010}}</ref> The guidance in the cables was actually written by the [[CIA]] before being sent out under Clinton's name, as the CIA cannot directly instruct State Department personnel.<ref name="g-cia">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/02/wikileaks-cables-cia-united-nations |title=WikiLeaks cables: CIA drew up UN spying wishlist for diplomats |author=MacAskill, Ewen |author2=Booth, Robert |date=December 2, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=London}}</ref><ref name="lat-ignored">{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/wire/sc-dc-1203-wikileaks-spying-20101202,0,6105024.story |title=Diplomats ignored spying requests, former officials say |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=December 2, 2010 }} {{dead link|date=May 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> The disclosed cables on the more aggressive intelligence gathering went back to 2008 when they went out under [[Condoleezza Rice]]'s name during [[Condoleezza Rice's tenure as Secretary of State|her tenure as Secretary of State]].<ref name="nyt-cables" /> The practice of the U.S. and the State Department gathering intelligence on the U.N. or on friendly nations was not new,<ref name="nj-cables" /> but the surprise in this case was that it was done by other diplomats rather than intelligence agencies, and that the specific types of information being asked for went beyond past practice and was not the kind of information diplomats would normally be expected to gather.<ref name="nyt-cables" /><ref name="g-cia" /><ref name="lat-ignored" /><ref name="ClintonMeetsKimoon" /> In any case, the instructions given in these cables may have been largely ignored by American diplomats as ill-advised.<ref name="lat-ignored" /> Responding to calls from WikiLeaks founder [[Julian Assange]] and a few others that Clinton possibly step down from her post due to the revelation, White House Press Secretary [[Robert Gibbs]] said, "I think that is absurd and ridiculous. I think Secretary of State Clinton is doing a wonderful job."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2010/12/gibbs-defends-clinton-amid-wik.html |title=Gibbs defends Clinton amid WikiLeaks criticism |author=Bacon, Jr., Perry |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=December 1, 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Clinton at OSCE Summit Dec 2010.jpg|thumb|left|At this early December 2010 summit in Kazakhstan, Clinton dealt with the fallout from the [[United States diplomatic cables leak]].]] On December 1, Clinton flew to a summit of the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]] in [[Astana]], [[Kazakhstan]].<ref name="cnn-sweep">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/POLITICS/12/15/sweep.wikileaks/index.html |title=WikiLeaks stirs anarchy online |author=Dougherty, Jill |author2=Labott, Elise |work=The Sweep |publisher=CNN |date=December 16, 2010 |accessdate=December 25, 2010}}</ref><ref name="aus-summit" /> There she would encounter some fifty leaders who were subjects of embarrassing comments in the leaks, including [[President of Kazakhstan]] [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]].<ref name="cnn-sweep" /> A Kazakh official said that during such encounters, Clinton "kept her face. She didn't run away from difficult questions."<ref name="cnn-sweep" /> During the encounters she emphasized that the leaked cables did not reflect official U.S. policy but rather were just instances of individual diplomats giving unfiltered feedback to Washington about what they saw happening in other countries.<ref name="cnn-sweep" /> The situation led to some leaders turning her strong remarks about Internet freedom earlier in the year back against her.<ref name="cnn-sweep" /> The OSCE summit also featured a meeting between Secretary Clinton and [[Ban Ki-moon]], [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]].<ref name="aus-summit" /> In an attempt to repair the strain caused by the Humint spying relevations, Clinton expressed regret to Ban for the disclosures, but did not make an apology per se.<ref name="ClintonMeetsKimoon" /><ref name="aus-summit">{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/clinton-regrets-spying-on-ban-ki-moon/story-e6frg6so-1225965376272 |title=Hillary Clinton 'regrets' spying on Ban Ki-moon |author=Norington, Brad |newspaper=[[The Australian]] |date=December 4, 2010}}</ref> A U.N. statement relayed that Ban thanked Clinton "for clarifying the matter and for expressing her concern about the difficulties created."<ref name="ClintonMeetsKimoon">{{cite news |title=WikiLeaks Cables: Hillary Clinton Meets Ban Ki-Moon after Spying Revelations |first1=Ewen |last1=MacAskill |first2=Robert |last2=Booth |first3=Julian |last3=Borger |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/02/wikileaks-cables-hillary-clinton-ban |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=December 2, 2010|location=London}}</ref>
Upon the December 13 death of veteran U.S. diplomat [[Richard Holbrooke]] (who had initially fallen ill during a meeting with her), Clinton presided over a spontaneous gathering of some forty senior State Department personnel and Holbrooke aides at [[George Washington University Hospital]], reminiscing about him.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/laurarozen/1210/Clinton_aides_gather_to_remember_Holbrooke.html |title=Clinton, aides gather to remember Holbrooke |author=Rozen, Laura |newspaper=[[Politico]] |date=December 13, 2010}}</ref> At a memorial service for him days later, both Clinton and her husband praised Holbrooke's work, and she said, "Everything that we have accomplished that is working in Afghanistan and Pakistan is largely because of Richard."<ref name="nyt-hol">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/18/nyregion/18holbrooke.html |title=Sharing Stories of a Man Who Loved Big Challenges |author=Otterman, Sharon |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 17, 2010}}</ref> As it happened, however, Holbrooke had developed poor relations with the White House during his time as Afghanistan envoy, and Clinton's vision of him forging an agreement in that country that modeled the success of his prior [[Dayton Accords]] (that resolved the [[Bosnian War]]) were unrealized.<ref name="nyt-backstage" />
On December 22, 2010, Secretary Clinton returned to the floor of the Senate during the lame-duck session of the [[111th Congress]] to witness the ratification, by a 71–26 margin, of the [[New START treaty]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2010/12/us_senate_votes.html |title=US Senate votes to ratify New START arms treaty |author=Arsenault, Mark |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=December 22, 2010}}</ref> Clinton had spent the several days beforehand repeatedly calling wavering senators and seeking to gain their support.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20101221/pl_afp/russiausnucleartreatypolitics_20101221022406 |title=Obama woos senators on START nuclear treaty |author=Knox, Olivier |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] |date=December 20, 2010}}</ref>
As the year closed, Clinton was again named by Americans in [[Gallup's most admired man and woman poll]] as the woman around the world they most admired; it was her ninth win in a row and fifteenth overall.<ref name="g10">{{cite web |url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/145394/Barack-Obama-Hillary-Clinton-2010-Admired.aspx? |title=Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton Are 2010's Most Admired |publisher=[[The Gallup Organization]] |date=December 27, 2010 |accessdate=December 27, 2010}}</ref>
==Regional issues and travels: 2011== [[File:Dilma Rousseff and Hillary Clinton 2010.jpg|thumb|right|Clinton and President of Brazil [[Dilma Rousseff]] at the [[First inauguration of Dilma Rousseff|inauguration of Dilma Rousseff]], January 1, 2011]] Secretary Clinton began the year 2011 abroad, attending the [[First inauguration of Dilma Rousseff|inauguration of Dilma Rousseff]] in Brazil, having been sent by President Obama to represent the U.S.<ref name="Ter">{{pt icon}} [http://noticias.terra.com.br/brasil/noticias/0,,OI4849683-EI7896,00-Posse+de+Dilma+tem+chefes+de+Estado+e+governo+confirmados.html "Posse de Dilma tem 14 chefes de Estado e governo confirmados"]. [[Terra Networks|Terra]]. December 17, 2010. Retrieved December 22, 2010.</ref><ref>{{pt icon}} [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]. [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gaiNYDVbshlaMNTogH0pUbgHWeoA?docId=CNG.cec7058894b65a7fc966da18da068122.2a1 "Hillary confirma presença na posse de Dilma"]. [[Google News]]. December 21, 2010. Retrieved December 22, 2010.</ref> Rousseff was the first woman to rule that country. While there, she ran into Venezuelan ruler and U.S. antagonist [[Hugo Chávez]], but the two had a pleasant exchange; Chávez said "She had a very spontaneous smile and I greeted her with the same effusiveness."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/01/02/Hillary-bumps-into-Hugo-Chavez-in-Brazil/UPI-19601293994589/ | title=Hillary bumps into Hugo Chavez in Brazil | agency=United Press International | date=January 2, 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Hillary Rodham Clinton in Doha Jan 2011.jpg|thumb|left|Secretary Clinton conversing with [[United Arab Emirates]] Foreign Minister Sheikh [[Abdullah bin Zayed al-Nahyan]] prior to a [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] meeting in [[Doha]] in January 2011.]]
In mid-January, Clinton made a four-country trip to the Middle East, visiting [[Yemen]], [[Oman]], [[The United Arab Emirates]], and [[Qatar]].<ref name="nyt-me5" /> Speaking at a conference in [[Doha]], she criticized Arab governments' failure to move more rapidly vis à vis reform in unusually blunt language, saying, "In too many places, in too many ways, the region's foundations are sinking into the sand. The new and dynamic Middle East that I have seen needs firmer ground if it is to take root and grow everywhere."<ref name="nyt-me5">{{cite news | url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/14/world/middleeast/14diplo.html | title=Clinton Bluntly Presses Arab Leaders on Reform | author=Landler, Mark | newspaper=The New York Times | date=January 13, 2011 | accessdate=January 15, 2011}}</ref> Her visit to Yemen, the first such visit by a Secretary of State in 20 years, found her focusing on the dangers of [[Terrorism in Yemen|terrorism emanating from that country]].<ref name="nyt-sanaa">{{cite news | url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/12/world/middleeast/12diplo.html | title=Clinton Addresses Terrorism and Politics in Yemen | author=Landler, Mark | newspaper=The New York Times | date=January 11, 2011 | accessdate=January 15, 2011}}</ref> An impromptu tour around the walled old city of [[Sana'a]] found Clinton being cheered by onlooking schoolchildren.<ref name="nyt-sanaa" /> A trip and fall while boarding the departing airplane left Clinton unhurt but news services making predictable witticisms.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://thecable.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/01/12/media_races_to_cover_clinton_s_trip_in_yemen | title=Media races to cover Clinton's 'trip' in Yemen | author=Rogin, Josh | magazine=[[Foreign Policy]] | date=January 12, 2011 | accessdate=January 15, 2011}}</ref>
When the [[2011 Egyptian protests]] began, Clinton was in the forefront of the administration's response.<ref name="usa020211">{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2011-02-02-Hillary02_ST_N.htm | title=Clinton stays on message as Egypt evolves | author=Hall, Mimi | author2=Wolf, Richard | author3=Jackson, David | newspaper=[[USA Today]] | date=February 2, 2011 | accessdate=February 4, 2011}}</ref> Her initial public assessment on January 25 that the government of President [[Hosni Mubarak]] was "stable" and "looking for ways to respond to the legitimate needs and interests of the Egyptian people"<ref name="reut-evol">{{cite news | url=https://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFN0219913120110202?sp=true | title=Factbox – Evolution of U.S. stance on Egypt | agency=Reuters| date=February 2, 2011 | accessdate=February 4, 2011}}</ref> soon came under criticism for being tepid and behind the curve of developing events, although others agreed that the U.S. could not be out front in undermining the government of a long-term ally.<ref name="usa020211" /> By the next day, Clinton was criticizing the Egyptian government's blocking of [[social media]] sites.<ref name="reut-evol" /> By January 29, Obama had put Clinton in charge of sorting out the administration's so-far confused response to developments.<ref name="pol-egypt-hrc" /> During the frenetic day of January 30, she combined appearances on all five [[Sunday morning talk shows]] – where she stated publicly for the first time the U.S.'s view that there needed to be an "orderly transition" to a "democratic participatory government"<ref name="reut-evol" /> and a "peaceful transition to real democracy", not Mubarak's "faux democracy"<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0111/48433.html | title=Hillary Clinton calls for 'real democracy' in Egypt | author=Smith, Ben | author2=Tau, Byron | newspaper=[[Politico]] | date=January 31, 2011 | accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> – with a flight to Haiti and back to mark the anniversary of its terrible earthquake, all the while engaging in conference calls again regarding Egypt.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/31/egypt-haiti-make-for-marathon-sunday-for-clinton/ | title=Egypt, Haiti make for marathon Sunday for Clinton | author=Brusk, Steve | publisher=CNN | date=January 31, 2011 | accessdate=February 4, 2011}}</ref>
The Egyptian protests became the most critical foreign policy crisis so far for the Obama administration, and Obama came to increasingly rely upon Clinton for advice and connections.<ref name="pol-egypt-hrc">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0211/48658.html |title=Hillary Clinton plays key role in dance with Hosni Mubarak |author=Thrush, Glenn |newspaper=[[Politico]] |date=February 2, 2011 |accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> Clinton had known Mubarak for some twenty years, and had formed a close relationship with Egyptian First Lady [[Suzanne Mubarak]] by supporting the latter's human rights work.<ref name="pol-egypt-hrc" /> Clinton originated the idea of sending [[Frank G.
