Wisner]] as an emissary to Cairo, to tell Mubarak not to seek another term as the country's leader.<ref name="pol-egypt-hrc" /> As Mubarak's response to the protests became violent in early February, Clinton strongly condemned the actions taking place, especially those against journalists covering the events, and urged new Egyptian Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] to conduct an official investigation to hold those responsible for the violence accountable.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2011/02/04/Clinton-blasts-Cairo-attack-on-journalists/UPI-82071296808200/ |title=Clinton blasts Cairo attack on journalists |agency=[[United Press International]] |date=February 4, 2011 |accessdate=February 4, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/International/04-Feb-2011/Hillary-urges-probe-into-new-Cairo-violence |title=Hillary urges probe into new Cairo violence |newspaper=[[The Nation (Pakistani newspaper)|The Nation]] |location=Lahore |date=February 4, 2011 |accessdate=February 4, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511071152/http://nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/International/04-Feb-2011/Hillary-urges-probe-into-new-Cairo-violence |archive-date=May 11, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> When Wisner baldly stated that Mubarak's departure should be delayed to accommodate an orderly transition to another government, Clinton rebuked him, but shared a bit of the same sentiment.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/02/07/administration-drop-kicks-ambassador-remarks-mubarak-echoes-sentiment/ |title=Administration Drop Kicks Ambassador for Remarks on Mubarak, but Echoes Sentiment |publisher=[[Fox News]] |date=February 7, 2011 |accessdate=March 2, 2011}}</ref> Mubarak did finally step down on February 11 as the protests became the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]. Clinton said that the U.S. realized that Egypt still had much work and some difficult times ahead of it.<ref name="ynn-predict" /> In mid-March, Clinton visited Egypt and indicated support for an Egyptian move towards democracy, but she avoided specific issues of U.S. aid and when elections should take place.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/15/us-egypt-usa-idUSTRE71175920110315 |publisher=Reuters |title=Clinton backs post-Mubarak Egypt, hears criticism |date=March 15, 2011}}</ref>
President Obama was reportedly unhappy with U.S. intelligence agencies following their failure to foresee the [[2010–2011 Tunisian uprising]] and the downfall of [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] as well as the Egyptian protests.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/04/world/main7317044.shtml |title=Obama "Disappointed" by Intel on Arab Unrest |author=Dozier, Kimberly |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=February 4, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref> Responding to criticism that the State Department had failed to see the developments in Egypt coming, Clinton defended the U.S. in an interview on [[Al-Arabiya]], saying "I don't think anybody could have predicted we'd be sitting here talking about the end of the Mubarak presidency at the time that this all started."<ref name="ynn-predict">{{cite news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4028743,00.html |title=Clinton: We couldn't have predicted Mubarak's downfall |author=Benhorin, Yitzhak |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=March 2, 2011}}</ref>
Reflecting on not just the situation in Tunisia and Egypt but also on the [[2011 Yemeni protests]], and the [[2011 Jordanian protests]], Clinton said at a February 5 meeting of the [[Quartet on the Middle East]], "The region is being battered by a perfect storm of powerful trends. ... This is what has driven demonstrators into the streets of ... cities throughout the region. The status quo is simply not sustainable." She said that while transition to democracy could be chaotic – and free elections had to be accompanied by free speech, a free judiciary, and the rule of law in order to be effective – in the end "free people govern themselves best".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12372983 |title=Hillary Clinton: Middle East facing 'perfect storm' |publisher=BBC News |date=February 5, 2011 |accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> The transformations highlighted that traditional U.S. foreign policy in the region had sided with rulers who suppressed internal dissent but provided stability and generally supported U.S. goals in the region.<ref name="afp-bah">{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5inJi1jMn1TGVvxak0qubKgy0CRzg?docId=CNG.5ff705d1bb699953d27412f47c096871.dd1 |title=Clinton urges restraint, reform in Bahrain |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=February 20, 2011 |accessdate=March 2, 2011}}</ref> When the monarchy's response to the [[2011 Bahraini protests]] turned violent, Clinton urged a return to the path of reform, saying that violence against the protesters "is absolutely unacceptable ... We very much want to see the human rights of the people protected, including right to assemble, right to express themselves, and we want to see reform."<ref name="afp-bah" /> At the same time, she said that the U.S. "cannot tell countries what they are going to do [and] cannot dictate the outcomes."<ref name="afp-bah" /> As the situation in Bahrain lingered on and continued to have episodes of violence against protesters, Clinton said in mid-March, "Our goal is a credible political process that can address the legitimate aspirations of all the people of Bahrain ... Violence is not and cannot be the answer. A political process is. We have raised our concerns about the current measures directly with Bahraini officials and will continue to do so."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/19/bahrain.unrest/ |title=Clinton concerned about Bahrain as 5th protester reported killed |publisher=CNN |date=March 19, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref>
When the [[2011 Libyan civil war]] began in mid-February and intensified into armed conflict with rebel successes in early March 2011, Clinton stated the administration's position that Libyan leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]] "must go now, without further violence or delay".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12611925 |title=Hillary Clinton: Libya may become democracy or face civil war |publisher=BBC News |date=March 1, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref> As Gaddafi conducted counterattacks against the rebels, Clinton was initially reluctant, as was Obama, to back calls being made in various quarters for imposition of a [[Libyan no-fly zone]].<ref name="nyt-libya-change">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/19/world/africa/19policy.html |title=Obama Takes Hard Line With Libya After Shift by Clinton |author=Cooper, Helene |author2=Myers, Steven Lee |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 18, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref><ref name="wapo-libya-change">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/obamas-shift-toward-military-action-in-libya/2011/03/18/ABiClIs_singlePage.html |title=Obama's shift toward military action in Libya |author=Wilson, Scott |author2=Warwick, Joby |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=March 19, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref> However, as the prospects of a Gaddafi victory and possible subsequent bloodbath that would kill many thousands emerged, and as Clinton travelled Europe and North Africa and found support for military intervention increasing among European and Arab leaders, she had a change of view.<ref name="nyt-libya-change" /><ref name="wapo-libya-change" /> Together with Ambassador to the U.N. [[Susan Rice]] and National Security Council figure [[Samantha Power]], who were already supporting military intervention, Clinton overcame opposition from Defense Secretary [[Robert Gates]], security advisor [[Thomas Donilon]], and counterterrorism advisor [[John O. Brennan|John Brennan]], and the administration backed U.N. action to impose the no-fly zone and authorize other military actions as necessary.<ref name="nyt-libya-change" /><ref name="pol-no-2nd" /> Clinton helped gained the financial and political support of several Arab countries,<ref name="nyt-libya-change" /><ref name="pol-libya-change">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0311/51583.html |title=Behind Barack Obama's turnaround on Libya |author=Thrush, Glenn |author2=Negrin, Matt |work=[[Politico]] |date=March 19, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref> in particular convincing Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, and Jordan that a no-fly zone urged by the [[Arab League]] would not be sufficient and that air-to-ground attacks would be necessary.<ref name="time-smart" /> Clinton then persuaded Russian Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] that his country should abstain on the UN resolution authorizing force against Gaddafi,<ref name="time-smart" /> and Rice and Clinton played major roles in getting the rest of the [[United Nations Security Council]] to approve [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973]].<ref name="nyt-libya-change" /><ref name="pol-libya-change" /> Regarding whether the U.S. or some other ally would send arms to the [[anti-Gaddafi forces]], Clinton said that this would be permissible under the resolution, but that no decision had yet been made on doing so.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/128223/20110329/hillary-clinton-united-states-london-conference-libya-rebels-arms.htm |title=Clinton Says No Decision Yet on Arming Libya Rebels |newspaper=[[International Business Times]] |date=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
Clinton testified to Congress in March that the administration did not need [[Declaration of war by the United States|congressional authorization]] for its military intervention in Libya or for further decisions about it, despite congressional objections from members of both parties that the administration was violating the [[War Powers Resolution]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/03/30/congress.libya.briefing/ |title=Congress members grill administration officials on Libya mission |publisher=CNN |date=March 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/152891-white-house-briefing-changes-few-minds-on-libya |title=White House briefing changes few minds on Libya involvement |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |author=Lillis, Mike |date=March 30, 2011|display-authors=etal}}</ref> During that classified briefing to Congress, she allegedly indicated that the administration would sidestep the Resolution's provision regarding a 60-day limit on unauthorized military actions.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://talkingpointsmemo.com/dc/clinton-to-congress-obama-would-ignore-your-war-resolutions?ref=fpblg |title=Clinton To Congress: Obama Would Ignore Your War Resolutions |work=Talking Points Memo |author=Crabtree, Susan |date=March 30, 2011}}</ref> Months later, she stated that, with respect to the military operation in Libya, the United States was still flying a quarter of the sorties, and ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that, while many presidents had bypassed other sections of the War Powers Resolution, there was little precedent for exceeding the 60-day statutory limit on unauthorized military actions – a limit which the Justice Department had said in 1980 was constitutional.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2011/05/26/world/middleeast/26powers.html|title=Libya Effort Is Called Violation of War Act |work=The New York Times|author=Charlie Savage |date=May 25, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/18/world/africa/18powers.html |title=2 Top Lawyers Lost to Obama in Libya War Policy Debate |work=New York Times |author=Savage, Charlie |date=June 17, 2011}}</ref> The State Department publicly took the position in June 2011 that there was no "hostility" in Libya within the meaning of the War Powers Resolution, contrary to legal interpretations by the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] and the [[Office of Legal Counsel|Department of Justice Office of Legal Counsel]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/president-overruled-2-key-lawyers-on-debate-over-libya-war-policy/ |title=President overruled 2 key lawyers on debate over Libya war policy |author=Savage, Charlie |date=June 18, 2011 |work=Seattle Times}}</ref><ref name=Cosgrove>Cosgrove, Maureen. [http://jurist.org/paperchase/2011/06/state-department-legal-adviser-obama-acting-lawfully-in-libya.php "State Department legal adviser: Obama acting lawfully in Libya"], [[JURIST]] (June 28, 2011).</ref> The State Department requested (but never received) express Congressional authorization.<ref name=Cosgrove /><ref>{{cite book |author=Owen, Robert |title=Precision and Purpose: Airpower in the Libyan Civil War |editor=Karl Mueller |page=105|publisher=Rand Corporation |year=2015 |chapter=The U.S. Experience: National Strategy and Campaign Support|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7RFDCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT105}}</ref> The US House of Representatives voted to rebuke the administration for maintaining an American presence with the NATO operations in Libya, which they considered a violation of the War Powers Resolution.<ref name="washingtontimes.com">Dinan, Stephen, [http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/jun/3/bipartisan-congress-rebuffs-obama-libya-mission/ "Bipartisan Congress rebuffs Obama on Libya mission"]. ''The Washington Times'', Saturday, June 4, 2011</ref><ref name="Steinhauer">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/04/world/africa/04policy.html|work=The New York Times|first=Jennifer|last=Steinhauer|title=House Rebukes Obama for Continuing Libyan Mission Without Its Consent|date=June 3, 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Hillary Rodham Clinton on Nessma in Tunis.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Secretary Clinton appearing on [[Nessma TV]] in [[Tunis]] in March 2011]] While Clinton recognized some of the contradictions of U.S. policy towards turmoil in the Mideast countries, which involving backing some regimes while supporting protesters against others,<ref name="nyt-libya-change" /> she was nevertheless passionate on the subject, enough so that Obama joked at the annual [[Gridiron Dinner]] that "I've dispatched Hillary to the Middle East to talk about how these countries can transition to new leaders—though, I've got to be honest, she's gotten a little passionate about the subject. These past few weeks it's been tough falling asleep with Hillary out there on Pennsylvania Avenue shouting, throwing rocks at the window."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thedaily.com/page/2011/03/17/031711-news-hillary-2-2/ |title=Oh, Hill No |author=Hersh, Joshua |newspaper=[[The Daily (News Corporation)|The Daily]] |date=March 17, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref> In any case, Obama's reference to Clinton travelling a lot was true enough; by now she had logged {{convert|465,000|mi|km}} in her [[Boeing 757]], more than any other Secretary of State for a comparable period of time, and had visited 79 countries while in the office.<ref name="nw-doctrine">{{cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2011/03/06/the-hillary-doctrine.html |title=The Hillary Doctrine |author=Lemmon, Gayle Tzemach |magazine=[[Newsweek]] |date=March 6, 2011 |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref> ''Time'' magazine wrote that "Clinton's endurance is legendary" and that she would still be going at the end of long work days even as her staff members were glazing out.<ref name="time-smart" /> The key was her ability to fall asleep on demand, at any time and place, for [[power nap]]s.<ref name="elle-2012" />
Clinton also saw the potential political changes in the Mideast as an opportunity for an even more fundamental change to take place, that being the empowerment of women (something ''[[Newsweek]]'' magazine saw as Clinton's [[categorical imperative]]).<ref name="nw-doctrine" /> She made remarks to this effect in countries such as Egypt – "If a country doesn't recognize minority rights and human rights, including women's rights, you will not have the kind of stability and prosperity that is possible" – as well as in Yemen, where she spoke of the story of the present [[Nujood Ali]] and her campaign against forced marriage at a young age.<ref name="nw-doctrine" /> At home, Clinton was even more expansive, looking on a worldwide basis: "I believe that the rights of women and girls is the unfinished business of the 21st century. We see women and girls across the world who are oppressed and violated and demeaned and degraded and denied so much of what they are entitled to as our fellow human beings."<ref name="nw-doctrine" /> She also maintained that the well-being of women in other countries was a direct factor in American self-interest: "This is a big deal for American values and for American foreign policy and our interests, but it is also a big deal for our security. Because where women are disempowered and dehumanized, you are more likely to see not just antidemocratic forces, but extremism that leads to security challenges for us."<ref name="nw-doctrine" /> She subsequently elaborated upon this theme, saying "A lot of the work I do here in the State Department on women's or human-rights issues is not just because I care passionately – which I do – but because I see it as [a way] to increase security to fulfill American interests. These are foreign-policy and national-security priorities for me."<ref name="elle-2012" />
In the midst of this turmoil, which also included Clinton pledging government-level support to Japan in the wake of the devastating [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://rafu.com/news/2011/03/u-s-officials-pledge-to-help-quake-tsunami-victims/ |title=U.S. Officials Pledge to Help Quake, Tsunami Victims |newspaper=[[Rafu Shimpo]] |date=March 11, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}</ref> Clinton reiterated in a mid-March CNN interview with [[Wolf Blitzer]] during her post-revolution visit to Cairo's [[Tahrir Square]] that she had no interest in becoming Secretary of Defense or vice president or of running for president again.<ref name="wolf-2nd-no">{{cite news |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-18/politics/wolf.blitzer.clinton.cairo_1_armored-vehicles-armored-car-state-hillary-clinton/2?_s=PM:POLITICS |title=Blitzer's Notebook: Behind the scenes on Clinton's Mideast trip |author=Blitzer, Wolf |authorlink=Wolf Blitzer |publisher=CNN |date=March 18, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006103147/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-18/politics/wolf.blitzer.clinton.cairo_1_armored-vehicles-armored-car-state-hillary-clinton/2?_s=PM%3APOLITICS |archivedate=October 6, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> She also explicitly said for the first time that she did not want to serve a second term as Secretary of State if President Obama is [[United States presidential election, 2012|re-elected in 2012]].<ref name="pol-no-2nd">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0311/51515.html |title=Day after saying no second term, a big win for Hillary Clinton |author=Thrush, Glenn |work=[[Politico]] |date=March 17, 2011 |accessdate=March 17, 2011}}</ref><ref name="no to 2nd">{{cite news |url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2011/03/16/clinton-running-for-president/ |title=Clinton says no to second term |work=Political Ticker |publisher=CNN |date=March 16, 2011 |accessdate=March 17, 2011}}</ref> She stressed how much she regarded her current position: "Because I have the best job I could ever have. This is a moment in history where it is almost hard to catch your breath. There are both the tragedies and disasters that we have seen from Haiti to Japan and there are the extraordinary opportunities and challenges that we see right here in Egypt and in the rest of the region."<ref name="no to 2nd" /> But reportedly she was weary at times from constant travelling, still not part of Obama's inner circle, and looking forward to a time of less stress and the chances to write, teach, or work for international women's rights.<ref name="pol-no-2nd" /> She was not bound by her statements, and Blitzer for one suspected she would change her mind.<ref name="wolf-2nd-no" /> In any case, she remained popular with the American public; her [[Gallup Poll]] favorability rating rose to 66 percent (against 31 percent unfavorable), her highest mark ever save for a period during the [[Lewinsky scandal]] thirteen years earlier.<ref name="gallup-mar2011">{{cite news |url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/146891/Hillary-Clinton-Favorable-Near-Time-High.aspx |title=Hillary Clinton Favorable Near Her All-Time High |author=Saad, Lydia |publisher=[[Gallup Organization]] |date=March 30, 2011 |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref> Her favorability was 10 to 20 percentage points higher than those for Obama, Biden, or Gates, and reflected in part the high ratings that secretaries of state sometimes get.<ref name="gallup-mar2011" />
[[File:Obama and Biden await updates on bin Laden.jpg|thumb|right|Secretary Clinton was among those in the [[White House Situation Room]] getting real-time updates on the [[Death of Osama bin Laden|May 2011 mission to kill Osama bin Laden]].]]
Throughout early 2011, the CIA thought there was a good chance it had discovered the whereabouts of [[Osama bin Laden]], and the White House held a final high-level discussion on April 28 about whether to go ahead with a raid to get him, and if so, what kind of mission to undertake. Clinton supported the option to send [[United States Navy SEALs|Navy SEALs]] in, believing that the U.S. could not afford to ignore this chance and that getting bin Laden was so important that it outweighed any risks.<ref>{{cite book |first=Mark |last=Bowden |authorlink=Mark Bowden |title=The Finish: The Killing of Osama Bin Laden |publisher=[[Atlantic Monthly Press]] |location=New York |year=2012 |isbn=0-8021-2034-2 |pages=198–203}}</ref> Following the successful May 1–2, 2011, [[Death of Osama bin Laden|U.S. mission to kill Osama bin Laden]] at [[Osama bin Laden's hideout compound|his hideout compound]] in [[Abbottabad]], Pakistan, and the resulting criticism from various Americans that [[Allegations of support system in Pakistan for Osama bin Laden|Pakistan had not found, or had let, bin Laden hide in near plain sight]], Clinton made a point of praising Pakistan's past record of helping the U.S. hunt down terrorists: "Our counter-terrorism cooperation over a number of years now, with Pakistan, has contributed greatly to our efforts to dismantle al-Qaeda. And in fact, cooperation with Pakistan helped lead us to bin Laden and the compound in which he was hiding. Going forward, we are absolutely committed to continuing that cooperation."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/usa/Clinton-Stresses-Pakistan-Cooperation-After-bin-Laden-Killing--121092289.html |title=Clinton: Pakistan Cooperation Helped Find bin Laden |author=Gollust, David |publisher=[[Voice of America]] |date=May 2, 2011}}</ref> Clinton then played a key role in the administration's decision not to release photographs of the dead bin Laden, reporting that U.S. allies in the Middle East did not favor the release and agreeing with Secretary Gates that such a release might cause an anti-U.S. backlash overseas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/whitehouse/why-obama-nixed-the-photo-release-20110504 |title=Why Obama Nixed the Photo Release |author=Ambinder, Marc |author2=Cooper, Matthew |newspaper=[[National Journal]] |date=May 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110507030825/http://www.nationaljournal.com/whitehouse/why-obama-nixed-the-photo-release-20110504 |archivedate=May 7, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
A June 2011 trip to Africa found Clinton consoling longtime aide [[Huma Abedin]] after the [[Anthony Weiner sexting scandal]] broke.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0611/56496.html |title=Report: Huma Abedin sought advice from Hillary Clinton |author=Epstein, Jennifer |newspaper=Politico |date=June 8, 2011}}</ref> She also emphatically denied published reports that she was interested in becoming the next president of the [[World Bank]], which would need a successor to follow [[Robert Zoellick]] after the end of his term in mid-2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/11/us/politics/11world.html |title=Clinton Dismisses Rumors of World Bank Job, However Plausible They Sound |author=Landler, Mark |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 10, 2011 |accessdate=June 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/06/09/clinton-world-bank-president_n_874484.html |title=Hillary Clinton, World Bank President? Secretary Of State Seeks Position: Sources (VIDEO) |work=Huffington Post |date=June 9, 2011|accessdate=October 5, 2011 |first=Cara |last=Parks}}</ref> A different suggestion, from wanting-to-depart [[U.S. Secretary of the Treasury]] [[Timothy Geithner]] that Clinton replace him at that position, gained some traction in parts of the White House before economic and budget issues intensified and President Obama convinced Geithner to stay on.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/geithner-proposed-hillary-clinton-for-treasury-secretary-white-house-scuttled-idea/2012/06/14/gJQAjhezcV_story.html |title=Geithner once proposed Hillary Rodham Clinton for Treasury secretary |first=Ned |last=Martel |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 14, 2012}}</ref>
By July, Clinton was assuring China and other foreign governments that the ongoing [[United States debt-ceiling crisis of 2011|U.S. debt ceiling crisis]] would not end with the U.S. going into [[sovereign default]]<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/clinton-seeks-to-reassure-asia-amid-us-debt-stalemate/2011/07/25/gIQAujW6XI_story.html |title=Clinton seeks to reassure China amid U.S. debt stalemate |author=Wan, William |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=July 25, 2011}}</ref> (a prediction that turned true when the [[Budget Control Act of 2011]] was passed and signed the day before default loomed). She spent much of that summer in an eventually unsuccessful attempt to persuade the [[Palestinian National Authority]] not to [[Palestine 194|attempt to gain membership in the United Nations at its September 2011 General Assembly meeting]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/clinton-wont-give-odds-on-averting-un-showdown-over-palestinian-statehood/2011/09/15/gIQABTPbVK_story.html |title=Clinton won't give odds on averting UN showdown over Palestinian statehood |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=September 15, 2011 |accessdate=September 25, 2011}} {{dead link|date=September 2013|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
Clinton continued to poll high, with a September 2011 [[Bloomberg News]] poll finding her with a 64 percent favorable rating, the highest of any political figure in the nation.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/blogs/ticket/poll-third-americans-believe-clinton-ve-better-president-152358495.html |title=Poll: A third of Americans believe Clinton would've been a better president |author=Bailey, Holly |publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] |date=September 16, 2011 |accessdate=September 23, 2011}}</ref> A third of those polls said that Clinton would have been a better president than Obama, but when asked the likelihood she would stage a campaign against the president, she said, "It's below zero. One of the great things about being secretary of state is I am out of politics. I am not interested in being drawn back into it by anybody."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-09-16/clinton-popularity-prompts-some-remorse-poll.html |title=Hillary Clinton Rise as Most Popular Politician Prompting Buyers' Remorse |author=McCormick, John |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=September 16, 2011 |accessdate=September 23, 2011}}</ref>
Following the October 2011 announcement by Obama that the [[withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq]] would complete by the close of that same year, Clinton forcefully defended the decision as emanating from an agreement originally signed with Iraq under the Bush administration and as evidence that Iraq's sovereignty was real, and said that despite the absence of military forces, the U.S. was still committed to strengthening Iraq's democracy with "robust" diplomatic measures.<ref name="pol-oct11">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1011/66644.html#ixzz1bh6Qnn2R |title=Hillary Clinton stands firm behind Obama |author=Thrush, Glenn |author2=Hirschhorn, Dan |newspaper=Politico |date=October 23, 2011 |accessdate=October 23, 2011}}</ref> She also praised the effectiveness of Obama's foreign policy in general, implicitly pushing back on criticism from [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|those running for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination]].<ref name="pol-oct11" />
Clinton specifically pointed to the [[death of Muammar Gaddafi]] and the conclusion of the Libyan intervention.<ref name="pol-oct11" /> She had been active during the final stages of the Libyan rebellion, and via Sheik [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]], had urged the rebels forces to unify and avoid factional conflicts with each other.<ref name="time-smart" /> She visited [[Tripoli]] in October 2011 and, in private, was somewhat guarded about Libya's future following the rebel success.<ref name="time-smart">{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2097973,00.html |title=Hillary Clinton and the Rise of Smart Power |author=Calabresi, Massimo |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=November 7, 2011 |pages=26–31}}</ref> (A video of her exclaiming "Wow" upon first reading on her BlackBerry of Gaddafi's capture achieved wide circulation.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/oct/21/gaddafi-death-image?newsfeed=true |title=Gaddafi's death: rumoured, announced and confirmed in a single image |author=Addley, Esther |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=October 21, 2011 |accessdate=October 24, 2011 |location=London}}</ref>) Over the next few years, the [[aftermath of the Libyan Civil War]] became characterized by instability, two rival governments, and a slide into status as a [[failed state]]; it became a refuge for extremists and terrorist groups, such as [[ISIL]], and spurred a massive refugee crisis as immigrants crossed the Mediterranean to southern Europe.<ref name="cnn-libya-problem">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/08/politics/hillary-clinton-libya-election-2016/index.html |title=Hillary Clinton's real Libya problem |author=Collinson, Stephen |publisher=CNN |date=June 15, 2015}}</ref> The wisdom of the intervention would continue to be debated, with President Obama maintaining that the intervention had been worthwhile but that the United States and Europe underestimated the ongoing effort needed to rebuild Libyan society afterward;<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/09/opinion/president-obama-thomas-l-friedman-iraq-and-world-affairs.html |title=Obama on the World |first=Thomas L. |last=Friedman |newspaper=The New York Times |date=August 8, 2014}}</ref> former U.S. Representative to NATO [[Ivo Daalder]] stating that the limited goals of the intervention had all been met but that the Libyan people had not seized their opportunity to form a better future and that post-intervention military involvement by the West would have been counterproductive;<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/07/libya-intervention-daalder_n_6809756.html |title=Was The 2011 Libya Intervention A Mistake? |first=Nick |last=Robins-Early |work=Huffington Post |date=March 7, 2015}}</ref> and scholar Alan J. Kuperman (along with some other scholars and human rights groups) writing that the intervention had been based on the faulty notion that Libya had been headed towards humanitarian disaster when in fact it was not and was thus the intervention was "an abject failure, judged even by its own standards".<ref>{{cite journal |title=Obama's Libya Debacle |first=Alan J. |last=Kuperman |journal=[[Foreign Affairs]] |date=March–April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/121879/hillary-clinton-should-take-blame-disastrous-libyan-intervention |title=Benghazi Won't Stick to Hillary Clinton, But the Disastrous Libyan Intervention Should |first=Joel |last=Gillan |magazine=The New Republic |date=May 27, 2015}}</ref> Kuperman's view that Gaddafi son [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]] held promise as a Western-style political reformer was in turn disputed by former [[Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs]] [[Derek Chollet]], who stated that such faith was misplaced and that Libyans were resistant to any post-intervention security mechanism and to many rebuilding programs.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/libya/2015-04-20/who-lost-libya |title=Who Lost Libya? |first=Derek |last=Chollet |first2=Ben |last2=Fishman |journal=[[Foreign Affairs]] |date=May–June 2015}}</ref> Clinton said in her 2014 memoir that she had been "worried that the challenges ahead would prove overwhelming for even the most well-meaning transitional leaders. If the new government could consolidate its authority, provide security, use oil revenues to rebuild, disarm the militias, and keep extremists out, then Libya would have a fighting chance at building a stable democracy. If not, then the country would face very difficult challenges translating the hopes of a revolution into a free, secure, and prosperous future."<ref name="cnn-libya-problem" />
Secretary Clinton cancelled a planned trip to the United Kingdom and Turkey to be with her mother, [[Dorothy Rodham]], who died in Washington on November 1, 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/nationalsecurity/hillary-rodham-clinton-s-mother-dies-at-92-20111101?mrefid=mostViewed |title=Hillary Rodham Clinton's Mother Dies at 92 |author=Sorcher, Sara |newspaper=[[National Journal]] |date=November 1, 2011 |accessdate=November 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150511155722/http://www.nationaljournal.com/nationalsecurity/hillary-rodham-clinton-s-mother-dies-at-92-20111101?mrefid=mostViewed |archivedate=May 11, 2015 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In November 2011, Clinton declared, in both a speech at the [[East–West Center]] and in an article published in ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' magazine, that the 21st century would be "America's Pacific century".<ref name="reut-apc">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/11/us-apec-usa-clinton-f-idUSTRE7AA2S120111111 |title=Clinton declares 'America's Pacific century' |agency=Reuters |date=November 11, 2011}}</ref><ref name="hrc-apc">{{cite journal |last=Clinton |first=Hillary |title=America's Pacific Century |url=<!-- http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/10/11/americas_pacific_century --> |journal=[[Foreign Policy]] |issue=189 |date=November 2011 |pages=56–63}}</ref> The term played on the notion of the "[[Pacific Century]]". Clinton said, "It is becoming increasingly clear that, in the 21st century, the world's strategic and economic center of gravity will be the Asia-Pacific, from the Indian subcontinent to western shores of the Americas."<ref name="reut-apc" /> The declaration was part of the [[East Asian foreign policy of the Barack Obama administration|Obama administration's "pivot to Asia"]] after the focus of the decade of the 2000s on the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.<ref name="reut-apc" /><ref name="hrc-apc" />
When the [[2011–2012 Russian protests]] had begun in late 2011, in response to the [[Russian legislative election, 2011]], Clinton had been outspoken about the need for legitimate democratic processes there, saying in December 2011: "The Russian people, like people everywhere, deserve the right to have their voices heard and their votes counted. And that means they deserve free, fair, transparent elections and leaders who are accountable to them."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/12/06/world/europe/russia-elections-clinton/index.html |title=Clinton cites 'serious concerns' about Russian election |author=Labott, Elise |publisher=CNN |date=December 6, 2011}}</ref> She added that "Russian voters deserve a full investigation of electoral fraud and manipulation." In return, Russian Prime Minister [[Vladimir Putin]] denounced Clinton, accusing her of backing Russian protesters financially and in fact precipitating their actions: "They heard this signal and with the support of the U.S. State Department began their active work."<ref name="cnn-putin">{{cite news |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/story/2011-12-08/Clinton-Putin-Russia/51729210/1 |title=Putin accuses Clinton of encouraging protesters |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=USA Today |date=December 8, 2011}}</ref> When Putin won the [[Russian presidential election, 2012]] in March 2012, some in the State Department wanted to denounce Russian process again, but they were overruled by the White House, and Clinton stated simply that "The election had a clear winner, and we are ready to work with President-elect Putin."<ref name="nytm-rock" />
[[File:Clinton talking with Suu Kyi.jpg|thumb|right|Secretary Clinton met with Burmese democracy leader [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] on December 2, 2011, as part of her historic visit to that country.]] In early December 2011, Clinton made the first visit to [[Burma]] by a U.S. secretary of state since [[John Foster Dulles]]'s in 1955, as she met with Burmese leaders as well as opposition leader [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] and sought to support the [[Reforms in Burma|2011 Burmese democratic reforms]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/30/hillary-clinton-burma-visit-reform-hopes |title=Hillary Clinton begins Burma visit |author=Burke, Jason |newspaper=The Guardian |date=November 30, 2011 |location=London}}</ref> Clinton said that due to the direct and indirect communications she had had with Suu Kyi over the years, "it was like seeing a friend you hadn't seen for a very long time even though it was our first meeting."<ref name="bbc-int-burma">{{cite news |url=http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/texttrans/2011/12/20111202125706su0.4918286.html?CP.rss=true#ixzz1iDNssGTL |title=Secretary Clinton's Interview in Rangoon, Burma, with BBC |publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]] |date=December 2, 2011}}</ref> The outreach to Burma attracted both praise and criticism, with Congresswoman [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]] saying it "sends the wrong signal to the Burmese military thugs" but others saying the visit combined idealism with respect to reform and realpolitik with respect to keeping Burma out of the direct Chinese sphere of influence.<ref name="guard-dec2011">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/08/hillary-clinton-world-tour-success?newsfeed=true |title=Hillary Clinton's world tour brings brickbats, but more bouquets |author=McGreal, Chris |newspaper=The Guardian |date=December 8, 2011 |location=London}}</ref> Clinton had had to overcome internal administration opposition from the White House and Pentagon, as well as from Senate minority leader [[Mitch McConnell]], to make the move, eventually making a personal appeal to Obama and gaining his approval.<ref name="nyt-backstage" /> Regarding whether the Burmese regime would follow up on reform pledges, Clinton said, "I can't predict what's going to happen, but I think it certainly is important for the United States to be on the side of democratic reform ... This is a first date, not a marriage, and we'll see where it leads."<ref name="bbc-int-burma" /> She continued to address rights concerns in a December 2011 speech a few days later before the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]], saying that the U.S. would advocate for [[gay rights]] abroad and that "Gay rights are human rights" and that "It should never be a crime to be gay."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-16062937 |title=Hillary Clinton declares 'gay rights are human rights' |publisher=BBC News |date=December 7, 2011}}</ref> This itself drew criticism from some American social conservatives.<ref name="guard-dec2011" />
As the year closed, Clinton was again named by Americans in [[Gallup's most admired man and woman poll]] as the woman around the world they most admired; it was her tenth win in a row and sixteenth overall.<ref name="g11">{{cite news |url= http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/12/gallup-poll-obama-and-hillary-clinton-top-most-admired-list-again.html |title=Gallup: Obama, Hillary Clinton are most admired, again and again |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=December 28, 2011 |accessdate=December 30, 2011}}</ref>
==Regional issues and travels: 2012== [[File:Clinton and Davutoglu.jpg|thumb|right|Secretary Clinton and Turkish Foreign Minister [[Ahmet Davutoglu]] following their bilateral meeting at the Department of State, February 13, 2012.]]
In a State Department town hall meeting on January 26, 2012, Clinton indicated her desire to remove herself from "the high wire of American politics" after twenty tiring years of being on it and added, "I have made it clear that I will certainly stay on until the president nominates someone and that transition can occur."<ref name=lee>{{Cite news |url=http://www.ajc.com/news/nation-world/hillary-clinton-dodging-political-1318559.html |title=Hillary Clinton dodging political 'high wire' |author=Lee, Matthew |newspaper=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |agency=Associated Press |date=January 26, 2012 |accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref> She also indicated that she had not watched any of the [[Republican Party presidential debates, 2012|2012 Republican Party presidential debates]].<ref name=lee />
As the [[Syrian Civil War]] continued and intensified with the [[February 2012 bombardment of Homs]], the U.S. sought a UN Security Council resolution that backed [[Syrian conflict peace proposals|an Arab League plan]] that would urge Syrian President [[Bashar al-Assad]] to relinquish powers to the vice presidential level and permit a unity government to form.<ref name="ap-syria" /> However, Russia and China vetoed the resolution, an action that Clinton characterized as a "travesty".<ref name="ap-syria">{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/clinton-calls-friends-syria-unite-132749258.html |title=Clinton calls for friends of Syria to unite |first=Matthew |last=Lee |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Yahoo! News |date=February 5, 2012}}</ref> After the failure of the effort, Clinton warned that Syria could degenerate into "a brutal civil war" and called for a "friends of democratic Syria" group of like-minded nations to promote a peaceful and democratic solution to the situation and pressure Syria accordingly.<ref name="ap-syria" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/feb/05/world/la-fg-syria-violence-20120206 |title=Hillary Clinton warns of 'brutal civil war' in Syria |first=Patrick J.|last=McDonnell|newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=February 5, 2012}}</ref> At a meeting in Tunis of the consequent [[Friends of Syria Group]], Clinton again criticized the actions of Russia and China as "distressing" and "despicable", and predicted that the Assad regime would meet its end via a military coup.<ref>{{cite news |title=Clinton rips Russia, China for vetoes at U.N. on Syria |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=[[Asbury Park Press]] |date=February 25, 2012 |page=A12}}</ref> Later, during the summer of 2012, she repeated her criticism of those two countries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/06/world/meast/syria-unrest/ |title=Clinton Slams Russia, China Over Syria |publisher=CNN |author=Labott, Elise |date=July 6, 2012}}</ref> At that time, Clinton developed a plan with CIA Director [[David H. Petraeus]] to send arms to, and perform training of, vetted groups of Syrian rebels, using the assistance of a neighboring state.<ref name="nyt-backstage">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/03/us/politics/in-behind-scene-blows-and-triumphs-sense-of-clinton-future.html |title=Backstage Glimpses of Clinton as Dogged Diplomat, Win or Lose |author=Gordon, Michael R. |author2=Landler, Mark |newspaper=The New York Times |date=February 3, 2013 |page=A1}}</ref> The plan also had the support of Defense Secretary [[Leon E. Panetta]] and Joint Chiefs chair General [[Martin E. Dempsey]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/08/us/politics/panetta-speaks-to-senate-panel-on-benghazi-attack.html |title=Senate Hearing Draws Out a Rift in U.S. Policy on Syria |author=Gordon, Michael R. |author2=Landler, Mark |newspaper=The New York Times |date=February 7, 2013 |page=A1}}</ref> Reluctant to become entangled in the Syrian situation and in an election campaign, Obama rejected the idea.<ref name="nyt-backstage" />
[[File:Sec Clinton Travel Map.xcf|left|thumb|Clinton has visited 112 countries during her tenure, the most of any Secretary of State in U.S. history.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/trvl/index.htm |title=Travels with the Secretary |publisher=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=December 16, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712183245/https://www.state.gov/secretary/trvl/index.htm |archivedate=July 12, 2012 |df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="ap-conc">{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/secretary-state-faints-sustains-concussion-172605823--politics.html |title=Secretary of State faints, sustains concussion |author=Lee, Matthew |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Yahoo! News |date=December 16, 2012}}</ref><ref name="csm-trav" />]]
In February 2012, a spokesman for Clinton denied again that Clinton wanted the President of the World Bank job, saying, "She has said this is not happening. Her view has not changed."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-pn-hillary-clinton-world-bank-20120215,0,1753490.story |title=Hillary Clinton to World Bank? 'Not happening,' aide says |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date= February 15, 2012|accessdate=February 16, 2012 |first=Paul |last=Richter}}</ref>
At a keynote speech before the [[International Crisis Group]], the secretary brought her view regarding the empowerment of women specifically into the area of [[peacemaking]], saying that women's multifaceted ties with a community make them more compelled to concern about social and quality of life issues that prosper under peacetime conditions. Furthermore, women identify more with minority groups, being discriminated against themselves. Thus, "Women are the largest untapped reservoir of talent in the world. It is past time for women to take their rightful place, side by side with men, in the rooms where the fates of peoples, where their children's and grandchildren's fates, are decided."<ref name="elle-2012" /> She also continued to believe that empowerment of women would continue to grow as people saw that it would lead to economic growth.<ref name="nyt-gc-next" />
In April 2012, an [[Internet meme]] "Texts from Hillary", hosted on [[Tumblr]] and based around a photograph of Clinton sitting on a military plane wearing sunglasses and using a mobile phone, imagined the recipients and contents of her [[text message]]s. It became suddenly popular and earned the endorsement of Clinton herself, before being brought to an end by its creators.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0412/74994.html |title=Hillary Clinton likes 'Texts from Hillary' Tumblr |first=MJ |last=Lee |work=Politico |date=April 10, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/media/2012/04/texts-from-hillary-creators-bow-out-120252.html |title='Texts From Hillary' creators bow out |first=Dylan |last=Byers |work=Politico |date=April 11, 2012}}</ref> Obama himself took note of the meme's popularity, in a humorous exchange that revealed the ease the two now had around one another.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/ready-for-the-fight-rolling-stone-interview-with-barack-obama-20120425 |title=Ready for the Fight: Rolling Stone Interview with Barack Obama |author=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner, Jann S.]] |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=April 25, 2012}}</ref> Around the same time, a photograph taken during the [[6th Summit of the Americas]] in [[Cartagena, Colombia]], showed Clinton with a group of colleagues relaxing, drinking Águila beer from a bottle and dancing, at a local nightclub.<ref name="nyp-swill">{{cite news |url=http://nypost.newspaperdirect.com/epaper/viewer.aspx |title=Swillary |author=Macintosh, Jeane |newspaper=[[New York Post]] |date=April 16, 2012 |page=1}}</ref> The episode gained front-page attention from the ''[[New York Post]]'' and illustrated how Clinton was enjoying the job.<ref name="nytm-rock" /> Regarding her ongoing popularity, Clinton said, "There's a certain consistency to who I am and what I do, and I think people have finally said, 'Well, you know, I kinda get her now.'"<ref name="elle-2012" /> One long-time Washington figure summarized the situation by simply saying, "There's no coin in criticizing her anymore."<ref name="elle-2012" /> At the same time, her fashion choices gained renewed attention, with her hair grown long and sometimes pulled back with [[scrunchie]]s.<ref name="elle-2012">{{cite news |url=http://www.elle.com/Life-Love/Society-Career-Power/At-the-Pinnacle-of-Hillary-Clinton-s-Career |title=At the Pinnacle of Hillary Clinton's Career |author=Combe, Rachael |magazine=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]] |date=April 5, 2012 |accessdate=June 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120522024829/http://www.elle.com/Life-Love/Society-Career-Power/At-the-Pinnacle-of-Hillary-Clinton-s-Career |archivedate=May 22, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Public commentary on Clinton's hair was now a tradition across twenty years, but as one female State Department traveller said, "As a chick, it's a big pain in the butt. The weather is different, and you’re in and out of the plane. [The staff] gets off that plane looking like garbage most days, but she has to look camera ready. She said the reason she grew her hair long was that it's easier. She has options."<ref name="elle-2012" /> Clinton professed she was past the point of concern on the matter: "I feel so relieved to be at the stage I'm at in my life right now, [...] because if I want to wear my glasses, I'm wearing my glasses. If I want to pull my hair back, I'm pulling my hair back."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/click/2012/05/hillary-clinton-on-makeup-hair-who-cares-122745.html |title=Hillary Clinton on make-up, hair: Who cares? |author=McDevitt, Caitlin |work=Politico |date=May 8, 2012}}</ref> In any case, Clinton showed a much more relaxed attitude vis a vis the press than in past eras.<ref name="elle-2012" />
A late April/early May 2012 trip to China found Clinton in the middle of a drama involving blind Chinese dissident [[Chen Guangcheng]]. He had escaped house arrest and, after finding his way to the [[Embassy of the United States, Beijing]], requested an arrangement whereby he could stay in China with guarantees for his safety. After a deal towards that end fell through, he requested a seat on Clinton's plane when she flew back to the U.S. After further negotiations in parallel with the existing agenda of Clinton's trip, Chen left for the U.S. after Clinton's departure.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/chen-guangcheng-chinese-dissident-leaves-us/story?id=16384545 |title=Chen Guangcheng: Chinese Dissident Arrives US |first=Akiko|last=Fujita|first2=Elicia |last2=Dover|first3=Dean|last3=Schabner|publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=May 19, 2012}}</ref> Clinton had negotiated personally with senior Chinese diplomat [[Dai Bingguo]] in order to get the deal back in place.<ref name="nyt-backstage" /> Despite an environment that had, as one aide said, "exploded into an absolute circus", Clinton managed to find a path for the U.S. that kept China from losing face and kept the overall agenda of the meetings intact.<ref name="nytm-rock" />
Following the June 2012 killing of high-ranking al Qaeda figure [[Abu Yahya al-Libi]] in one of the U.S. [[drone attacks in Pakistan]], Clinton defended the action, saying "We will always maintain our right to use force against groups such as al Qaeda that have attacked us and still threaten us with imminent attack. In doing so, we will comply with the applicable law, including the laws of war, and go to extraordinary lengths to ensure precision and avoid the loss of innocent life."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/07/clinton-defends-drone-strikes_n_1577125.html |title=Clinton Defends Drone Strikes After Al Qaeda Leader Abu Yahya al-Libi Killed |first=Arshad |last=Mohammed |agency=Reuters |work=Huffington Post |date=June 7, 2013}}</ref> Indeed, beginning with her 2009 trip to Pakistan, Clinton had faced questions about U.S. drone strikes, which she refused to comment much upon at the time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/33548966/ns/world_news-south_and_central_asia/t/clinton-faces-pakistani-ire-over-drone-attacks/ |title=Clinton faces Pakistani ire at drone attacks |publisher=NBC News |year=2009 |accessdate=April 13, 2015}}</ref> Behind the scenes, Clinton was in fact one of the leading administration proponents of continuing and expanding the strikes there and elsewhere.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-12-27/national/35285416_1_drone-program-drone-campaign-lethal-operations |title=Under Obama, an emerging global apparatus for drone killing |author=Miller, Greg |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=December 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019012717/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-12-27/national/35285416_1_drone-program-drone-campaign-lethal-operations |archivedate=October 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> She did, however, side with U.S. Ambassador to Pakistan [[Cameron Munter]] in 2011 when he requested more input into, and control over, the U.S. "kill list" selections for that country.<ref>Mazzetti, ''The Way of the Knife'', pp. 290–293.</ref>
In June 2012, Clinton set down in [[Riga, Latvia]], which represented the 100th country she had visited during her tenure, setting a mark for secretaries of state; the record had been Madeleine Albright with 96.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.freep.com/article/20120628/NEWS07/120628011/Frequent-flier-Clinton-hits-100-country-mark |title=Frequent flier Hillary Clinton hits 100-country mark |author=Lee, Matthew |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=[[Detroit Free Press]] |date=June 28, 2012}}</ref> In July 2012, Clinton became the first U.S. Secretary of State to visit [[Laos]] since [[John Foster Dulles]] in 1955.<ref name=laosvisit>{{cite news|title=US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on historic Laos visit |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-18792282 |publisher=BBC News |date=July 11, 2012 |accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref> She held talks with [[Prime Minister of Laos|Prime Minister]] [[Thongsing Thammavong]] and Foreign Minister [[Thongloun Sisoulith]] in [[Vientiane]].<ref name=bbcnews />
Also in July 2012, Clinton visited Egypt for the first time since [[Mohammed Morsi]] became the first democratically elected president of the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/us-role-post-mubarak-egypt-still-unclear |title=Clinton's calls fall flat in Egypt political fight |first1=Hamza |last1=Hendawi |first2=Bradley |last2=Klapper |date=July 15, 2012 |work=The Big Story |accessdate=April 13, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413160549/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/us-role-post-mubarak-egypt-still-unclear |archivedate=April 13, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> As she arrived in the country, her convoy was met with a protest and had shoes, tomatoes and bottled water thrown at it, although nothing hit either Clinton or her vehicle.<ref name=bbcnews>{{cite news|title= Hillary's motorcade pelted with tomatoes and shoes as Egyptian protesters shout 'Monica, Monica' |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2174083/Hillary-Clintons-motorcade-pelted-tomatoes-Egypt.html |publisher=[[The Daily Mail]] |date=July 16, 2012 |accessdate=July 18, 2012 |location=London}}</ref> Protesters also chanted "Monica, Monica", in reference to the [[Lewinsky scandal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/b06b6b00-ce94-11e1-bc0c-00144feabdc0.html |title=Clinton in talks with Egypt military head |first=Heba |last=Saleh |work=Financial Times |date=July 15, 2012 |accessdate=April 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/15/world/africa/egypt-clinton/index.html |publisher=CNN |title=Protests as Clinton holds meetings in Egypt |date=July 16, 2012}}</ref> She also faced conspiracy theories (in a country that tended towards them) that the U.S. was secretly aligned with the [[Muslim Brotherhood]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://world.time.com/2012/07/15/for-us-or-against-us-egyptians-confront-clinton-with-conspiracy-theories/ |work=Time |date=July 15, 2012 |title=For Us or Against Us: Egyptians Confront Clinton with Conspiracy Theories |accessdate=October 4, 2013}}</ref>
An advocate of ending Somalia's [[Transitional Federal Government|transitional phase]] on time,<ref>{{cite news|title=Clinton threatens sanctions for undermining Somali political transition|url=http://thehill.com/video/administration/212373-clinton-threatens-sanctions-for-undermining-somali-political-transition-|accessdate=September 14, 2012|newspaper=The Hill|date=February 23, 2012}}</ref> Clinton showed support in August for the new [[Federal Government of Somalia]], which took over as the permanent government.<ref>{{cite news|title=Clinton encouraged by Somalia's governing progress|url=https://news.yahoo.com/clinton-encouraged-somalias-governing-progress-142802106.html|accessdate=September 14, 2012|publisher=Yahoo! News|date=August 4, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hillary Clinton Congratulates Somalia’s New Leaders – Calls for Continued Reforms |url=http://www.raxanreeb.com/2012/09/hillary-clinton-congratulates-somalias-new-leaders-calls-for-continued-reforms/ |accessdate=September 14, 2012 |publisher=Raxanreeb |date=September 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120918090606/http://www.raxanreeb.com/2012/09/hillary-clinton-congratulates-somalias-new-leaders-calls-for-continued-reforms/ |archivedate=September 18, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[File:Obama and Clinton at Transfer of Remains Ceremony for Benghazi attack victims Sep 14, 2012.jpg|thumb|President Obama and Secretary Clinton honor the Benghazi victims at the Transfer of Remains Ceremony held at [[Andrews Air Force Base]] on September 14, 2012.]]
On September 11, 2012, an [[attack on the U.S. diplomatic mission in Benghazi]] took place, resulting in the death of U.S. Ambassador [[J. Christopher Stevens]] and three other Americans. The next day, Clinton also made a statement describing the perpetrators as "heavily armed militants" and "a small and savage group – not the people or government of Libya."<ref>{{cite news |title=Obama vows to track down ambassador's killers |author=Matt Spetalnick |author2=Hadeel Al Shalchi |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/12/us-libya-usa-attack-idUSBRE88B0EI20120912?irpc=932 |newspaper=Reuters |date=September 12, 2012 |accessdate=November 5, 2012}}</ref> Clinton also responded to the notion that the attack had been related to the [[Reactions to Innocence of Muslims|reactions in Egypt and elsewhere]] to the [[Criticism of Islam|anti-Islamic]] online video known as ''[[Innocence of Muslims]]'', saying: "Some have sought to justify this vicious behavior as a response to inflammatory material posted on the internet. The United States deplores any intentional effort to denigrate the religious beliefs of others. But let me be clear: There is never any justification for violent acts of this kind."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skynews.com.au/politics/article.aspx?id=794301|title=Romney slams reaction to protest|publisher=Sky News|date=September 12, 2012|accessdate=September 12, 2012}}</ref> She and President Obama appearing together in the [[White House Rose Garden]] the same day and vowed to bring the attackers to justice.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/09/20129112108737726.html|title=US envoy dies in Benghazi consulate attack|date=September 12, 2012|publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=September 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.voanews.com/content/us-ambassador-3-others-killed-in-libya-attack-/1506222.html |title=Obama Condemns Libya Attack That Killed US Ambassador |author=Robinson, Dan |publisher=[[VOA News]] |date=September 12, 2012}}</ref> On September 14 the remains of the slain Americans were returned to the U.S. Obama and Clinton attended the ceremony; in her remarks, Clinton said, "One young woman, her head covered and her eyes haunted with sadness, held up a handwritten sign that said 'Thugs and killers don't represent Benghazi nor Islam.'"<ref>[https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2012/09/197780.htm "Remarks at the Transfer of Remains Ceremony to Honor Those Lost in Attacks in Benghazi, Libya"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130112182249/https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2012/09/197780.htm |date=January 12, 2013}}, Hillary Rodham Clinton, September 14, 2012</ref>
The attack, and questions surrounding the U.S. Government's preparedness for it, and explanations for what had happened afterward, became a political firestorm in the U.S., especially in the context of the [[United States presidential election, 2012|ongoing presidential election]].<ref name="cnn-attack-resp" /> The State Department had previously identified embassy and personnel security as a major challenge in its budget and priorities report.<ref>{{cite news |title=Years of warning about embassy security preceded Libya attack |author=John Solomon |url=http://www.washingtonguardian.com/red-flags-embassy-security |work=Washington Guardian |date=September 12, 2012 |accessdate=November 5, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028061103/http://www.washingtonguardian.com/red-flags-embassy-security |archive-date=October 28, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> On the September 20, Clinton gave a classified briefing to U.S. Senators,<ref>{{cite web|author=Josh Rogin|title=Republican senators decry 'useless, worthless' Clinton briefing on Libya attack|url=http://thecable.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2012/09/20/republican_senators_decry_useless_worthless_clinton_briefing_on_libya_attack|work=Foreign Policy|date=September 20, 2012|accessdate=September 22, 2012}}</ref> which several Republican attendees criticized, angry at the Obama administration's rebuff of their attempts to learn details of the Benghazi attack, only to see that information published the next day in ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Alexander Bolton|title=Senate GOP furious newspaper got better briefing on Libya|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/251109-senate-republicans-upset-obama-administration-passed-them-over-for-the-new-york-times |work=The Hill|date=September 22, 2012|accessdate=September 22, 2012}}</ref> She did announce the formation of an Accountability Review Board panel, chaired by longtime diplomat [[Thomas R. Pickering]] and vice-chaired by retired Admiral and former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff [[Michael Mullen]], to investigate the attack from the State Department's viewpoint.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/clinton-forms-panel-investigate-benghazi-attack-175841876.html|title=Clinton forms panel to investigate Benghazi attack|agency=Reuters|date=September 20, 2012|accessdate=September 22, 2012}}</ref>
On October 15, regarding the question of preparedness, Clinton said she was accountable: "I take responsibility. I'm in charge of the State Department's 60,000-plus people all over the world, 275 posts. ... I take this very personally. So we're going to get to the bottom of it, and then we're going to do everything we can to work to prevent it from happening again."<ref name="cnn-attack-resp">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/15/us/clinton-benghazi/index.html |title=Clinton: I'm responsible for diplomats' security |author=Labott, Elise |publisher=CNN |date=October 16, 2012}}</ref> Regarding the different explanations afterward for what had happened, she said, "In the wake of an attack like this, in the fog of war, there's always going to be confusion. And I think it is absolutely fair to say that everyone had the same intelligence. Everyone who spoke tried to give the information that they had. As time has gone on, that information has changed. We've gotten more detail, but that's not surprising. That always happens."<ref name="cnn-attack-resp" />
On November 6, 2012, Obama was re-elected for a second term as president. Clinton said shortly before the election that she would stay on until her successor was confirmed, but that "this is not an open-ended kind of time frame."<ref name="wapo-102612">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/clinton-wont-leave-til-successor-in-place/2012/10/26/4f794786-1f7f-11e2-afca-58c2f5789c5d_story.html |title=Clinton won't leave til successor in place |author=McCrummen, Stephanie |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=October 26, 2012}}</ref> Despite her continuing to express a lack of interest, speculation continued about Clinton as a possible candidate in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]].<ref name="nyt-gc-next">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/11/opinion/sunday/collins-hillarys-next-move.html |title=Hillary's Next Move |author=[[Gail Collins|Collins, Gail]] |newspaper=The New York Times |date=November 11, 2012 |page=SR1}}</ref><ref name="wapo-102612" /> A poll taken in Iowa, the first state in the nomination process, showed that in a hypothetical 2016 caucuses contest, Clinton would have 58 percent support, with Vice President Biden coming in next at 17 percent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/burns-haberman/2012/11/exclusive-clinton-would-dominate-iowa-caucuses-ppp-149064.html |title=Exclusive: Clinton would dominate 2016 Iowa caucuses, PPP shows |author=Burns, Alexander |newspaper=Politico |date=November 8, 2012}}</ref>
Later in November, Clinton traveled to Jersusalem, the West Bank, and Cairo, meeting with leaders [[Benjamin Netanyahu]], [[Mahmoud Abbas]] and [[Mohamed Morsi]] respectively, in an effort to stop the [[Operation Pillar of Defense|2012 Gaza conflict]]. On November 21, she participated in a joint appearance with Egyptian Foreign Minister [[Mohamed Kamel Amr]] to announce that a cease-fire agreement had been reached between Israel and Hamas in Gaza.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/11/21/world/meast/gaza-israel-strike/index.html |title=Cease-fire declared in Gaza conflict |publisher=CNN |date=November 21, 2012}}</ref> When the [[2012 Egyptian protests]] against Morsi broke out shortly thereafter, Clinton said that it showed how a dialogue between both sides was immediately needed on how to reshape that nation's constitution.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2012/12/05/egypt-morsi.html |title=Egypt clashes between Morsi backers, protesters hurt 200 |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=December 6, 2012}}</ref>
In mid-December, Clinton fell victim to a stomach virus contracted on a trip to Europe. She subsequently became very dehydrated and then fainted, suffering a mild concussion. As a result, she cancelled another trip and scratched an appearance at scheduled Congressional hearings on the Benghazi matter.<ref name="ap-conc" /><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/16/us/politics/hillary-clinton-concussion.html |title=Clinton Is Recovering From a Concussion |author=Mazzetti, Mark |author2=Gordon, Michael R. |newspaper=The New York Times |date=December 15, 2012}}</ref> A few conservative figures, including Congressman [[Allen West (politician)|Allen West]] and Ambassador to the UN [[John R. Bolton]], accused Clinton of fabricating her illness to avoid testifying, but a State Department spokesperson said that was "completely untrue" and Republican Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] denounced the allegations.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://security.blogs.cnn.com/2012/12/18/working-from-home-clinton-on-the-mend/?hpt=hp_t1 |title=State Department: Clinton not dodging Benghazi hearings |author=Levine, Adam |publisher=CNN |date=December 18, 2012}}</ref><ref name="cnn-flu">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/on-congress/2012/12/graham-back-off-hillary-on-flu-152648.html |title=Graham: Back off Hillary on flu |author=Kim, Seung Min |newspaper=Politico |date=December 21, 2012}}</ref>
On December 19, the Pickering–Mullen Accountability Review Board report on the Benghazi matter was released.<ref name="ARBReport">[[Thomas R. Pickering]], [[Michael Mullen]], et. al, [https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/202446.pdf Accountability Review Board report on Benghazi (Unclassified)] U.S. Department of State. December 18, 2012.</ref> It was sharply critical of State Department officials in Washington for ignoring requests for more guards and safety upgrades, and for failing to adapt security procedures to a deteriorating security environment.<ref name="upi-pm-arb">{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2012/12/19/Clinton-accepts-Benghazi-panel-guidance/UPI-34121355896475/ |title=Three in State Dept. resign after report |agency=[[United Press International]] |date=December 19, 2012}}</ref> It explicitly criticized the [[Bureau of Diplomatic Security]] and the [[Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs]]:<ref name="nyt-pm-arb" /> "Systemic failures and leadership and management deficiencies at senior levels within two bureaus of the State Department ... resulted in a special mission security posture that was inadequate for Benghazi and grossly inadequate to deal with the attack that took place."<ref name="ARBReport" /> Four State Department officials were removed from their posts as a consequence, including [[Assistant Secretary of State for Diplomatic Security]] [[Eric J. Boswell]] (who resigned completely), a deputy assistant secretary for embassy security, [[Charlene R. Lamb]], and a deputy assistant secretary for North Africa, [[Raymond Maxwell]].<ref name="nyt-pm-arb">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/20/us/politics/3-state-dept-officials-resign-following-benghazi-report.html |title=4 Are Out at State Dept. After Scathing Report on Benghazi Attack |author=Gordon, Michael R. |author2=Schmitt, Eric |newspaper=The New York Times |date=December 19, 2012}}</ref> The report did not criticize more senior officials in the department; Pickering said: "We fixed it at the assistant secretary level, which is, in our view, the appropriate place to look, where the decision-making in fact takes place, where, if you like, the rubber hits the road."<ref name="nyt-pm-arb" /> Clinton said in a letter to Congress that she accepted the conclusions of the Pickering–Mullen report,<ref name="upi-pm-arb" /> and a State Department task force was formed to implement some sixty action items recommended by the report.<ref name="pol-2dep" /> On December 20, the [[United States Deputy Secretary of State|Deputy Secretary of State]], [[William Joseph Burns|William J. Burns]], and the [[Deputy Secretary of State for Management and Resources]], [[Thomas R. Nides]], testified in her place before two Congressional committees, and said that many of the report's recommendations would be in place before year-end.<ref name="pol-2dep">{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2012/12/clinton-aides-testify-on-benghazi-85357.html |title=Hillary Clinton aides testify on Benghazi |author=Kim, Seung Min |author2=Nocera, Kate |newspaper=Politico |date=December 20, 2012}}</ref> Clinton planned to testify herself in January.<ref name="cnn-flu" />
The Benghazi matter also had an effect on Clinton's successor as Secretary of State. Obama's first choice was Ambassador to the UN [[Susan Rice]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505267_162-57548823/susan-rice-likely-hillary-clinton-replacement/ |title=Susan Rice likely Hillary Clinton replacement |publisher=CBS News|date=November 13, 2012 }}</ref> but she came under heavy criticism from Congressional Republicans for what they felt were incorrect or deceptive statements in the aftermath of the attack, and by mid-December she withdrew her name from consideration.<ref>{{cite news |first=Tracy |last=Connor |date=December 13, 2012 |url=http://rockcenter.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/12/13/15888883-exclusive-susan-rice-drops-out-of-running-for-secretary-of-state-cites-very-politicized-confirmation-process |title=Susan Rice drops out of running for secretary of state, cites 'very politicized' confirmation process |publisher=NBC News}}</ref> Obama then nominated Senator [[John Kerry]] for the position instead.<ref name="nyt-kerry-nom">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/22/us/politics/kerry-is-pick-for-secretary-of-state-official-says.html |title=Kerry Named for the Role of a Lifetime |author=Landler, Mark |newspaper=The New York Times |date=December 21, 2012 }}</ref> By one report, Clinton had preferred Kerry over Rice all along anyway.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/sneed/16724826-452/hillary-clinton-doesnt-fancy-rice.html |title=Sneed: Hillary Clinton no fan of Susan Rice, prefers Kerry for State |author=Sneed, Michael |newspaper=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |date=November 30, 2012}}</ref> Although still not well enough to attend the December 21 announcement of Kerry's nomination, Clinton was described by Obama as being "in good spirits" and, in a statement, praised Kerry as being of the "highest caliber".<ref name="nyt-kerry-nom" />
Clinton was scheduled to return to work the week of December 31,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/12/27/politics/clinton-back-to-work/index.html |title=Hillary Clinton returning to work next week |author=Labott, Elise |publisher=CNN |date=December 28, 2012}}</ref> but then on December 30 was admitted to [[New York-Presbyterian Hospital]] for treatment and observation after a blood clot related to the concussion was discovered.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/AP0cd301bf10544018a92795c8ff84c0ce |title=Hillary Clinton hospitalized with blood clot |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=December 30, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130102234002/http://online.wsj.com/article/AP0cd301bf10544018a92795c8ff84c0ce.html |archivedate=January 2, 2013}}</ref> On December 31 it was announced that the clot was behind her ear near her brain, specifically a right transverse sinus [[venous thrombosis]], that she was being treated with [[anticoagulant]]s, that she had not suffered any neurological damage, and that she was expected to make a full recovery.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-pn-hillary-clinton-blood-clot-recovery-20121231,0,2962900.story |title=Hillary Clinton expected to make full recovery from blood clot |author=Richter, Paul |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=December 31, 2012}}</ref>
==Final days of tenure== [[File:Hillary Clinton receives a football helmet.jpg|thumb|right|Secretary Clinton is welcomed back to work at the State Department on January 7, 2013]]
On January 2, 2013, Clinton was released from the hospital.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/hillary-clinton-to-return-to-work-next-week/2013/01/03/7494896a-55f1-11e2-bf3e-76c0a789346f_story.html |title=Hillary Clinton to return to work next week |author=Gearan, Anne |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=January 3, 2012}}</ref> She returned to work at the State Department on January 7, when co-workers welcomed her back with a standing ovation and a joke gift of a [[football helmet]] featuring the department's seal.<ref name="tel-dos-ret">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-politics/9786617/Hillary-Clinton-returns-to-work-with-American-football-helmet-gift.html |title=Hillary Clinton returns to work with American football helmet gift |agency=Agence France-Presse |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=January 7, 2013 |location=London}}</ref> It was her first normal public appearance in a month.<ref name="tel-dos-ret" />
[[File:Hillary Clinton receives a football jersey.jpg|thumb|right|Secretary Clinton receives a football jersey with 112, the number of countries she visited during her tenure]]
The illness did, however, put an end to her days of travel in the job.<ref name="nyt-amplified" /><ref name="wapo-travel" /> She finished with 112 countries visited, making her the most widely traveled secretary of state in history.<ref name="nyt-amplified">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/05/us/politics/scare-amplifies-fears-that-clintons-work-has-taken-heavy-toll.html |title=Scare Adds to Fears That Clinton's Work Has Taken Toll |author=Mark Landler |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 4, 2013}}</ref> Her total of 956,733 air miles ended up falling short of [[Condoleezza Rice]]'s record for total mileage.<ref name="nyt-amplified" /> That total, 1,059,207, was bolstered late in Rice's tenure by repeated trips to the Middle East.<ref name="csm-trav">{{cite news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Foreign-Policy/2012/0905/Hillary-Clinton-vs.-Condi-Rice-Who-gets-the-most-traveled-crown |title=Hillary Clinton vs. Condi Rice: Who gets the 'most traveled' crown? |author=LaFranchi, Howard |newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor |date=September 5, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/theoval/post/2012/06/clinton-rice-vie-for-most-traveled-secretary-of-state/1 |title=Clinton, Rice vie for most traveled secretary of State |author=Jackson, David |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=June 18, 2012}}</ref> Clinton traveled during 401 days, with 306 of those spent in actual diplomatic meetings, and spent the equivalent of 87 full days on airplanes.<ref name="nyt-amplified" /><ref name="wapo-travel" /> Compared to other recent secretaries, Clinton traveled more broadly, with fewer repeat visits to certain countries.<ref name="wapo-travel">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/post/hillary-clintons-overseas-diplomacy-versus-other-secretaries-of-state/2013/01/08/742f46b2-59f3-11e2-9fa9-5fbdc9530eb9_blog.html |title=Hillary Clinton's overseas diplomacy versus other secretaries of state |author=Kessler, Glenn |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=January 9, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Hillary Rodham Clinton farewell remarks to State Department employees.jpg|thumb|right|Secretary Clinton gives her farewell remarks to State Department employees on her last day in office, February 1, 2013]]
On January 23, Clinton finally gave more than five hours of testimony on the Benghazi matter before hearings of the [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] and the [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|House Foreign Affairs Committee]].<ref name="cnn-0123-hearings" /> She said with a choking voice, "For me, this is not just a matter of policy, it's personal. I stood next to President Obama as the Marines carried those flag-draped caskets off the plane at Andrews.
